reviewText: 1:39 gave me chills. I love shows like this!

An excellent story and presentation!

Julian Fellows is the best

Loved it
Really enjoyed this series.
Love these types of clean, quality entertainment and loved being introduced to a new British author I was unaware of!
The Dr is steamy.

Pure, unadulterated treacle. A shame, because I like the actors in other projects they've been involved in. And for some odd reason Julian Fellowes feels a need to chat both before and at the end of each episode. I didn't like the practice when Alfred Hitchcock did it, and I don't like it here.

While Downton Abbey was Fellow's opus, this is not; although it has incited myself to read the story as the book is generally far superior to the 'movie/television' rendition I did enjoy the good doctor's stoic wisdom not to mention calm demeanor and nice looks.
Truly a treasured find. Lots of humor... Lots of dreams made true.
No rape, no murder, no torture scenes, no high speed car chases, just a great romantic story, great book, great movie!
great ty

This is awful.
a C Plus is pushing this review!  DONT WASTE YOUR TIME!
Loved Tom Hollander - perfect actor for the part - and i loved Dr. Thorne, his character.
I loved this series... the storyline, actors, and setting were all excellent.  thank you!
Good!!

I really did love this little miniseries.  It was completely predictable but it was just fun to watch.  There was humor, romance and intrigue.  What's not to love?  The costumes were beautiful to see on screen and the settings were breathtaking.  The acting was of good quality and I actually enjoyed the little fireside chats with Julian Fellowes.  It's clear Mr. Fellowes loved this novel and seeing it made into a move, I can see why.  There is nothing truly groundbreaking here but it's fun little escape.  I hope Mr. Fellowes chooses to do more of these because they are quite fun.
Please make more of these wonderful series!
What a sweet, fun story - I wish there was more!
Loved it. A sweet family friendly series with a happy ending.
Loved, loved, but want more episodes.
Julianne Fellowes does an excellent job with an intro & ending for each episode. It was delightful and by the end I wanted more which is always a good sign. Great cast, costume & set design. Enjoy!
Loved the series!  It was too short.  Very well done.

I could not believe my eyes, the bad ratings and what was said. 1) I am American and found the American Character charming and never offensive in any way. IT IS JUST A CHARACTER for goodness sake. 2) I Absolutely enjoyed this little series. 3) I will also enjoy picking up the book and reading it myself with my teenage children. 4) Very well put together. 5) NOT boring. I watched all episodes back to back and wish there were more. BRAVO!
GREAT STORY
I absolutely loved this! I really hope that they bring Julian Fellowes back to do another one or even rotate authors to bring these stories to life.

It's like Masterpiece Theater mixed with Alfred HItchcock Presents.  Julian Fellowes opens and closes each episode with commentary.  Definitely not on par with Downton Abbey, but a quick watch that enjoyable if not that well acted.

Not Downton Abbey, not so much. More like Jane Austen, with a little bit of Dickens and costumed in puffy skirts. Good pace, good acting, good production values, feels a little like a soap opera, especially when compared to other adaptations.  Still, fun to watch, especially if you like period pieces
Love it. .. good story telling. No smut.
I enjoyed this season very much. Very positive and uplifting.
love it
My wife really enjoyed this.

I loved all of it and may watch it again to get a good grip on who's related to whom, and who killed Dr. Thorne's brother, and why things developed in an odd way.  Dr. Thorne himself is a predictably kind and tactful middle-class doctor who seems to have favor with everyone.  He's almost too perfect, but he it the glue that binds all these various classes in a Victorian countryside.  I gave it five stars because it left me wanting more.  If the series ended here, the conclusion to this season would suffice.  Apparently the viewers have spoken and hopefully, we will get more. I agree that this is nowhere near the caliber of Downton. The period does not demand the sophistication in the characters as they do in Downton. Don't let that deter you......it is more on the stiff proper Sense and Sensibility genre.

My only critical comment is dear Julian Fellowes presenting each episode and following with a summary.  Not meaning to sound harsh but it reminded me of the format of the Alfred Hitchcock series with a more gentrified presentation.  I hope that is discontinued now that we have sunk our teeth into this series and have enjoyed the fare.
Thoroughly enjoyed this wonderful period piece. Julian Fellowes does not disappoint.
Really enjoyed it!
Beautiful locations and great actors. Enjoyed it.
A gentle drama, not as severe as Downton. Very enjoyable and as with all of Fellowe's work, a very beautifully filmed piece.

This was a great show and I ended up binge watching season 1!  It has a great story line and I was so glad to find something so good that didn't have bad language, violence or anything else.  Wish more writers would do that!!

This was one of the best series I've watched so far this year. There were powerful women, men with many flaws, and youngsters trying to do what was best for them despite their parents' interference. I loved every second of it, especially Julian Fellowes introduction and conclusion as bookends to the presentation. During my treadmill walks, I was able to spend 4 days watching the superb writing and acting. I'm hopeful that Julian Fellowes considers doing more of these limited series for Amazon.
Nice period drama.  Well put together and I liked that Julian had a bit to say about each episode.

Absolutely fabulous, lighthearted and magical.
Love period dramas. This one is up there on my list.
Enjoy!
Cant wait for movies to be made of all Julian Fellows books.
The sweetest love story between Mary & Frank <3
wish there was more then just 4 ep. this is a great story

I thought it was fun!  It is definitely worth watching.  It doesn't rip your heart out with drama ... it's a nice escape ... spoiler alert ... with a happy ending .. just as it should be .. like Jane Austen.
Good if you like these old English type stories.
completely predictable

This is fairly lightweight as dramas go.  It's even predictable.  But, it has a happy ending and after Drummond was killed off in "Victoria," I think I needed a happy ending.  Sets, costumes, location, scenes, acting, notable actors - all great.  It's only four episodes so I did the whole series in one evening.
Feels much alike to Downton Abbey

I really enjoyed it! I loved Dr Thorne`s performance, I remember him as Mr. Collins in Pride and Prejudice, he was so much better in this story, he held it all together, and such amazing acting with his compassion at the death bed and also his anger at injustices. He was brilliant! My favorite actor.
The whole story was lovely.
great

MOST: The Era, Author, 80% of casting. Rich people being rich complicated good bad. The usual. Fellowes. Bad? Well these storylines have a way of working out happily in the end......so not exactly sitting on the edge of your seat.
Ok.
loved it!

I absolutely enjoyed watching Doctor Thorne!  <3 This is what I would consider a classic and very original. The storyline is far interesting and I love all the characters! Honestly, I found the last episode to be hilarious after Dr. Thorne announced the news to Frank's mom! I started to crack up lol
Really enjoyed this original series.
I enjoy Trollope very much and the production was beautifully done. I very much appreciated the insight and background from Mr. Fellowes
Positively the best series I have seen.. Incredible acting and brilliant storyline.  My only wish is that there would be more episodes!

I truly enjoyed the four episodes, with the exception of the interruption at the beginning and end of each by Julian Fellowes, an Alfred Hitchcock wannabe.  I would have given the presentation 5 stars were it not for his strange insertion of himself, which appears to be ego gone awry. He would have served this production better by remaining in the writers' room. This was basically a good story. The role of Louis was over acted and poorly done. Loved the role of the charming leading lady.
I enjoyed it.
I wish the guy didn't come on screen before and after every episode.
A delightful story and very well done.
I loved it! At first I thought it would be dull but I binged an devoured the entire season in one sitting!! Delightful!
Five stars for Tom Hollander!  Three for the series.

It was a little hard for me to follow at first, but once I understood how the characters were related to one another I throughoughly enjoyed it. It was a funny, dramatic, romantic, historic, mysterious series.
This is entertainment.
What a wonderful story!
Innocent, sweet, easy to watch but didn't find it nearly as good as other series I have enjoyed.
A bit boring. Nice sets and costumes. Poor acting and lousy chemistry on the part of the younger actors. Not in line with the customs of the Victorian era. A lazy, contrived period piece at best.

Oh, dear.  I'm a great fan of Anthony Trollope, and Dr. Thorne is one of my favorites.  This adaptation, though, is thin, shallow, and rather vulgar.
One of the joys of Trollope is the sheer volume and flow of language:  the copious back-stories on every character, the long asides to the reader on social mores, the fourth-wall-breaking meta-narrative of the narrator justifying his own choices.  Having taken out all that, the mere plot is only melodrama, and not very compelling at that.
Trollope is quite cheekily aware of the absurdity of his characters, but Fellowes does not seem to be. By playing it more or less straight, he allows the viewer the cheap thrill of feeling superior to the characters; Trollope undercuts the reader's moral superiority by implicating himself as well as the reader.  Trollope serves ambiguity, but Fellowes does away wit all that in favor of obviousness.
There is also something very modern in the performances, especially on the part of Mary and Young Frank, and that is not a compliment.
Very much a made-for-TV movie, with all the shallowness that implies.
The costumes and sets were pretty.
This movie will be enjoyed by everyone who loves stories of England in the 1800s.

Pathetic little story. A common person absolutely cannot identify with this idiotic story. Here, Scatcherd who made his money by hard work is a drunkard. His son even more so and is called "pathetic" by Fellowes at the end. Somehow the Squire who lost all his money through gambling or whatever is to be saved at the end because "they have been there forever". What complete utter nonsense.

Same nonsensical premises as Downton Abbey, some rich "noble" English family is in trouble and somehow they find some self-made rich person or the heir of the self-made rich person to save their estate via marriage or engagement or an altered Will. Immediately and conveniently that self-made rich person or the heir is bumped off so the main loser characters who are in "love" can marry and live happily, not ever after mind you but only for a while, before they inevitably squander the money too.

And people are supposed to like these characters? Every character is hate-able and punch-able in this story. Even the maternally Lady Scatchered who favors mopey Frank over her own son Louis. How do people eat this elephant excrement up?

The costumes were good I guess.

I love British period pieces and this did not disappoint.  It's more of a movie shown in parts than a "season."  But that's fine.  I watched the whole thing in one sitting.  Great acting and a good adaptation by Julian Fellowes.  Very enjoyable entertainment......
Great clean and Heartwarming show!! I hope they make more like this! My husband and I enjoyed the show.
I loved it, I wish there could be a second season, but its still one of the best.
a bit of a cross between Austen and Dickens!!!

I enjoyed this adaptation of the book for the most part. My biggest problem is that we never see why Mary is viewed by nearly everyone we meet (Dr Throne, Beatrice, Augusta, Frank, etc) as such a very special person. We see her help her uncle nurse Sir Roger (1 patient); we see her deliver 2 food baskets to poor villagers (1 occasion of good works). That's all. Some conversation where Mary tells her uncle she's going to help such a family, or helping with the church, would have added more to her character. I agree with another reviewer who thought the actress playing Mrs Dunstable much too young; she looked a contemporary to Mary or Frank's sisters, rather than nearly middle aged, as she is in the book.
fun, good story line period piece.

I loved it from start to finish! Yes, some twists and turns, but a happy ending is always desirable. The humor in the last episode was wonderful and so well thought and acted out. I'll even want to watch it again . . . and again!
Excellent four-part series. full of characters you instantly love (and hate).  I'd encourage Amazon and Julian Fellowes to throw their energies into more stuff of this quality!
Just lovely

I quite enjoyed watching Doctor Thorne! Although the plot was slightly predictable, I found myself eagerly anticipating the next episode. The characters, Dr. Thorne in particular, were intriguing and dynamic; each one brought his/her own flare to the story. The fireside introductions and conclusions to each episode were a nice touch as well. Overall, this series is worth a watch!
best show iv watched on amazon yet. Very enjoyable !!
loved it! There needs to be more shows just like this. Uplifting and true.

Superb actors and writers aside, it is with regret that I must offer only one star in review because the financier of this show is pitifully offensive to American women.  Godspeed Lord Fellows.  Please find better company in which to keep.

Wonderful miniseries! Someone mentioned Doctor Thorne was a "Step Down" from Downton Abbey. I don't think you can make a side by side comparison because Downton Abbey was a long running series with a lot of  storylines & character complexities. Doctor Thorne told a simple storyline & the characters were more predictable ~ but still a good well-rounded story!
I was worried I wasn't going to like it at first but I'm really glad I kept watching! What a great story!
Positively one of the best mini series I have seen. Captivating and exciting at every turn.
Beautiful story, cast and location.
I still love a good fairy tale! And the Brits still know how to do one.
well done
Adored this!
Enjoyed the showing.  Very predictable plot and ending. But, the snobby old bitty should be thrown out on her ****.
Enjoyed the characters very much. The settings were indeed of the Age of Victorian slender.  Story line contained all the elements that make a novel a pleasure to read or watch,
Unraveling of the plot and the ultimate resolution of it is predictable at best and boring at worst.
Fun, engaging, and satisfying ending!
An outstanding story that had all the elements of emotion and greed. Hope there will be more seasons.
Loved the happy ending.... so simple yet refreshingly different from the depressing Victorian versions I am so used to watching.
Great sets, colorful characters and plenty of fun all round.  Where is season 2?
Nowhere near as good as Julian Fellowes prior endeavor.

I have to say it was absolutely adorable for the shortness. I recommend it to anybody that loves this genre. It is a simple love story with everything you could ask for in it. 10/10 would watch again.
I loved this series!

This series lacks in definition, as a painting without a subject. The characters are all silly, along with being contradictory of themselves.  The story line lacks interest, and at its best is boring, lacking intelligent, creative or comprehensive writing. Don't waste your time, if that's a commodity that is important to you.

I didn't go into this comparing it to Downton Abbey. I never finished Downton Abbey. I enjoyed this a lot. The story did end in what some might call an unrealistic happy ending but so few movies and shows seem to have happy endings anymore. People are complex and life can deal some unfair circumstances but so many shows just end up coming across as so depressing its maddening. I loved the story and thought it was executed really well in this miniseries.
Absolutely lovely! Wish it had lasted longer--but at least I've found a new period author.

I'd recommend not watching it with the expectation of Downton 2.0. It's clearly its own show. But oh so good!!! I loved every minute of it! The ending had me sitting on the edge of my seat and cheering it on! I definitely recommend this show! A must see!!!
Very good with no trash.
Good storyline and acting. Not quite Downton Abbey but enjoyable without smut or foul language. Shows adults appreciate.
I really enjoyed this Series.  Easy to watch, beautifully filmed.  Since I cannot handle sitcoms and reality shows, it was nice to have a real quality entertaining show.
Pretty decent....more of a chick flick.

A lovely little period piece. I would have to say the ending is not as shiny as the beginning but a show can only be as good as it's source material. The ending is tied up farrr too tidy for my tastes but I guess that's the Trollope style. I feel the production and acting itself deserves five stars but the narrative is much more three stars.

I still found it delightful for the cast. Tom Hollander as Doctor Thorne is the dad you always wanted. He is just unbelievably charming and fun to watch. For a character that seems to have zero flaws, Hollander makes him so incredibly charismatic and human.

Harry Richardson is of course, a dream as Frank Grisham. He completely lights up the screen with charm. And Stefanie Martini is absolutely delightful as Mary. So yes, a bit frothy and fluffy under the seams but definitely a delightful watch anyways.

As to what to watch next, add Poldark and North & South to your list after all the Austen classics of course :)

Just finished this. It was Ok, but for those expecting another Downton Abbey, it was nowhere near. As you know Julian Fellows was the writer for both. I love period dramas and especially 3 or 4 part adaptations of English classics, like the Jane Austen's you see all the time on Masterpiece Theater. There are 2 better Anthony Trollope adaptations that I have seen. Those are The Way We Live Now and He Knew He Was Right, which are available in many places to view.
loved it
Outstanding.
Great show
This was a true delight! Good writing and well cast. I didn't want it to end!
loved it
I wish there were more like this! This was a great adaptation of a great classic.

I enjoyed the Doctor Thorne miniseries very much. I thought it was visually appealing, well acted, and resonated nicely of Julian Fellows' influence. My regret is the limited duration however, as I viewed it in its' entirety in one morning. Being a steadfast Downton Abbey enthusiast, I am looking for a period drama for the long term to fill in the gaps of time when I have completely rewatched Downton and need something to redirect my attention. I would very much like to see more period offerings from Mr. Fellows in the future - so far I have yet to see anything which has captivated me as much as my all time favorite series - the incomparable Downton Abbey. But I am certainly up to continuing the search, and Dr. Thorne was a very worthy watch.
It was great!!!  Not quite Downton....but it will do.  More of this, please.
Stop looking and watch this! I've passed this series so many times - I had no idea what I was missing! Beautifully done.
Excellent story of the topsy turvy life of the noble set.

This movie is a visual feast!  I love the gorgeous English castles, countryside, and gardens as well as the beautiful Victorian period costumes.  I also love the movie's themes of "good triumphs over evil" and "love conquers all". Especially enjoyable for those who have visited England and seen such castles and scenery. You'll enjoy this if you like happy endings.
loved it!!! THANKS AMAZON!!
well made and vastly entertaining!

Absolutely LOVED this series. It ended much too soon. If you like Jane Austen books put into movies, such as "Pride and Prejudice" with Colin Firth, you'll love this! One interesting thing to note, this storyline is nearly exactly the same as the storyline of a book written by Louise May Alcot, "The Inheritance." Not sure who wrote the first story, but I'd say one of the author's plagiarized the other's idea!
I really loved this season! I hope there is another season.
I loved this movie!
Please make a season two- even if Anthony Trollope didn't.
Fabulous show!
Brilliant !!! The writing, acting, sets, costumes are so wonderful!!! Love it!!!
Well done Trollope, perhaps Trollope's "the American Senator" or "Rachel Ray" as an encore. I don't know of any production of either and they both have fetching heroines.

It's no Downton Abbey, but I watched it straight through all the episodes until 4:30 in the morning so it's certainly entertaining. I really enjoyed the Masterpiece Theater-style presentation; I kinda want that guy to read us the story :) Hope to see more like this.
I loved it.  Would have like 3 or 4 more episodes though to get in the more characters.
excellent show
A wonderful watch!!! Wholesome, humorous and uplifting!!
Simply lovely! From the first to the last scene.

I enjoyed this tv series with the Victorian age in mind.  I think, though, you could figure out what was going to happen by what was set up already.  Very sweet, all the same.  Makes me want to look up the author and actually read the book.
It was a very entertaining movie with excellent costumes, humor, and just the perfect amount of drama.
What a great story!! I only wish there was more!!
Heartwarming
I really liked this story! Great actors, well-told.
Nowhere near as good as Downton Abbey or Gosford Park, but still a quality production.
Loved it! Fantastic to see Mr. Fellows at the fireside chat. Beautifully acted, lovely story. Wish there was more!

In his inimitable style Julian Fellowes's charming adaption Dr. Throrne from Anthony Trollope's Chronicles of Barsetshire delights not only his fans of Downton Abbey but fans of Masterpiece Theater and a particular brand of British literature, TV, and movies.
I particularly enjoyed his fireside chat's before and after each episode that were so reminiscent of the Master of Masterpiece Theater Alistair Cook.
Besides his writing skills Mr Fellowes has an eye for historical authenticity so that the characters and settings are very creditable . The countryside was lovely, the stately houses were perfect, the village  charming, and along with the superb costuming made for a charming visual confection.
Some reviewers have referred to it as lightweight and amusing. Both of which I think the world needs a little bit more of.  Happy endings have a great appeal.
I think if Amazon is smart this will be the beginning of a long and happy collaboration with Mr. Fellowes.
Enjoyed each episode
This was a surprisingly engaging series. I enjoyed the plot and relationship twists and turns.
You guys are gana like...make more, right?
Great story
Love it!
Engaging and heartwarming. Nice to have good guys and bad again in a TV show, and something that doesn't revolve around illicit sex.

Very entertaining.  The series walks a fine line of camp, cheese and quality.  Fortunately, it teeters in the direction of quality, and allows the viewer to enjoy the tale, tongue in cheek.  Lots of fun.  I needed to watch something light hearted and this was able to fill that order without being Hallmark Christmas Movie sentimentality.  Well written, bravo Julian Fellowes. And well acted, kudos to the cast.
Absolutely love this show! 5/5 stars! Will be watching again! There needs to be a second season however

I really love the language in this story as well as the plot and characters. I agree with Julian Fellowes; it belongs with the classics. I also thought it was a clever idea to have the actor from Pride and Prejudice (the newer version) play the doctor in this story. It made it stand out more. Thank whoever decided to keep it a clean video for having that idea - it would have ruined it for me had it had anything stupid like that in it. This was a GREAT series.
Definitely a must watch!!!
Love it!!!!
Great Victorian era story! I have heard it was cancelled. Why? We are left hanging. Can it be brought back?
SO RIDICULOUSLY ADORABLE!

Could not have loved it more. Simply brilliant. And because of its quality, its density of delightful character and charm, I can be fully satisfied with only the four precious episodes presented, although of course, more would be an irresistible indulgence.
Loved this series! I want more!
This was surprisingly good, even if it is predictable. Doesn't measure up to Downton though.

Started with an interesting introduction from Julian Fellowes.  I was intrigued until it began with this incredibly hokey music that sounded like something from the 50s comedy on TV  .
 I was so disappointed as there were good actors and an interesting plot but I couldn't bear to listen to the music ruin it.

Doctor Thorne is definitely not a "Downton" hit. Rather a sorry attempt by Julian Fellowes to formulate success instead of giving Trollope the full respect he deserved.  On the face of it, Doctor Thorne is  just fine and quite enjoyable.  What is not so enjoyable is being subjected to an introduction and epilogue by the egocentric and insufferably pompous Julien Fellowes. How I wish there was a way to remove him from the equation.

For a mini series, it is simply marvelous. A must watch.
Plus... Frank is a babe. #swoon
I really enjoyed this story. The actors were marvelous and the story was engaging.  Wish it was longer!
This miniseries is short and worth one or two "quick" binge sessions. Formulaic and predictable (but that's on Trollope not Fellowes), BUT pleasant to watch. Go for it!
I enjoyed this but the series seems a bit too short!
entertaining, romance and great ending

Fantastic entertainment! Great adaptation and wonderful acting. And the locations and costumes, of course, to die for. Completely engrossing story of human characters. I hope Julian Fellowes takes on more Trollope.
Adorable  Just what I needed.
Entertaining show.

I really enjoyed this series. I had never heard of this book, and so I had no clue where the story was going to go. It seemed at first that it was going to be a sad story, but it turned out really well. A little predictable by the time it came to the end of Episode 3, but still I enjoyed it. I did not like Downtown Abbey at all as to me it seemed too much of a soap opera, so Julian Fellowes presenting this series made me a little leery at first. I am so glad I watched it.
Good story. Good acting. I'm fond of screen adaptations of novels.
I love period pieces... especially ones with happy endings and a love story!
Stunning locations, landscapes, costumes, dialogue and intrigue. This is very well done and has an authentic period tone. Witty and humorous writing showcase perfectly rendered scenes. Bravo.
Fantastic period series
Loved this period of History and nobles and the rich lady's with their frocks

This is okay. It feels a bit stiff and stilted. I am not sure if it's the writing, the pacing, or the way it's shot. It just feels like old style tv.

Anyway, the story is fine. It's a tale about rich people who spend more than they earn so they have to marry money to maintain their lifestyle. The problem is, they are snobs, and the only people they know with money are beneath them. This snobbery creates some problems for the two lovers who actually don't care about that.

There is some humor and a lot of veiled preaching that I am sure went over well back in the day. The human qualities are intact and the story still plays well today.
A lovely dip into 1850s English society.  The plot is a bit predictable, but that lay with the author of the novel.  Cast was superb and as always shot beautifully.
What a wonderful tale! I do hope that there is more than one season in the works.
This is a wonderful rendition of Trollope's writings.. Please treat yourself by reading one of Anthony Trollope's novels.  You will thank PBS and me for this recommendation.
Entertaining.  Actors played their parts well.
This era of clothing and style is fascinating, I enjoy the time period of this show and setting.  Great story!
Worth every moment.  Might be a tad predictable, but being every the romantic, it was a welcome journey away from real life.

I hate the "look" of this.  The colors are fake and unnatural. Also, the characters are shallow and unlikable.  Just my opinion and obviously I am in the minority based on the reviews here but at some point there is such a thing as too much color and this has definitely reached it.  Downton Abbey was much easier on they eyes. I think that this was filmed with a type of technique that must be state of the art but I really do not like it and it detracts from the feeling of authenticity.  IT LOOKS TOO MODERN. Also, the accents are completely inauthentic.  I cannot believe that this comes from the same person who brought us Downton Abbey.
Witty, romantic, funny!

A great story done by Downton Abbey's Jullian Fellows. He's a master at creating masterpieces of the visual arts. You'll enjoy Dr. Thorne! The picture of Mary Thorne for the feature is not very flattering, but the story is far better than the picture tells. I was first off-put by the featured picture for this Series. But after watching the series, I found that I really liked the tale!

Finally an Amazon original I enjoyed (and finished). The story is sweet, a little lighter than Downton Abbey but very engaging. It is not up to old Masterpiece Theater/BBC standards but I am assuming the target audience is less literary, more visual, and wants their stories to move along. The lead actress's make up was a bit much but again maybe meant for a younger audience. I even enjoyed "Kilwillie's" intros and wrap-ups. They were a bit campy and trite, but endearing nonetheless. The four episodes went by much too fast.
Please bring more seasons. I loved it!!!

I loved watching Julian Fellowes as our Masterpiece Theatre host. He is completely charming. The story isn't Downton Abbey-it is very simple by comparison and also short. Pretty typical Victorian romance but enjoyable to watch and not overwhelmingly dark like some of these can be.

I absolutely adore this show - well written, well acted, and overall the perfect balance of drama and happiness. There was great character development and the main romance story was incredibly sweet and innocent. Overall a wonderful show!
I think it was delightful,,
I didn't like the cast.  Plot is boring and slow.  Too much similarity to Downton which Fellows also did.  Disappointing.
Absolutely a very well made and acted show.  i enjoyed it quite a lot.  Looking forward to the next season!

I am such a big fan of masterpiece..however Dr Thorne was a bit disappointing. very predictable story. one loses interest as soon as we find out who she actually is . there was no excitement or curiosity for next scene..
without criticizing much, all I would say, it was ok to kill some time.
So enjoyable that I binged on the whole season !! A story that won't disappoint. Highly recommend.
Wish there were more than four episodes!

having not read the book I was unfamiliar with the plot, but found myself enjoying this movie for being alot less depressing than other such period pieces. The characters may be a bit less complex & more idealistic, but that's the way I prefer them
Liked it so much I purchased the movie, as it belongs with my Jane Austin movies  ;)
Loved this series!

Totally entertaining, marvelous acting--a completely delightful bit of fluff. that also incorporates social wisdom about money and class Of course, you need to be a fan of the posh soap opera genre to really enjoy this.
It was so boring and predictable, bad acting, just horrible.
Incredibly stupid, predictable and boring. I feel like I just lost hours of precious life on this. The only thing that makes it worth watching is the costumes and scenery.
Binge tested and approved.
Slow start, but got really interesting.  If you like Downton Abbey, you'll like this.  Similarly, the characters are well written and slowly develop.

The outcome was predictable from the first episode but it was a fun ride. Good acting, humorous situations and perfect for any Jane Austen lover.

The most interesting character is Dr. Thorne himself, the man the series is named after, but he doesn't really get a whole lot to do. Everyone else is very boring and predictable in comparison. The only other interesting element is that there is a certain sense of danger that a lot of these types of period series lack, in that two characters fight a losing battle with alcoholism. There was no romance I found myself rooting for. The only thing I really wanted was more on Dr. Thorne and the life he has outside of his niece or the friends he might keep, but unfortunately, we just don't get enough of his character or much on his background. He's clearly an upstanding and honorable man: why has he remained single in a society that is all about connections? I really liked him and the series would benefit from more of him! The series is called Doctor Thorne, not All About Mary.

Compared to many videos I soon stopped watching, Doctor Thorne is a delight. Julian Fellowes' interspersed comments are part of the entertainment, making it clear that he was having a good time. An ending predictable long before it arrives did not diminish the pleasure.

Lead roles are well played, and one of Frank's sisters has amazing eyes. Several supporting roles are overplayed, however: At one point, I envisioned Louis, the male villain, twirling his mustache after having laid a young lady across the railroad tracks.

In hopes that Trollope reveals the key rags to riches back story, I've begun to read the book, but it is incredibly wordy. I admire Fellowes' ability to cut to the chase but not his ignoring that important ingredient. In that respect, the video is unpredictable. Some may regard that observation as a spoiler, but I regard it, coupled with aforementioned weak acting, as grounds for awarding only four stars.

For those who enjoyed period dramas, this one will do quite nicely. Based upon the book of the same name by Anthony Trollope and adapted for television by Julian Fellowes, the creator of Downton Abbey, this is a well-done period drama. The cast is uniformly excellent, as are the settings and costumes. The observance of the social mores of the time serve to ground its authenticity of time and place. Aficionados of period dramas will most definitely like this four part series, though it lacks the grandeur of Downton Abbey.

Dr. Thorne lives with Mary, his niece, in Greshamsbury, home of the Greshams, who used to rule all they surveyed. With the changing of the times, however, money has proven to be in short supply for the Greshams, and the need to marry off the Gresham children to those with deep pockets has become of paramount necessity in order to maintain the status quo. Their mother, the Lady Arabella is determined to ensure that this happens but runs into a roadblock when she discovers that her son, Frank, has fallen in love with Mary. Therein lies the rub.

The machinations of the Lady Arabella to ensure that her plans come to fruition, and the fact that Mary harbors a ruinous secret, all serve to create tension and drama throughout the four episodes. The series concludes with episode four with no loose ends. So, it is a stand alone season in case there is no follow-up. Still, I can't help but hope that there will be a season two.

3 1/2 Stars.  I'm not surprised that Julian Fellowes selected this Trollope tale to film.  Like his Downton Abbey, there was nary a surprise to be had, from beginning to end, every plot point as predictable as the rising and setting of the sun.  Zero suspense.  Even so (as with Downton), the settings and costumes were lush, the actors personable, engaging and believable.  For me, Tom Hollander (I'm a fan) as Dr. Thorne was the bulwark of the production, the rock.  Without him (Ian McShane was great too) , the production would've been even more insipid, purely a drama of manners.  One reviewer likened this to Emma or Sense and Sensibility- can't agree with that, they were clever and anything but predictable.  This isn't BAFTA calibre film making by any stretch of the imagination (pun intended) but even so, worth watching for the eye candy and performances.

Tom Hollander plays "Doctor Throne," the dignified moral center in a miniseries directed by Niall MacCormick and adapted by Julian Fellowes from Anthony Trollope's novel.  The story is set in England during the 1850s.  Thorne's niece, Mary (Stefanie Martini), is a lovely and kindhearted woman who has won the heart of her childhood friend, handsome Frank Gresham (Harry Richardson).  However, nothing is simple in Trollope's world. Frank's family is deeply in debt; if he does not acquire a fortune by making the proper match, the Greshams will lose their estate, status, and comfortable lifestyle.  Frank's mother, Lady Arabella, caustically and frequently reminds her son of his duty.  Still, when Frank gazes into Mary's lovely eyes, he cannot resist telling her that he intends to make her his wife.

Executive producer Julian Fellowes introduces each of the episodes and "debriefs" us afterwards. Viewers will "ooh" and "ah" at the gorgeous scenery, stately mansions, lavish costumes, and meticulous attention to period detail. Hollander is wonderful as an intelligent and reasonable individual who behaves honorably in spite of the pressures he faces. The always watchable Ian McShane stands out as wealthy reprobate Sir Roger Scatcherd, an ill-tempered drunk who treats his wife like a poor relation.  Also notable is Rebecca Front, perfect as the sharp-tongued, mercenary, and domineering Lady Arabella Gresham.  Alison Brie is the wry and witty Lady Dunstable, an American oil heiress who may be getting on in years, but her fortune makes her a prize catch. Alas, Edward Franklin has the thankless task of trying to imbue the role of Louis, Sir Roger's ne'er-do-well son, with a semblance of realism. Louis is an insecure and jealous braggart who clings to his flask like a baby to his bottle.  He is thoroughly one dimensional--an immature, stubborn, and self-destructive wretch.

Its visual splendor notwithstanding, "Doctor Thorne" is, at heart, a soap opera in which male and female malcontents do what they can to improve their lot at the expense of others.  Fellowes captures Trollope's dry sense of humor, satirical attitude, and insight into the pettiness, snobbery, and greed of England's pampered classes. In the final episode, the plot is wrapped up as neatly and prettily as an extravagant gift.  This diverting entertainment is easy on the eyes, but only occasionally engages us intellectually and emotionally.  The bonus features are quite good.  Fellowes eloquently expresses his enthusiasm for Trollope, while members of the cast and crew share their views about the making of "Doctor Thorne."

Frankly, Oscar Wilde's The Importance Of Being Ernest" did it much better, but this is still worth watching just to experience the typical Victorian novel. Julian Fellowes's narrative at the beginning is an obvious copy of Alistair Cooke's introduction to Masterpiece Theater years ago. I can't image why his adaptation is so bad when he did such a good job with Downton Abbey. You can guess the ending before you are even halfway through - there are no surprises anywhere in this story.

What a great series!!!!  I'm a huge fan of Downton Abbey, The Crown, and Bleak House.  So this series was right up my alley.  Great storyline and plot.  From beginning to end, it was well done. I enjoyed it and Sir Julian did an excellent job of summarizing the book.  I was so interested in the production that I decided to read the book first.  The book is all about the fact that Frank MUST MARRY money in order not to be evicted from the ancestral home and the machinations of his family as well as the deCourcy's to discourage him from marrying Mary.  There were a few slight changes to the book, but I think they really enhanced the story.  I liked the fact that Frank was totally committed to Mary even when she was poor.  Loved the production and the casting....I only gave it 4 stars because the characters (from the book) weren't that compelling.

Tender story of young love defying convention and confronting the exigencies of earning one's way in a system that looked down on those who had to work. Beautifully staged and performed by winsome leads who could only have ended up together.

I absolutely loved Julian Fellowes' work in Downton Abbey, which was amazing on so many levels. This attempt, however, was a rather sad disappointment, but I believe that he probably did the best he could with the story he chose to adapt to the screen. Hopefully the future will find him more discerning regarding what will possibly capture the attention and any high accolades from his audience. HE will always be a fantastic writer .. the material, though, left a lot to be desired.

I thoroughly enjoyed Dr. Thorne. My husband and I have watched it twice and enjoyed it even more the second time around. Dr. Thorne is Julian Fellowes next project after his huge success with Downton Abby.  Think Jane Austin with before and after fireside chats by Alfred Hitchcock. Its quite apparent Julian Fellowes loves this production and his on camera chats.
Dr. Thorne is not serious television, but a wonderfully delightful escape from violence and reality TV. So, on the next blustery winters evening, curl up with your favorite hot beverage and begin this four part journey back in time.

This is an entertaining series in the genre of Downton Abbey about the challenges of life in 19th century England in the context of the old British class system. This class system was portrayed as causing complications to members of both the upper and lower classes in issues of personal liberty, free choice, personal responsibility, and family and societal expectations.  The acting and story line is good, but in my estimation neither with quite the quality of Downton Abbey..

My wife and I both love all things England, especially the history, stories, myths and lore of the landed, titled gentry. From Upstairs, Downstairs, to Downton Abbey, and Sherlock Holmes to Gosford Park. We're now watching Victoria on Netflix. But, having read many of Trollope's works about Victorian England earlier in my life, I stumbled across this 4-episode gem that was adapted by Downton Abbey's creator Julian Fellowes. It's on Amazon Prime, and the story has been cut into four roughly 45-minute episodes. However, we consumed these in one sitting, and it was well worth it. The cast was perfect for their respective roles, although most of them are not well known here in America. But, in English circles, many are regulars in television, movie and stage roles. They were marvelous as either representative of inherited wealth, the newly "working" wealthy and the more common folks of the village...such as Dr. Thorne. It turns out, he has a secret about his niece that is later revealed (no spoilers here!), and at the end of the episodes you are left feeling that all is right with the world of Victorian England. The "bad" guy gets his comeuppance, and the two young stars of the story both enjoy life together. Would love to see the a follow-up series on what happens next to everyone in the story. But, that would be taking license with Trollope's original story, so Mr. Fellowes may not go beyond this very well-done adaptation.

If you like Downton Abbey, I feel certain you'll really enjoy binging this 4-episode Amazon Prime television drama. Mr. Fellowes introduces each episode fireside in a small study, and adds some commentary at the end of each episode. His commentary is worth watching all by itself.

First rate acting, lavish sets, and beautiful English countyside, plus a fairy-tale plot (think Cinderella) and you have an thoroughly enjoyable four-part mini-series. There are likable characters to root for (Frank, Mary, Dr Thorne, Lady Skatchet, Squire Greshem), and unlikable (but not evil) antagonists. I haven't read the Anthony Trollope novel on which it is based, but, as would be expected of Julian Fellowes, the screenplay is articulate and funny, and satisfying.

Well done adaptation. I thought the acting was very good, especially the character of Dr. Thorne, who was played with a subtle touch by Tom Hollander. The story is one fans of Jane Austen would appreciate: love thwarted by social standing and the need for money. Even though you can guess the ending very early on -- the penniless woman ends up with all the money, so that true love (subsidized by 500,000 BPS) prevails -- the journey there is nonetheless enjoyable.

The only detraction for me was the somewhat pompous introduction of each episode by Julian Fellowes. And even that produced some gems: Trollope invented the ubiquitous red post box. Who knew?

I've watched this twice in the span of about four days. Dr Thorne is one of my two favorite Trollope novels (the other favorite is Orley Farm). And Julien Fellowes did a SPLENDID job of winnowing a long complicated novel into four short episodes while still catching all the important highlights. Ian McShane is incredible, of course. Tom Hollander is a perfect Dr. Thorne, quiet and moral and kind and just the kind of person you want in your corner. I hope Fellowes does more of the Trollope novels. Just wonderful.

Julian Fellowes has dumbed down a very smart and funny book, and unnecessarily. He removed the complexity from a number of characters, and in what seems a very patronizing move towards his American audience (of which I am part), makes Miss Dunstable American, and then a deal more attractive than she is supposed to be. How tedious. Must everyone that is wise look beautiful? He doesn't allow Fred to be foolish in the beginning, but instead Fellowes makes him into a vacuous love lorn Ken doll the whole time, and so he becomes quite one dimensional and is not able to grow.  And it is neither credible nor particularly gratifying to see Mr. Moffatt made into a hero for class equality. Fellowes has robbed a delicious story of its complexity and depth, and made it into suggary melodrama.  (Tom Hollander and Ian McShane are both, on the other hand,  wonderful, in the midst of this. And their scenes together make you yearn for more of them, and less Barbie and Ken).

And really, Mr. Fellowes, the Alistair Cook impersonation in the library is embarrassing.

My husband and I both loved Dr. Thorne. We have re-watched it several times now. Julian Fellows' introductions and follow-ups for each episode are fun & informative, the actors do a great job and the scenery is beautiful. It has made us want to look into more stories by Anthony Trollope.

As a Trollope lover, this Doctor Thorne production was a real treat. I have watched it four times, and loved each viewing. To me, the production values and script are true to Trollope's writing and to his time. He wrote about the social, economic religious and political issues and values of Victorian England, but always packaged them in a great love story, and usually with a happy ending. This Jullian Fellowes production meets all those objectives. I have one small but nagging complaint: the portrayal of Sir Louis Scatcherd. It seemed more like a caricature of a spoiled rogue than a portrait of one. The performance becomes distracting, and detracts a little from the whole picture. It might have served the story better to have a slightly more sympathetic (but still spoiled and rogueish) Scatcherd.

Like I said, it's a small complaint.

Good for British drama. I am delighted to have Trollope adaptations again on television. In the 70's, watching the Pallisers is what made me begin to read him and there have only been two further adaptations that I know of since then, both very good. I love Julian Fellowes and it is nice to see him introduce the series as well as writing the adaptations (though he does appear to be more like Alfred Hitchcock than Alistair Cook!). The acting is first rate and I always love the British use of the same actors that appear in other British products (like Tom Hollander). I hope that Fellowes will do some more Trollope for us!

THOUGH A QUITE PREDICTABLE PLOT, YOU CAN ALWAYS COUNT ON JULIAN FELLOWES FOR A LOVELY CHOICE AND PRODUCTION.  I ENJOYED IT AND TOM HOLLANDER IS A WONDERFULLY SENSITIVE ACTOR.

a beautiful rendition of the novel.  Although not absolutely faithful in chronology and substance to the book, the cinema captures the essence of the inner thoughts of the principal characters, which cannot be represented in words.  It is a wonderful complement to the book in that it presents the glory and magnificence of the three principal dwellings as well as the lush countryside and the flavor of the countryside.  But it also stands on its own--if you have not read the book and never plan to, you will enjoy the drama and suspense of this novel as well as an understanding of the important of money, class, and title in nineteenth century England.

Doctor Thorne is like a pair of comfortable jeans. You know what to expect, you think fondly of it, and it makes you happy.  I couldn't help but smile watching this with my wife. Julian Fellowes hits all the right notes with this period peace about love and it's challenges in the rigid class system of England.
The characters you are cheering for are all likeable and very well played and the heels are irksome just as you would expect them to be.
I do feel like calling this a season of a show is a bit of a stretch. The story arc very much feels like a film that they artificially broke up into episodes but it doesn't detract from the show at all. I also enjoyed hearing Fellowes excitedly talk about the story during his debriefs.
If you were hoping for a Downton Abbey replacement you need to look elsewhere. This is much more of an appetizer portion than a 7 course meal like Downton, buts it's still quite enjoyable for what it is.

I know how to MUTE Julian Fellowes with the touch of a button. And thank God for it.  Now if only someone would have the guts to edit his sloppy writing.  As he did in Downton Abby, Julian Fellowes never met a plot twist he didn't enjoy revealing over and over and over again.  Who is Mary's true father?  And how many of the characters need to hear the exact SAME answer before they all finally know what WE knew from the first episode?  His ham-fisted writing is as patronizing as his Alistair Cooke introductions.  But this adaptation is still very watchable because of the great actors he employs.  Could easily have been trimmed to under two hours and have been tighter and better for it.

Great short series with outstanding scenery from the UK. We were not sure how many episodes this series when we began watching it and were somewhat disappointed to see it was only 4. However, unlike some of the movies we have watched recently, this was a wonderful story and series that had a beginning, a great middle and a wonderful end that was suitable to either ending the series or allowing it to continue.  Way too many movies and series do not seem to have a great ending, but this was the exception.

Great acting by great actors and again I cannot emphasize enough the wonderful English countryside and background that can only be fully experienced with one of the newer HD TV's.

We look forward to the possibility of a Season 2 but if it never happens, we are very happy to have had the opportunity to view this short series.

Doctor Thorne has nicely developed personalities with backgrounds (and baggage).  The viewer can easily delve into their relationships as they crisscross each other's lives. Doctor Thorne is a nicely done miniseries focusing on the differences in class in turn-of-the-century England.  The characters are very richly developed and the underlying tensions are well written.  I particularly liked the scene toward the end where the "tables are turned" and reveal all the changes in circumstance.  Tom Hollander did a lovely job with his character, and the other actors perform beautifully in the roles they have.  If you are looking for a 4-hour or so diversion, I highly recommend this quality show.  If you loved Downton Abbey, you'll definitely like this.
This was a true treat to fall upon.  I hope Mr. Fellows can keep us entertained with more of the likes.

I love finding British costume dramas, especially based on classic literature. And a Julian Fellowes adapted British costume drama doesn't disappoint. I have yet to read any Anthony Trollope's novels, but after this series, my interest is piqued to read a few. I didn't know many of the actors in this 4 part miniseries except for the excellent Tom Hollander (Wives and Daughters, 2005 Pride and Prejudice/Mr. Collins) but I enjoyed them all. Sir Julian hosts the beginning and end of every episode, in Alistair Cooke Masterpiece Theatre style, which I enjoyed. It reminded me a lot of Dickens meets Elizabeth Gaskell. Not an overlong series, and concludes with the fourth episode. Sometimes the Season 1 tag on many of these series is misleading. But sometimes I am only in the mood for a series I can binge in just a few hours, and this fit the bill nicely. Well done, Amazon. I hope you will create more of these types of series.

What was it:  4 or 5 episodes and you're done?  Well, it wasn't Downton Abbey, but it was a pretty enjoyable series.  Very nice love story and the villain got his due - as well he should have.  Even Julian Fellowes thought justice was done - and he was the host who introduced each episode!

I must say it takes a lot of searching on Amazon to find a movie that justifies the time spent watching it.  Most of the movie titles make me shudder because they're such obvious junk.  Search search search - and then get out the Kindle and read a book.

So disappointed with Doctor Thorne. Could not even bring myself to finish the fourth episode. Maybe I set my expectations too high being a fan of Downton Abbey, The Forsyte Saga, and more recently Poldark but all British period dramas are not created equal. I love Julian Fellows but what was this? Like some of the other reviewers I agree that it probably wasn't Julian Fellows fault solely that this was bad. As a HUGE Downton Abbey fan and Julian Fellows fan disapointed that there were times when he literally used lines from Downtown Abbey in Doctor Thorne. Discredits Downton in my opinion in this way and when it uses Lady Rosamond's London house for Greshemsbury-others would think that's absurd but that's my opinion. I can't pinpoint exactly why I hated about this but mostly I think the plot is just terribly predictable and uninteresting which sometimes can be overcome when other things are done well but this just wasn't. I can see how Ms. Dunstable could have been an interesting character but she is suppose to be 35 or something and the actress looks the same age as "20 year old" Mary Thorne and isn't even likable plus is doing a fake American accent? Main characters-Frank and Mary aren't even likable and their acting is not captivating which again maybe isn't really their fault just the script, etc. Some of the characters are flat out annoying i.e. Lady Arabella and her daughters. This adaptation is simply goofy at times I'm not sure if it was suppose to be funny but I didn't find it funny at all. The only good thing is probably the beautiful landscapes and houses. Horrible casting across the board which is probably the main reason this failed in my option. For example, the actress who plays Lady Susan in Downton is the Aunt in this and she is a great actress and great in Downton but in this she is just annoying for lack of a better word. Overall it's bad because it lacks emotion, intrigue, characters you can connect to or even care about what happens to them. I could see how this is probably a good book just wondering how it could have been adapted better? Literally watched an American Girl movie when I got bored of this that was more interesting. I wasn't even excited or interested after watching the trailer for this even though I knew Fellows was doing it if that tells you anything.

Although Fellowes, in full  Allistair Cooke mode, makes a point of distinguishing between Dickens and Trollope (the latter being much more reality based, his characters far more nuanced) this rendition looks more like a Dickensian romp.  As a Trollope fan, i was delighted to see him getting the attention; can't wait for a production of "Can You Forgive Her."

Mr. Fellowes follows up Downton Abbey with this beautifully-filmed, dramatic, intriguing and sometimes comical period piece.  He even breaks in periodically (filmed sitting in a plush chair in front of a cozy fireplace) to explain and comment on the story as it progresses.  Some of the English accents are thick and hard to understand, but Mr. Fellowes's commentary helps in tracking plot, sub-plots. and characters.  Highly recommended for folks who like this type of English period piece and you know who you are.

Good actors, quality scenes, costumes, etc. But the story was too shallow and predictable. The only thing that makes it sound interesting and mysterious was the words of the man speaking at the beginnings and ends of each episode. He was talking about a "vicious triangle of love and jealousy", but in reality there wasn't any such intense moments. Only a sudden appearance of a drunken young man, his sudden desire to have Dr. Thorne's daughter and then his conveniently sudden death. You can actually predict his death from the moment he appears since the talks are all about wills, fortunes, and debts.

Another great dramatization of an Anthony Trollope novel - by Julian Fellowes, who also introduces each of the 4 episodes.  Familiar faces from British series pop up in unexpected roles with some wonderful newcomers (to me anyway).  Very bad men repent on their deathbeds - but are satisfyingly dreadful for much of their screen time.  Virtuous behavior is rewarded more genteelly than in Dickens.  Amazingly the character whose sentiments may be most understandable to American viewers is American.  Miss Dunstable is a delight, making me want to read the book again.  Very highly recommended.
Wonderful story great scenery

I attempted to read the book, but I found that Trollope's style is just too much work.  I don't mind having to exercise my brain, but I found myself saying over and over "just tell the story!"  I watched the movie and was much more satisfied.  The story moved along and we weren't forced to follow the inner workings of the storyteller's mind.  I don't often say this, but the movie was better than the book.

This was a well produced and scripted costume drama, enacted by England's seemingly never-ending supply of first rate actors. The story is based on a novel by Trollope, never one of my favorite British novelist, but after viewing this, I may give his works a look-see. Another thing that England has in abundant supply is grandiose country houses, several of which Mr. Fellowes utilizies in this production, i.e., to good effect. Inevitably, one may compare this to Downton Abbey, and find this is lacking, but then, it can be said that of its type, Downton Abbey is incomparable, and anyway, this doesn't trail D.A. by that much.
Since this is a good story which is well acted and well presented, why not give it a try? You may be pleasantly surprised, as I was.

All of ys good people are doing what we can to be happy & generous & helpful to others. All of the prople who only care about themselves & live a life of greed & entitlement,well,let's just say that we all usually get what we deserve in the end. This is a beautiful production! Love the costumes, the countryside and the homes of the nobility, inside and out. The actors are all well cast and play their parts in a wickedly delicious manner. But, because I have just finished reading Trollope's book, I find that Julian Fellowes' version feels like a "Doctor Thorne, Light". Obviously, Fellowes is very good at incorporating the back story into the present without going on and on like Trollope very deliciously does, but so much else is lost, like the hypochondria of Lady Gresham after she has lost so very many babies/children and so her need for the services of Dr. Thorne while banishing his niece from consorting with her only son, and like Trollope's extensive and ongoing critique of  the way the elections of the time were being conducted. Anyway, I enjoyed this visual presentation but wished it had been somewhat more nuanced. Also, I do not understand how this can be labeled "Season 1" since the entire plot of the book has been presented already???

The show is interesting and in places great. Although it is based on a series of novels written by Anthony Trollope, the basic plot has many of the same elements of Downton Abbey-uppercrust society, arranged marriages and secrets. The show cast includes some very great actors such as Tom Hollander and Ian McShane (who only appears briefly in 2 episodes). While it shares many common themes with Downton Abbey, it plods along in many places and the characters are not quite as interesting. Most are very 2-dimensional and could have been updated for the series. That said-it's a good watch.

I was happy to find this new Julian Fellowes creation!  It was done very well - both in dialogue, and in the acting.  The cast was great!  Yes, this may have been a predictable period drama, but I loved it!  Each actor performed his part so well.  I even like the "Masterpiece" touch of Julian Fellowes sitting in a chair by the fire introducing each episode.  What I am wondering, though, is will there really be a "Season Two"??  This story is completed, so will Julian Fellowes adapt another book or part of a book?  It seems strange to label this set of episodes as "Season One" if it is the one and only.  And since I'm sure that no one connected with this film will answer my query, I'll have to be satisfied that I did enjoy this film.  I would (and have) recommend it!

This is an excellent period piece that was very enjoyable to watch.  The production values were high, the acting was very good, the scenery and costumes were appropriate and well-done, the social satire and low-key humor were deftly presented, and the plot and action unfolded and moved to the conclusion in a coherent and well-paced manner.  Unlike the poor quality and mediocre presentation of many modern movies and TV mini-series, this show was great.  I wish more movies and mini-series would strive to match the quality of this one.  I hope Julian Fellowes and his collaborators make many more like this gem.

I found Dr. Thorne to be a sweet, predictable English period drama, but I happen to like sweet predictable period dramas. The story takes place around 1855 in England among the privileged class. The length of this series was not too long, but it was sufficient to tell the story, and it held my interest from beginning to end. The film features some beautiful photography and gives one a glimpse of the life of those living during this period.  I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for a brief escape into 19th century England.

I found it great fun. It was everything it was expected to be, quite so. Visually ravishing, wickedly witty (at times), comfortably predictable and well acted. What more would you wish for? I also very much enjoyed Mr. Fellowes, who with a wink in his eye and a wisp of irony in his tone, intimately dished on Trollope and his characters. It was as if Alfred Hitchcock and Aleister Crowley had had a love child and he was our best friend, sharing with us  the guilty pleasures of romantic, period drama.

Predictable story, pleasurable watching and perfect presentation in the English estate drama format. Trollope's stories show how badly lorded gentry, especially older women, treat those who cannot enhance their societal standing.  Wealthy men are predictably arrogant and unsympathetic but goodness and generosity wins the day.  Excellent casting and acting close to the superb standard of Downton's cast.

I, like many, am missing Downton Abbey.  One of my fellow Downton-ites turned me on to this series.  While set in the 1850's in England, it still gives us a bit of a taste of what many of us loved about Downton: characters we can identify with, some whom we like, and some we do not, masterful and clever use of the English language at the hand of Julian Fellowes, and having a glimpse of the lush scenery and beautiful estates in the English countryside.  This series was less about the upstairs/downstairs relationships as in D.A.  Rather, Doctor Thorne focused on the class differences between the manor-born and those who engage in an occupation to earn a living outside of Service.  Think Dr. Clarkson on DA, and Lady Violet's classic quip, "What is a weekend?"  Since Doctor Thorne is referred to here as "Season 1," we can only hope we see more in the future.

Ah, to be able to reduce the Trollope's novel "Dr. Thorne" into such a predictable plot. The actors, costumes, scenery were enchanting, but much was lost in the translation. I'm a Trollope fan. I began with "The Warden," which probably wouldn't have so well adapted to the screen as "Dr. Thorne." And I continued reading all of The Barchester Novels, as well as other Trollope novels. Yes, Trollope gives depth to his characters in his novels, and this characteristic I found lacking in the film. The doctor himself in the novel is filled with mixed feelings when he finds out that his beloved Mary is likely to be an heiress. But he takes great joy in her good fortune, and not, as much as the film suggests, in giving Tom's mother her comeuppance. I too could have done without Julian Fellows giving the audience "spoilers" before an episode played. But still I enjoyed watching the film, but I do think it could have been expanded to show more of Trollope's characterization.

Doesn't have QUITE the quality - in acting, writing, or production value - of Fellowe's hit "Downton Abbey". But then again, it's an adaptation of a charming and sweet, but fairly simple and predictable, Victorian novel, and is only about 3 hours long in total (all four "episodes"). For what it is, it is as charming as its source material, and the characters, while underdeveloped in many respects, are yet likable and well-portrayed. The actor who plays Frank is perhaps the weakest, but then again he has little to do but be the foil to Sir Louis and the "ladies" of the households who oppose the match with Mary. Tom Hollander/Doctor Thorne is, as might be expected, the best actor and character, in such a different role from any I've seen him in before (Going from seeing him in "The Night Manager" series to this was... a little jarring.).

Parents, nothing to worry about here, despite the TV-14 rating for "violence". The opening scene is a brief moment of violence, but there is nothing else in the rest of the series, and nothing inappropriately sexual at all. This, on the heels of the similarly-safe-for-watching "Love & Friendship", is quite a relief to find in this modern age of dark, brutal, oversexualized drama.

Overall, it is about the same level of quality and type of production as that other Amazon-produced recent film, "Love & Friendship". Likewise, there are similarities with Fellowe's other show, "Downton Abbey". It's really a bit of both, and if Doctor Thorne is really one of Fellowe's favorite books, one can see clearly the influence it had on him in creating "Downton" and his other works.

I was at first put off by, but then looking forward to, the introduction and closing of each episode by Mr Fellowes himself, ala Alfred Hitchcock. Julian Fellowes' genius returns!  I love his treatment of Trollope's classic work, Dr. Thorne.  I was easily drawn into the stories of each of the very believable characters. Similar to DA, the storyline is well-paced and satisfying.  Different from DA, however, is it's lighter mood, and most pleasant look.  The scenes are filmed mostly in natural sunlight, during the day, lending a happy tone to the characters while showing off the beautiful English countryside and architecture. (Which, let's face it, the pastoral setting is a large part of the allure and enjoyment of this genre.)  On a technical note, I love how Fellowes' casting continues in the style of DA by including both new and familiar English actors in his productions.  After seeing the actor, Tom Hollander play bafoonish characters in past BBC dramas, it is so satisfying to see him shine in the lead role as the affably honorable Dr Thorne.  It's nice to see a great actor break out of his type-casting and surprise us with the genuine sincerity, humility and kindness he lends to the role. (Very savvy, Mr. Fellowes!)  And just how endearing is it, to be personally and intimately welcomed into each episode by Julian himself, casually sharing his remarks while seated comfortably in front of a warm fireplace?  Imagine my disappointment, however-- I was all set for the other volumes in Trollope's works!  I hope they turn up soon!!

As a piece of storytelling on its own Doctor Thorne succeeds in every fashion. They have wonderful characters a wonderful tale and beautiful costumes and scenery. I really enjoyed the commentary from Julian Fellowes at the start and end of each episode. You really get to know a little back story about the author Anthony Trollope and the wonderful passion he has for English literature. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys the wonderful world of English literature during the Victorian era.

Julian Fellowes has a well-earned reputation for bringing historical period dramas to the TV screen. The most successful and popular is probably Downton Abbey. Dr. Thorne is a TV adaption of a novel written by the great Victorian writer Anthony Trollope, which is part of Trollopes collection known as the Chronicles of Barsetshire. I must admit that I have not read the original novels of Trollope, but I have seen a number of TV adaptions of his works (notably The Barchester Chronicles, He Knew He Was Right, The Way We Live Now and The Pallisers) and enjoyed them tremendously. I would not say that Julian Fellowes Dr. Thorne is "up there with the best of them", although it is worth watching. The acting, sets, countryside, period dress and stately homes, as we would expect, are very well done. But the plot is unfortunately a familiar one in many Victorian dramas. Beautiful heroine is poor and (how shocking!) illegitimate; she is therefore unacceptable in good society. She falls in love with the handsome and eligible son of aristocratic parents, who have no money but are well regarded in high society. Son reciprocates her love but is under terrible pressure to marry a rich American woman that he does not love in order to save the upper-class familys finances (yes, its the usual rich American a.k.a. Downton Abbey). I don't know whether to blame Julian Fellowes or Anthony Trollope, but Season 1 does become too predictable, despite the clever twist at the end, which however is also predictable in its own way, but I won't say more on that, because I don't want to be a spoiler! There is a modest attempt at variation by bringing in a hopeless young alcoholic who is super-rich but hated by all (including himself). Incidentally, there are four episodes but it is not clear if there might be a second Season. I would have given the series four stars on the basis of presentation but I deducted a star for the too-familiar plot. I also felt that the actor playing the son Frank (Harry Richardson) is not cast at all well. He has the looks but no real strength of character.
The outcome was predictable but nevertheless enjoyable.  Some gaps missing as to how certain people came by their fortunes but I suppose we'll have to read the original.

"Doctor Thorne" set in 1850's England is a very well adapted, produced and entertaining drama. Julian Fellowes shows his masterful art keeping a sensitive and relevant approach to the issues at hand.
The incredible consciousness and sensitivity of Dr Thorne dealing with the many issues coming at him from different avenues show him a master at finely and safely navigating the social vagaries of the period and a very "conscious" human being in a world fraught with egocentric manipulating personalities interested only in their own agendas. He is the most genuinely aware person in this drama and it elevates him steps above others in being a mature, realized individual.
Fellowes' ability to adapt and deliver this novel to the screen in such a subtly profound manner (without today's addiction to high adrenaline extroverted action) is a marvel in itself. This is a quietly powerful drama that transcends today's loud action movies and brings to the screen a more gentle and conscious approach needed in the journey to grow as a human being,  in each individual and as a people in any society.

Not the best of Trollope's work to begin with.  Add to it the ham-size fist of Julian Fellowes, and you get an over-ripe, over-acted (save for the good doctor himself, played by the ever-excellent Tom Hollander) hodgepodge of every Masterpiece Theater trope going all the way back to "The First Churchills."  Everything about it feels like a self-conscious parody, with the perpetually snarling and fiendishly-drunk young gun of the manor, Lord Scatcherd, played like nothing so much as Christopher Guest's Nigel Tufnel in period dress--turned up to eleven.

I thought the story went too fast, only about 3 hours in total viewing time, more like an epic movie length rather than the more thorough leisurely pace I expect from a miniseries. There was insufficient time for developing the plot and characters or for the viewer to get involved with them. I've read many Trollope novels, including Dr. Thorne twice, and was interested in watching the whole series, but my wife stopped watching after one episode.  I don't blame her.
Unlike Fellowes, I think Dr. Thorne is one of the weaker of the Chronicles of Barsetshire sextet. I prefer Trollope's storylines involving the workings of the clergy, legal and inheritance procedures, and political maneuvers to the standard romantic story more in the Austen tradition that is the majority of Dr. Thorne. The book was strongest when dealing with the election and electioneering which were shortened in the miniseries and with the Scatcherd inheritance issues. I thought the 1980 Barchester Chronicles miniseries to be superior, but both pale before the thorough 26 part Pallisers miniseries from 1974.
I also found the bright light green grass, Greshambury's hue and overall color and brightness distracting and unreal.

Good acting, nice scenes of English manor houses, but Fellowes' Dr. Thorne is not Trollope's Dr. Thorne.  He chops up the plot, rearrange the parts, perhaps to fit a filming schedule, and adds things that simply aren't in the novel.  For example, Sir Louis dies from a punctured lung in Fellowes' version whereas he dies from acute alcoholism in the novel.  And much that makes the novel more enjoyable -- the political machinations, the rivalry with Dr. Fillgrave, the horse whipping of Mr. Moffet, etc. are not there.

The top review from Design Think is really spot on.  This really is not like Downton Abbey.  There are indiscretions and improprieties but they are handled more in the Jane Austen style - known about or mentioned but not played out for us all to watch.  This is also similar in style to Dickens in that there are twists and turns in the plot.  It is unlike Dickens in that those twists and turns are somewhat predictable. This is also less gruesome than most Dickens movies.  If you like Jane Austen, Dickens, Elizabeth Gaskell, and happy endings you will enjoy Doctor Thorne.

I particularly liked watching Dr. Thorne as he struggled with decisions about what information to reveal to whom and when.  Although Mary and Frank are the spotlight, Dr. Thorne really carries the story line between all the different groups and does so masterfully!!!

Thank you Amazon for producing such a quality program.  I especially loved that there were not bosoms busting out of every dress.  I did not care for the summaries at the beginning and end of each episode, but I do hope you will continue to make more programs like this one.

I expected to like "Dr. Thorne" because I enjoyed the first few seasons of "Downton Abby".  Instead, I was sorely disappointed.  Sadly, "Dr. Thorne" was slow moving and boring.  There was nothing unique about the plot of Episode One to hold my interest, and there were so many characters that I couldn't keep track of who was who.  I don't plan on watching the other two episodes.

This is exactly the type of well scripted adaptation of a classic story that should be much more common on TV and in movies. Beautifully done, great locations, good actors, and my wife and I do like the slightly quirky conversational moments with Julian Fellowes in his chair by the fire. Please do more collaborations with Julian, and produce more period drama. There is too much smut and violence, and far too much reliance on computer generated "action" sequences. What I look for is quality production values, shot at interesting locations, and well scripted human conversations. Show me real humans doing human things, and treat me as the viewer like I have a brain. This is an excellent series. Thank you Julian Fellowes and Amazon for making a great series.

If you love period English drama like we do, you will like this production of Doctor Thorne. It is a classic story of a titled gentleman who's father has squandered the family wealth and he knows it is his responsibility to marry an heiress in order to save their home and lands. Unfortunately, he is in love with Dr. Thorne's niece who is penniless and of questionable birth. Of course, there are twists and turns along the way to the happy ending. Secrets are revealed which change everything! A great story.

I loved this short series! I wish it was more than 4 epidsodes.. Never got to watch Downtown Abbey but now I want to because Julian Fellowes is simply brilliant and I can't get enough of his works as director!

Very disappointing. The actors did not speak or have the demeanor, protocol or deference appropriate to the context of the mid 1800's. They were all acting "too modern" for the time period. Hair styles, particularly the women, and especially Dr. Thorne's niece, and costumes and make up were also out of context. Although the scene was England, not one actor had a British (or even slightly England-ish) accent. It was very off-putting. Everything seemed to be out of sync with the mid 1800's.
