The best re-production of a great story I've seen since Kiera Knightley & Matthew MacFayden in Pride & Prejudice in 2005! Thoroughly enjoyed how the plot was consistent with the books; actors gelled very well which made the story that much more visually appealing and intellectually captivating! I enjoyed it each time I watched it (I'm up to 5 now!)! Julian's intro and 'extro' were right on point and did not in anyway take away from the screening of this story. His narration actually helped build the anticipation, gave great background on the author, and provided a wonderfully light telling of how this 're-production' came to be.

Very good production values in this period piece.  Beautiful costumes and grand, gorgeous houses both inside and out.  Perhaps the Trollope story needs more tweaking for this time, being a bit predictable. Some very good individual performances, but overall the cast was much too wooden.  I have read that Julian Fellowes was inspired by many of the actors in Downton Abbey and the resulting character development gave life to the story line and sparked individual performances. Perhaps it is the lack of this longer familiarity tempered by the effects of an in demand schedule, or simply the result of adapting a piece from another time that doesn't completely deliver the Julian Fellowes touch we are so spoiled for.  It is pleasant and lovely viewing sans the addictive quality of Downton Abbey.
Just as one would imagine a Julian Fellowes production to be this follows Trollope's novel to a T. Those of us who so enjoyed Downton Abbey can take great pleasure in viewing Doctor Thorne as well.

There was always that feel-good under current in Downton.  Yes, sisters were snarky at times, bad things happened, but there was always that part that was wonderful, caring, positive and just made you smile. Entertaining adaptation of Anthony Trollope's 550+ page 1858 novel. While the novel is a bit too verbose and slow moving for modern taste, the movie crisply tell the love story of Mary, Dr. Thorne's niece, and Frank Gresham, the son of the local squire who has foolishly sold off most of the family's land and mortgaged the remainder to the hilt. Frank's mother, Lady Arabella, is determined that he marry wealth to save the family from financial ruin. The love story is handsomely mounted with mid-1800s clothing and the splendid Greshambury Park and the picaresque Village. Plenty of romantic intrigue, deeply buried family secrets, and aristocratic snobbery.
Very good miniseries.

Delightful British drama!  While not quite rising to the quality of "Downton Abbey," this is nonetheless entertaining and compelling television drama.  With Allister Cooke-like imitation, Julian does a nice job of setting up the stories and teasing them at the conclusion.  The series is well-acted with delicious characters and a money-vs-love theme that has a satisfying ending where the villain gets his due and the hero & heroine do too.  This is a nice installment for all who are still grieving the loss of "Downton"!

This adaptation gave me the impression that Trollope was the English equivalent of a romance novelist - the bad ones (Harlequin). I am sure that impression is completely wrong. The series just never delivered what was promised. The characterizations were shallow and dull, the plot was utterly predictable, and some of the portrayals were way too over-the-top (McShane) or kind flat/strange (almost everyone else). The token American's accent was cringeworthy. The JF interviews were downright annoying, mostly absent of historical context or any useful information, opened with strange camera angles (no, I didn't see any nose hair even though that obviously was the intent), and promised so much that was never delivered. The costumes, sets, and scenery were absolutely lovely although the excessive fake hair and hat flowers were kind of distracting. Pass on this one, there are better things to do with four hours!

While we 21st Century Americans idealize Victorian England, we can forget how circumscribed and difficult life at that time could be.  Of course, the poor of that period, without any "social safety net," suffered endlessly from poverty, illness, alarmingly high infant and maternal mortality rates, constant crime, and cities awash in filth.  But even the growing middle-class and the nobility, despite their lovely homes and their lovely clothes, found their lives bounded by the strict and intrusive rules of society - including how one would be expected to use one's time, as well as whom one might love and whom one might marry (not always the same person).  Julian Fellowes has a gift for bringing to our attention the real struggles of those who - through the misty lens of time - might otherwise seem to us to have drifted through lives consisting of only charm and elegance.  I also appreciate Baron Fellows' re-introduction of Anthony Trollope to modern readers and viewers.

My husband and I love period pieces, and this is definitely one that ranks up at the top 10 list in our books.  Yes, as with many period pieces, there are some slow spots.  However, those are still important to get those points in for the storyline to flow properly.  We loved that you saw both the good and bad of so many of the characters.  No one was the "perfect" good guy, and no one was all evil either.  It gave depth to every character by having this dynamic. In addition, although it is rated 14 and above (which made us nervous that there might be some inappropriate scenes in it), the storyline was so well crafted to let you know about indiscretions in plenty of detail to understand what was happening without having to actually show any sex scenes at all.  That shows great writing skills.  My husband and I would feel very comfortable watching this with our teenage children.  We hope that Amazon creates more period series just like this one.  We also would love to see a sequel to this series that had these same characters in their continued story, even though the next book in the series apparently focuses more on different characters.  Be prepared for a few slow spots, but a great story with a great ending. Well done, Amazon.

Well, this is no Downton Abbey, but you have to remember that the story is Anthony Trollope's with Julian Fellowes dramatizing the novel for viewing. Any criticisms about the plot and even some of the dialogue would rest with the original. I thought the first episode was a little slow and predictable, but the sharp characterizations, the not-always-expected twists and turns of the plot, and Fellowes' wry sense of humor drew me back to each succeeding episode. I guess you could watch all of the episodes at once, but I chose to make each episode a weekend treat. I added a star for the most enjoyable part of the show, Fellowes' slyly amusing commentaries that introduce and conclude each episode. Julian Fellowes has a perceptive respect for an old-fashioned story brought to life by a talented cast.
Wonderful script, excellent acting, great story-line.  Matches his work in Downton Abbey.

Fans of Victorian era tales will doubtlessly enjoy this short series.  Fellowes has done a skillful adaptation of Anthony Trollope's novel with the filming involving beautiful estate locations such as Downton Abbey viewers came to appreciate.  Cast members were unfamiliar to me, but all turned in quite credible performances.  All told, this series was engaging enough that if Fellowes chooses to do more with this or similar material, it should be a treat to watch.  As a bonus, the short narratives given at the beginning of the episodes were quite helpful in keeping the plot details and intricacies of the character relationships straight.

It is definitely nothing like Downton Abbey, but it was incredibly charming and tasteful.  It is so hard to find a good romance made in this decade without the distraction or encouragement of seduction, or blatantly bearing every detail of sexual intimacy.  However, I know deep intimacy between man and woman does not solely lie in a physical connection. Some of the best and truest connections of life first are built in friendship, humility and honoring one another.  Then, and only then have I been able to give myself over to the deepest love I have ever experienced and it was delightful to see these values recognized, all without making it too heavy. Very enjoyable and I expect by the end you will find yourself admiring Miss Thorne and her many virtues. (I think I've found a new author to look into!)

Jullian Fellowes loves the dramatic and comedic tensions the infamous British class system brings to any story of romance, ambition, greed, etc. and he can't help but make those stories interesting, whether he's writing original material or adapting material, as in the case of Doctor Thorne.  What makes this offering less appealing to me than the spectacularly successful "Downton Abbey" is the casting. Along with the alway terrific and appealing Tom Hollander and the always grizzled and commanding Ian McShane you get a number of actors who seem like people who auditioned for Downton and were passed over as "not quite right."  Stephanie Martini tries too hard to play the headstrong and forthright Mary Thorne, with a coquettish laughter that borders on the maniacal when flirting with Frank Gresham, the boy she's known since childhood.  The two ostensibly love each other but he's above her station and while he refuses to accept this, she is too level-headed to deny the realities of the world they live in. Unfortunately, she also appears to be too old for him (almost a big sister to his boyish romantic), and consequently their chemistry is less than it needs to be.  And maybe I'm just watching with my own prejudice, but Tom Hollander as her guardian doesn't seem to be all that knocked out by the actress playing the niece he supposedly adores.  Then there are the almost Maggie Smiths and almost Hugh Bonnevilles and the whole thing quickly feels like a road company trying to bring the game of the A team but not quite having the chops or the star power. If you're addicted to British drawing room dramedy, it's okay, but I'll be browsing Netflix and Amazon for something else.

The STORY! The beautiful sets, the funny characters (as caricatures!) And the interesting "once upon a time" feel to this  perfect and complete 4 part binge-watching delight is for young and old. Remember being read a story when you were a kid? Well, curl up and enjoy some old fashioned story-telling and narration given before and after each part of the story by the inspired creator, Julian Fellowes.  Get lost  in the humorous and complimentary cinematography and the well developed characters as they struggle with love, greed, alcoholism, jealousy, and a plethora of other human emotions all familiar to each one of us today (if we're honest!) An unbridled, unexpected happy ending is your reward, making you believe once more that goodness and love always prevail in the very end.

(THANK YOU AMAZON FOR THIS PERFECT OFFERING. THIS IS THE KIND OF VIEWING SO MANY OF US ARE LOOKING FOR! PLEASE BRING BACK ANOTHER "TROLLUP" STORY AS CREATED BY JULIAN FELLOWES. HE TRULY UNDERSTANDS  WHAT SO MANY OF US WANT!!!)

Really enjoyed the characters and the story line..It's all about class and how people treated those "beneath" them, how the upper class saw themselves as so much better than those below them, but the great thing is, some of the uppity upper class really had to swallow their pride, which was hillarious..Really captures how people manipulated others to get what they wanted.. And also, the show demonstrats how a person's word was good enough, there wasn't the need for all kinds of legal documents/lawyers to prove something, like how it is today.  Please continue with more seasons!

Although the film did not dive deeply into emotion and many characters seemed rather one-dimensional- things I usually do NOT like in period dramas or television- it still worked!  While this would not have survived a longer mini-series, for a short series it was intriguing, fun, and satisfying.  Beware that the first episode, like many period dramas, seem to set up the story; it is well worth continuing on to the conclusion.

3 stars because of its predictable plot and predictable characters. The Oh So perfect (against odds) heroine seems rather flat after seeing this theme so many times in more fleshed out dramas..the righteous suitor with his meddling mother and aunt etc etc. Somehow I really didn't care whether they ended up together or not. But it is passable escapist fare with luscious settings and the exemplary fashions of the day. Don't get me wrong. I am a major fan of period pieces. This one seemed like a quick fix and just too formulaic for me to add more stars.

Another good run from Julian Fellowes! I'm glad he brought to light an author that I'd never heard of. For those of us who loved Downton Abbey, this was a good, albeit brief (only 4 episodes), return to that era and its societal rules. They hired some very good actors, too. It was great to see Tom Hollander in a very different role from those he played in "Pride and Prejudice," "John Adams," and in Pirates of the Caribbean" movies. I also thought that Stefanie Martini, a relative newcomer, was great. Lastly, it was great to have Mr. Fellowes himself doing the Alistair Cook thing (Masterpiece Theater), explaining context and such for the audience from his comfy leather chair.

I have never read Trollope's novel, so I can't compare the novel with this film adaptation, but I have to say that I found this series to be quite delightful to watch. I love period dramas, especially Jane Austen. I was concerned that this might be too much like a soap opera (like Season 1 of Downton Abbey--and I ended up really enjoying the full run of Downton Abbey), but it was just the right blend of drama, humor, and witty dialogue. The main characters of Dr. Thorne, Mary, and Frank are very likeable, and the supporting characters are a delightful mix. I watched this with my 16yo daughter, but I felt that some scenes might be too intense for my 12yo daughter or had content that I didn't want to have to explain....not very many, but a few.

The story is not especially complex or thought provoking and treads a fine line between drama and light satire.  But, it was refreshing that there were no plot turns added just for the sake of shock or cheap manipulation of the viewer. Being accustomed to "modern" story telling,  I kept dreading that something awful would happen to one of the protagonists in order to create drama (Downton Abbey,  Game of Thrones...).

The show concludes with no surprises for the viewer,  yet it leaves one missing the characters when it's all over.

It has everything a Victorian drama should: romance, scandal, intrigue.

Tom Hollander is excellent as the moral compass, wanting to do right by his niece, Mary, without ruffling too many feathers, except Lady Gresham's. She and her sister-in-law, Countess de Courcy, are typical aristocratic snobs, but are fun to watch. You know pretty early into the series that their machinations will backfire, it is a Victorian romance after all.

I gave the series four stars because I wanted to see Ian McShane more. I haven't read the Barsetshire novels yet (but I want to now!), so I'm not sure if more scenes with Sir Roger were possible, but it would have been nice to see more of the dynamic between Sir Roger and his son to get a better understanding of Louis's awful behavior.

Everything is wrapped up nice and neatly and happily ever after, so it's a nice easygoing miniseries to watch when you're in the mood for something light and uplifting, but not really that well-suited if you're looking for something with depth or insight. The intro and outro with Julian Fellowes is a bit unnecessary though, I actually wish he'd just let the story unfold without his interjections. And I was very disappointed there wasn't more of Alison Brie, considering how prominently her name was billed. Overall, I enjoyed it, but more Alison Brie please!!

I very much enjoyed this period series. The costumes, the buildings, the land -- all were beautifully portrayed. Trollope's satire was clearly present. However, I am not in favor of having death-bed conversions to show us that even bad people have good points. No matter that I do believe the statement, the author's use is contrived. That flaw is not the fault of Fellowes. I think he did an outstanding job with the production. I enjoy Fielding and Austin for many of the same reasons: wonderful satire and characters who are not just cardboard. I highly recommend viewing this series.

Not great...but not bad.  It's written by Julian Fellowes but it's no Downton Abbey by any means.  The characters aren't as meaty and the story is not as strong.  But, if you love period pieces, it's worth watching.  The story itself involves two lovers, he upper class, she middle class, who fall in love but aren't allowed to marry for various reasons, the primary being money.  The female lead reminded me of a Jane Austin heroin.  She's mature, clever, well spoken, and sarcastically witty at times.  It's good fun all around but, again, if you're expecting something as meaty as Downton Abbey you may be disappointed.  However, if you take it for what it is, a light, sweet, romantic period drama, you'll enjoy the ride.

I am a huge Downton Abbey fan and I love Julian fellows, so Dr. Thorne piqued my interest.  I was a little disappointed but I thought it was good.  To me, the characters lacked the depth of those of Downton Abbey.  But it is only season one after all and who could not like the romance and intrigue of a good 19th English novel!

Anthony Trollope, like so many  Victorian novelists, wrote books that may be a little difficult to tackle for some of today's readers who are used to sound bites and tweets.  However,  like Dickens, Trollope's novels are rich in memorable characters, astute psychological insight, and social  commentary.  Trollope's work transfers  beautifully to film and television, (think Barchester Towers and The Pallisers) as long as the adaptations take their time and don't' try to condense the stories and characterizations too much.

Julian Fellowes' adaptation of Dr. Thorne is absolutely spot on to Trollope's intention in writing a gripping, sometimes amusing commentary on the power of money vs. the power of love.  This series offers everything one would hope for:  brilliant acting from British actors that have practically become beloved friends to their American viewers; splendid scenery, gorgeous settings, lush costumes,  all a perfect antidote to the same old same old of most standard TV offerings in the U.S.A.

The cherry on the sundae is the delightful appearance at the beginning of each episode by Julian Fellowes himself, channeling Alistair Cooke, complete with easy chair and fireplace, and doing it splendidly!  Anglophiles, sit up and pay attention!  Dr. Thorne is the answer to your prayers!

It's such a pleasant alternative to so much of the formulaic, unimaginative, dark crap that celebrates people behaving badly on TV now.

As a great Trollope fan, I loved Julian's version. He left out the great clash between Mary and Lady Arabella, and he chose a beautiful actress to play the plain but witty Miss Dunstable, but why complain when it was so much fun. My wife and I watched all 4 episodes in one night and drank far too much wine. So I raise a glass to Julian Fellowes and all the pleasure he has brought us viewers.

I liked this mini series. I have never read the book so I don't know how well it followed the original story.  It was a little slow at times but a lot of period pieces can take some time to pull all the story lines together.  Such was the case here.  The only reason I gave it 3 stars was because of all the hoopla given this Julian Fellows T.V. production after his absolutely stunning Downton Abbey. That was such a hard act to follow. And this wasn't even in the same league. It's like comparing beer to champagne.  If this show hadn't been so over promoted as another Julian Fellows, Downton Abbey like show I would have probably given it 4 stars.

My main unhappinesses were the headlong pace and several shortcuts required to pack that wonderful book into four short episodes. The second season implied by mentioning a first ought to have gone far to improve on that, given how well was done with too little time. Encouraged by Amazon to compare this offering with similar products, I will mention time squandered on less substance by "Downtown Abbey" in recent years. The quality of the production struck me as superb and the casting often inspired -- Scatcherd, Lady Arabella, and Miss Dunstable in particular. Alas, I could never altogether quiet the ghost of Tom Hollander's perfectly splendid Mr. Collins from some years back, but that is surely more my fault than his.
Nicely done!  Follows the conventions and model of the original book.  It was not modified to inject modern political correctness.  It is a faithful representation of the book in all ways.

Doctor Thorne was no where near the quality of Downtown Abbey.  It felt forced and overly dramatized.  Clever idea, and if more time were taken to develop character and nuance, could have been entertaining.  The use of Julian to introduce and then cap off each episode indicated to me that they knew it was a flawed execution of a clever idea, and were trying to add another dimension to package it in.  I think the character of Doctor Thorne could be a fun and rich serialized figure, given the right production.

I loved Downton Abby. I read Jane Austen and have seen almost every movie production made of he novels, even the unconventional ones: (see Clueless).
First I'll say what was good: the sets were amazing, the costumes were detailed and beautiful, Ian McShane delightfully chewed up the scenery with his performance!
Now the bad: the other characters were dull, either over the top bad or good, the story was bland and predictable, the acting was so so to incredibly bad (the vicor's beautiful sister sounded as if she was reading the script, badly).
Whoever thought giving Julian Fellowes fireside chats before and after each episode should be shot. I can tell he thinks he's Alistair Cooke, but he reminded me of the Monty Python skit about upper class twits. He disrupted the flow of the story so much!
The character of the American heiress was overdrawn; I imagined her with a John Wayne accent and added 'little lady's or 'pilgram' to the end of her lines, and it improved her immeasurably!
It was a disappointment.

Where do I begin? It could have been so much better.

The soundtrack overwhelms each scene, gratingly informing the viewer when to be happy, suspicious, or sad. Except for a few actors (Hollander being one; he's marvelous and understated), the cast needs lessons on how to NOT chew scenery (that's another way to say overacting). For this,  blame the director. The script was written with stereotypical characters, that at any moment you expect the liquor-soaked villian to growl "You must pay the rent!" and the innocent ingenue to sob in response, "But I can't pay the rent!" This show is overdone drivel.

The absolutely most annoying aspect of this miniseries is having to endure Julian Fellowes' attempts at channeling Alistair Cooke, the British journalist who eloquently introduced each episode of PBS Masterpiece from 1971 to 1992. Cooke, seated in gentleman's library chair, possessed an eloquence and mastery of voice that engaged, unlike Fellowes, who also sits in a wingback chair, has a voice that repels.

Why take decent actors and a Trollope novel and weight them down with such a leaden script and awkward direction and editing?  Hardly any of Trollope's satire or the actors' charisma shines through.  I got through the whole thing, but part of that was in hopes that it would get better, which it didn't.  The simple romance that's left is nothing you haven't seen a dozen times, and better done.

Trollope is actually brilliant.  I didn't think his membership of the British literary pantheon was in any doubt. Watch the recent The Way We Live Now adaptation with David Suchet, Shirley Henderson, and Matthew Macfadyen instead of this.

I loved Downton Abbey. I have an Acorn add-on subscription. I love a lot of British TV. But I hated this. It was much too girly-girl for me, and I'm a woman. Very stilted, very mannered, very feminine. And very boring (also, annoying).  I didn't like the intros by Julian Fellowes, they seemed superfluous. I don't think this is anywhere near his best work. It lacks energy.

Anthony Trollope wrote this story and Julian Fellowes adapted it for television. The book is better in my
opinion. For those who do not take the time to read anymore this is an ok adaptation with some changes.

She did a very good job and gave me a chance to see her do something quite different from the usual.
The scenery and costumes were great and the acting was good. I just really did not get into it as I did
the book.

Having enjoyed every delicious moment of DOWNTON ABBEY, I was, foolishly, hoping I could jump back into another Julian Fellowes' masterpiece and thought this might be it. Sadly, this did not immediately engage me. Not remotely. I simply did not care about a single person in it. In truth, I did not get past the first 10 minutes and I will, if I return to it, modify this review accordingly. But in DA, I was immediately drawn into the story and I cared almost instantly about all involved. Mr. Fellowes is obviously brilliant and one does not argue with such brilliance and I should give this series the time it deserves. But in all honesty, it just didn't grab me the way DA did, and I realize, now, that nothing ever will. DA was, at least in my experience, singularly unique. Doctor Thorne... well, the jury is still out.
I enjoyed the series and would like to see a second season.

Julian Fellows continues his Downton Abbey ways with a well produced Hallmark Channel production. This is a short series, just four episodes, so it feels a bit dashed off. Though Dr. Thorne, his daughter, the man she loves and his mother are fully realized and quite wonderfully performed, the secondary characters are thin cartoons. It is a story of true love pitted against requirements class, family and honor. A good time if you're looking for something light and fluffy to watch.

I am always drawn to Fellowes work. I first saw him as the quirky neighbor in Monarch of the Glen, which is a must watch. Then read several of this works of fiction, finally to be enraptured by all that was Downton. He is a brilliant producer, writer, and actor. In the style of Alfred Hitchcock, Fellowes introduces each episode and does a brief wrap up at the end. These make the viewer feel more involved. Thanks for another delightful venue.

I am enjoying Doctor Thorne a great deal, and it shows an historically accurate depiction of the higher levels of British society.  That said, such a depiction includes a great deal of over drinking and also the diminution of the role of women.  While this may be historically accurate, I am watching for entertainment and I feel like there is just too much depressing "stuff" going on.  There are fine, upstanding characters to be sure, and I will watch the entire series, but the disgusting characters are given a bit too much importance.

Very disappointed.  I loved absolutely everything about Downton Abbey, but sadly, this production didn't come close to it.  I felt the acting was wooden.  I felt that most of those who were cast into the roles of these characters did not come across well- for it seemed that the actors were out of touch with the characters they were playing- i.e., with those who were living in the Victorian age.  I wanted so much to be drawn into the story, but as I watched, I felt that I was simply watching actors on a stage who were  "play acting" and therefore not believable.  I needed to feel some measure of sympathy and/or empathy for the character-  to finding myself truly caring about his/her personal life and situation.  These, I believe are absolute essentials to any successful theater experience (whether it be a stage production, viewed at the cinema, or watched on television!)
Perhaps others will disagree with my assessment... but since you asked my opinion... well, there it is.

Nice and simple.

In my humble opinion, this is a well done Anthony Trollope adaptation.  It was entertaining, beautifully filmed and the acting was superb.  1 star is subtracted however, because Julian Fellowes needs to get over himself!  Ian McShane or Tom Hollander would have better served as presenter.  (They are such gifted actors and really hot at the moment: Ian McShane in GOT, Tom Hollander in The Night Manager... amazing!)  After the first episode, I simply fast forwarded through the introduction and debrief.  Honestly, does Julian Fellowes assume American audiences need to be spoon-fed information about classic literature or 19th-c. societal structures?  Those who appreciate British drama don't need the lecture.  I hope this format is not a new trend from Masterpiece.  Having grown up with the series, I never felt that the former introductory commentaries were debased, or as self-involved.  Regardless, give Doctor Thorne a try, the acting is well worth it!

Critics who compare this series to Downton Abbey and suggest that this series "is no Downton Abby" don't get it. This is an adaptation of a Trollop novel, and a very good one. If you love Victorian novels of manners, this is a good one. It is not as intricate as Austen or Dickens novels, but it is tinged with subtle humor. The acting is very good, and the mise en scene is excellent! Fellows did a very good job of bringing Dr. Thorne to life.

Julian Fellowes, one-time actor, is now best known as the creator of Downton Abbeythe sweeping saga of the noble family Crawley that opens in Edwardian England. Downton fans saddened by the series conclusion in March, can now stream Fellowes newest delight, Doctor Thorne, which debuted on Amazon Prime on May 20.

While Downton was an entirely original work that ran six seasons, Doctor Thorne is a four-part mini adapted from the third novel of Anthony Trollopes beloved Barsetshire Chronicles. Published in 1858, Thorne tells the lovelorn tale of Doctor Thomas Thorne and his orphaned niece Mary.

Virtuoso Tom Hollander (The Night Manager, Rev) is subtle and brilliant as Thorne, while newcomer Stefanie Martini (Endeavor) is at once coy and mocking as Mary. Thorne also stars the excellent Richard McCabe (Wallander) as the bumbling Squire Gresham, Alison Brie (Mad Men) as the daring American heiress Miss Dunstable, Ian McShane (Deadwood) as the drunken rascal Sir Roger Scatcherd, and Phoebe Nicholls (Downton Abbey) as the commanding Countess de Courcy. Personally, I find the acting nimbler and the dialogue tighter in Thorne than in Downton. Perhaps thats thanks to Trollopes text and the shorter running timefour episodes rather than fifty-two.

Still, Downton fans will not be disappointed by Doctor Thorne.
Enjoyed the program very much. Would recommend it to anyone interested in period British drama.

My teen daughter and friends strong-armed me into watching this short series, which until then I hadn't heard of (book or video). Beautiful scenery, costumes, and production value---and Julian Fellowes' approval! Turned out to be an enjoyable few hours, with plots nicely tied up in happy endings.

I found it very predictable in terms of plot and characterization: the teen girls here enjoyed it even more for those same reasons though! And they were delighted to see it all wrapped up neatly in just four episodes. Diehard Downton Abbey fans might find this series too simple and straightforward (and with less engaging characters), but lots of others will really enjoy this light and pretty period piece.

I was unfamiliar with the works of Anthony Trollope when I began watching this production.  I was hooked in the first episode by the costumes and the beautifully shot exteriors which were familiar staples of Downton Abbey.  To be honest, I found the plot to be a bit shop-worn and trite.  The theme of star-crossed lovers kept apart by accident of birth and fortune has been done often and done better.  This is not a criticism of Julian Fellowes's screenplay, however, as it is appears to have been true to Trollope's original novel with one or two minor exceptions.  The main problem is that the plot is rather thin for four one-hour long episodes.  With regards to the cast, I give high marks to Ian McShane.  His performance might have been a bit campy but he appears to have embraced his role with glee and his presence was a high point.  Lord Fellowes's appearance as host of each episode may bring to mind Alistair Cooke's stint with Masterpiece Theatre.  Personally, I found myself recalling SNL's Jon Lovitz as Evelyn Quince in Tales of Ribaldry, an image that I doubt Lord Fellowes intended to project.  Overall, I would recommend this production to fans of Victoriana.  It has motivated me to read Anthony Trollope's novels which I believe may have been at least one of Lord Fellowes's goals in this endeavor.

Anything Julian Fellowes does is fine with me!  This series is a mini-novella -- succinctly wrapped up in four episodes.  It has all the dramatic elements of the period -- class distinctions (the upper class young man who falls in love with a girl;" beneath his station"), villains (including the wealthy but nasty would-be suitor), posers, the kindly uncle, conflict, vanity (the money-challenged upper-crust looking down on those who control their financial fate), and good-triumphs-over- evil. This is formula drama, but a fun summer "book" on video.

The actors are all believable and enjoyable. The Doctor Thorne character, played by the same actor who was Mr. Collins in the Keira Knightley version of Pride and Prejudice, is very good.  Whereas I found him so creepily irksome in the P&P role, he is so likeable as Dr. Thorne and manages to convey an entirely different persona.  Since it is just four one-hour episodes, it is easy to finish it on a rainy, lazy afternoon or two evenings.  It is predictable, but an enjoyable movie with a few loose ends in regards to the resolution of some under-developed minor characters.

I love British period pieces a la Jane Austen.  Doctor Thorne is the perfect fix for a Brit-period-Ro. You know the formula, two exceedingly attractive young people in love, one of whom is wise and witty beyond her years which only enrages the despised but usually socially and financially powerful, wicked mother/aunt/town snob(s) who wants their offspring to "marry well, marry money" but whose object of affection is in different social class, thereby unattainable.  Julian Fellowes penned this fun, witty, satirical take on the good girl Becky Thorne, whose birth of questionable origin comes to the fore as she's cruelly frozen out and banned from her friends-since-birth circle of friends, including the handsome and kind son who loves Becky. The mother is scheming to marry him off to an older American.  Mother embodies all that is cruel with the misguided notion that the appropriate and family-name and social status saving marriage is only attained through betrayal, plotting, and "polite"but cruel social maneuvering.  Don't count Becky Thorne out or underestimate the power of the idealistic, authentic and pining young love to give the town snobs their comeuppance.

Trollope takes just a bit of license here and there with the storyline; on most points I'd say he improves on Trollope in fact (and I'm a big fan of Trollope).  Wish it had been done as a longer production though, like 2-3 times the length ;)  Well worth watching then reading the book (then watching again!)

The costuming was interesting.  There were some pieces I wouldn't be caught dead in, so it would be interesting to research just how accurate the styling was.  As Julian Fellowes said in his opening remarks, it was filmed during one of the most glorious summers England has seen, and there is nothing like the English countryside during a glorious summer!  What splendid scenery! Fortunately, the summer I spent in Wilstone near Tring was just such a summer, and this brought it all back.  Thanks you for a super enjoyable feast that delighted all the senses!  I might forgive you now for taking away Downton Abbey.

This was too pretty and too well-acted to get anything below four stars, but there were aspects and parts of it that were extremely lacking. The bizarre introduction and conclusion of each video by Julian Fellowes was ridiculously erudite at best, creepy at worst. If you know anything about the period, you will be rolling your eyes at his absurd condescension; if you aren't as familiar with it, you'd have an easier (and less creepy) time of it just heading over to wikipedia and reading up a bit. Secondly, the tone was... confusing. The story itself was rather serious; people's livelihoods and well-being were at stake, and the actors played it very seriously. But the music would suddenly become light and comical at the weirdest moments; it was sort of like listening to the Cranford soundtrack while watching Downton Abbey (a very, very serious show). This ties in with the treatment of one of the young female characters; the way she is tricked and left out in the cold at the very end is apparently supposed to be humorous, yet I felt Fellowes (being the filmmaker) was unnecessarily making fun of this character, who just wanted to secure her own well-being and seemed to form a genuine connection with the person she was interested in (plus the person she was interested in seemed rather sincere and interested in her, too, and so the sudden change he makes -off camera- comes out of nowhere and is just very bizarre). If this entire situation is true to the book, then fine, but film it in a way that makes more sense. If the character is genuinely mercenary and/or a fool, then present her in that way, rather than sympathetic. Lastly, and I suppose this ties in with the previous point, but the length is problematic. Some 19th century novels can be successfully summed up in a single film, but this is very rare. They are massive tomes where each and every scene adds something to the narrative... it's why so many of them are made into mini-series, and it's why this almost always works (Bleak House, Price and Prejudice, and Cranford [though Cranford is an amalgamation of three novels] are the best examples). I felt as if I was just missing something, here and there, from one scene to another... characters seemed to change their minds out of nowhere, and it made the passage of time difficult to keep up with (apparently Frank leaves for Cambridge several times and I believe several months actually pass, maybe even years, but it truly feels like little more than a week passes throughout the entire thing). Okay, despite all those criticisms, like I said, it wasn't painful to watch, and I was totally fine with it. Adaptations of Victorian novels are my favorite, and it's hard to disappoint me TOO much. Fellowes is just lucky his actors were so good. And for gods sake, please Amazon get rid of those creepy fireside chats if you decide to let him make another one!

As a great fan of Anthony Trollope, I was thrilled to see this dramatization appear on Prime video.  Julian Fellowes adaptation has rendered this wonderful Victorian piece well, with spectacular settings and wonderful costumes, as well as capturing the very essence of Trollope's work.  Trollope writes primarily of the manners and mores of Victorian England, mostly with his tongue firmly planted in his cheek.  Fellowes manages to capture his style and the actors do a terrific job of portraying the characters.  Wonderfully done and I hope he tackles another Trollope work soon!

'Julian Fellowes Presents Doctor Thorne' is a lovely story that centers around the penniless niece of an upright but nevertheless poor country doctor, in 1850s England.  It is a story about love, manipulation, financial woes, the narrow-minded attitudes of high society at the time, lust for fortune and prominence, and other life dramas.

While received during childhood by the influential Gresham family at nearby Greshamsbury Park estate, in adulthood Mary Thorne is shunned by the mistress of the estate because of Marys low standing in society and suspicions in regards to her parentage.  Nevertheless, young Frank Greshams love for Mary remains steadfast, even when Mary herself deems herself unworthy and tries to distance herself.  Despite all the twists and turns in the story, true love wins over, lessons are learned, and the ending is a happy one for all.

The story is rich with colorful characters  some endearing, some amusing, others provoking and unpleasant.  The four-part drama series, season 1, is based on Anthony Trollopes novel Doctor Thorne, scripted for television and hosted by Julian Fellowes.

If you enjoyed Downton Abbey, then this mini series is a must. I don't want to give too much away but I will say Julian Fellowes is a genius. Okay, yes this is a trip back in time, 1700's if I remember correctly. The well to do British trying to save their status by marrying the daughter to a man of means. It's just never that easy and I found myself sympathetic towards the main character. I love the British but I do have a problem understanding what is being said due to the thick accent. I found watching the series on my Kindle instead of on the television made a big difference. I just loved this series, so do watch it.

Long before the Downton Abbey phenomenon I was/am a sucker for all things British: Merchant Ivory, The Jane Austen film adaptations, etc. so I was happy to discover this short series on Amazon and honestly had it not been so short I don't think I would've stuck it out until the end.  Others who gave it poor reviews pretty much echo my issues with it so I won't repeat them with the exception of the under drawn character complaint because it is the most obvious issue with this series.

In all honesty, the reason for this review was I just wanted to bring the overall rating down so people don't get their hopes up because this may be one of the disappointing series I have ever dedicated any time to.
Thin and predictable.

While I enjoyed it, it was trite and entirely predictable.  Julian's commentary was entertaining, albeit rather much an advertisement for the show to follow as opposed to an actual preface.  What I realized, and should have after the Downton Abbey series, was that these are relatively inexpensive productions to raise.  All you need are actors, period costumes, and the rental of fancy estates and vehicles.  There's no CGI or exotic stunts or arcane locations (think "African Queen" in the actual jungle, or the Bourne Series throughout Europe, Moscow, and the US), and no extremely expensive stars.  "Upstairs, Downstairs" presaged this period approach on TV (a technology which has morphed into any streaming, satellite, or cable media), but it took a number of years before it actually took hold.  We're likely to see more of this inexpensive soap-opera-ish type of offering given the demand for content.  Scripps Network, Disney, Netflix, and now Amazon....all chasing inexpensive but attractive content.
In this instance they took 4 episodes to produce a 2 hour made for TV movie.  Entertaining but don't expect much.

This is a charming, albeit lightweight, summertime treat without the depth of Jane Austen nor the complexity of Downton Abbey.  The two young star-crossed lovers pictured here are beautiful to look at & their acting renders them sincere.  Of course, they're surrounded by a bevy of bubble-headed twits, scheming old hags & a delightful American heiress who proves invaluable.  If you can't travel to England soon, feast your eyes on the landscapes that inspired hundreds of poets & the castles-to-die for.  As julian Fellowes says in his fascinating commentaries, Anthony Trollope's characters are not quite Dickensian, but if you can't get enough of Victorian dramas, one step above soap operas, this is for you. p.s My husband tried several times to watch it & fell asleep repeatedly.

The climax was very satisfying, and I felt foolish that I had not seen it coming. One quibble with this as with most modern historic productions was the very modern makeup on the women.

This was fairly good, although it was no "Downton Abbey"!  It takes place earlier, in the Victorian era, and is a very typical story -- titled nobleman from impoverished family rejects rich American woman who could save his family, in favor of true love with a poor, illegitimate local girl.  Said local girl, who has been raised as "Dr. Thorne's niece", is actually the niece of a very wealthy  man (wonderfully played by Ian McShane); and with a few, predictable, twists and turns, true love, great wealth, and happiness all around  end up together in the finale.  It feels like a Masterpiece Theater, and the costumes and scenery are spectacular.  It's a fun, easy, short series to watch; and despite calling it "Season One", I highly doubt there is a Season Two.

This is a good and faithful adaptation of a great novel.  If the actors exaggerate character traits somewhat, I find that in keeping with the way they are written in the novel.  In other words, the actors are not trying to, nor should they, give contemporary,modern realistic performances, but rather portray the fictional people as Trollope described them, a bit over-the-top.  I loved the phyiscal authenticity of this period piece, including the men's messy hair and some of the ladies' overly floral hair ornamentation.  However, Frank's hairdo was quite distracting, toupee-like, definitely NOT swoon worthy.  The only other element that distracted from the perfection of presentation of this novel was Julian Fellowes' appearances.  He is no Alistair Cooke, and instead of being capable of drawing American audiences into material they might have regarded as effete, Fellows comes across as exactly the kind of silly British snob we sneer at.
I never read the book, but this mini-series was enjoyable if not a little predictable.  I love this period in history.  I also love the actor playing Dr. Thorne.

While you'll recognize some actors from other British dramas, including Downton Abbey, this seemingly B-class drama felt rushed and left me wanting. This wasn't the quality we expect from Mr. Fellowes. While keeping close to the story and with witty banter Jilian is known for, it felt too much of a comical stretch. The acting was a bit off, especially when it comes to our villian. We want to love Mary Thorne, but in the end she is quite dull. The best of the series lies in the last 15 minutes. I'm sorry Mr. Fellowes... I'm a huge fan of your work, but I just couldn't hop aboard this train for more than 3 stars.

Fun miniseries, in the vein of recent adaptations of Jane Austen's novels. It reminded me a lot of screen adaptations of Mansfield Park. The same cast of characters you see in many costume dramas - star-crossed lovers, a henpecked husband who gets his quiet comeuppance at the end, shrill judgmental society ladies, giggling debutantes. It's all very predictable, comfortable, and delightful. This one has a slow spot or two, but hang on for the ending, which is comical and jubilant.

The intros by Julian Fellowes were cute and quirky but ultimately didn't add any value or interesting information to the episodes. Think Alan Cummings or Laura Linney introducing the Masterpiece Theater programs. Fine as a buffer between commercials for a TV airing; but not really sure why it's necessary on a Prime show. It's a minor quibble; I think the intro on each episode will probably be annoying with a repeat viewing. Because there WILL be a repeat viewing - it's definitely a keeper.

I think the photo chosen for the series doesn't do it justice, frankly I was turned off by it. The actors are captured better in the series, just like a book cover that one image can determine for some whether to crack the cover. I enjoyed the story very much, I loved (spoiler alert) the happy ending. Loved the cast they all fit the time period and their roles. If you are a fan of 19th century English literature (I am) and enjoy taking an imaginary journey to a time of non-modern manners and sensibilities (as I do), then this one's for you.  The romantic morality tale fits the 4-episode format nicely.  The characters and locations are full of charm.  I'd seen Tom Hollander (who plays Dr. Thorne) recently as a villainous modern-day international arms dealer in "The Night Manager" mini-series, so took pleasure in his acting versatility.  Dr. Thorne is the pivot around which the entire plot of the story turns.  He proves to be a benign, honorable and seemingly unintentional puppet master whose actions and attitudes shape the lives of everyone else.

Julian Fellowes provides wry and affectionate commentary to introduce and close each episode.  That's fun...very reminiscent of the role Alfred Hitchcock played  in his tv series in the 1960s.

Doctor Thorne was light, fun, and entertaining, as well as beautifully acted and shot. Julian Fellowes himself appears at the beginning and end of each episode (which, incidentally, I found rather irksome; I skipped these sections after the first episode), extolling the virtues of the tale and claiming that it belongs in the annals of classic Regency fiction along with such as Jane Austen. However, the premise of the eldest son of a rich family that has squandered their fortune who falls in love with a kind but poor woman is so tired as to be considered a cliche. It was quite clear from the first episode what the resolution would be, and the plot played out exactly as expected. So while I enjoyed this production, I don't believe it compares favorably with the works of a master like Austen, whose complex and engaging plots and characters never get old.

The scenery was exquisite and authentic. Highly recommend to anyone who enjoys period pieces such as this.

I had never heard of Trollope's Dr. Thorne before Julian Fellowes adaptation came to Amazon. A wonderful job!  Thanks to Fellowes, Amazon and the cast and crew for such a great job.  I must honestly say I've now watched the whole series through a number of times and am nearly as amazed with Fellowes work on it as with Downton Abbey.  Major Kudos!!!

Now I am the first to say that the book is better than the film or TV adaptation but this version of Doctor Thorne is just so well done that it's one of my favourite adaptations of a novel.

The settings are exquisite and the characterization just as I pictured in the novel so this ticks all the boxes for me and more. It's nice and compact too without feeling rushed and there is so much detail and charm to this story that it really is a nice one to settle down with on a sunday afternoon.
It's a nice gentle drama with a dark secret at its core and the unravelling of this secret is the crux of the story - there's also some classic comedy moments however regarding how people of the different classes used to act - take note of the boy's mother in the story and how she changes her tune when events change! I did giggle at this. This is just one of the many fine moments which make up this drama.

If you're keen to know where this was filmed, there is a review and map on thebooktrail.com and the villages are just as cute as they look on the TV!

Highly recommended!

This was so enjoyable.  I was interested because I thought Tom Hollander was great in The Night Manager, and thought it would be neat to see him in a much different role.  He was great as the titular Doctor Thorne and seemed very natural in the role.  Also phenomenal were Harry Richardson (yum!) and Stefanie Martini as the conflicted couple - their longing was palpable and was the lynch pin to maintaining the story's interest.  They are both gorgeous in addition to being obviously talented...I look forward to seeing more of them.
I was concerned that the story may move too slow, as some of this genre do, but with only 4 episodes, things move along swiftly enough to keep the viewer's interest.  While the story was fairly predictable, it was good fun and I was disappointed for it to end.  Another favorite performance that I have to mention is Janine Duvitski as Lady Scatcherd.  I really hope we get to see more of this story, and I thank Julian Fellowes for bringing this author's work to light.

I am hard-pressed to evaluate this four-part series.  Julian Fellowes introduces and then ends each episode in very Hitchcockian fashion, even looking and posing much as Hitchcock did.  It is no Downton Abbey and it is very dark but not satisfying.  I found a total disconnect between the story and the music as the music seemed very light and airy at some of the dreariest parts.  I have no ear at all for music so you can imagine that it must have been very apparent- even intrusive- for me to pay attention.  But each episode is only 42 minutes so three hours is not much time to spend if you are a Trollope and/or Fellowes fan.

Look out Downtown Abbey.  Their's a new show on the block.  Looks like Julian Fellows did it again. That's what I have gathered while I'm playing on my tablet while my wife watches it.
I so enjoyed and loved, loved, loved this series. Julian Fellows nailed it again,. He is adorable with is introduction and conclusion to each episode. I would love more just like this.

We've been spoiled with six amazing seasons of what is arguably the best drama ever to grace the television screen. So, it's probably unfair to even make a comparison.  That said, this is vintage Fellowes: wealthy landed gentry losing control of land and position and needing a wealthy American heiress to secure their place; a seemingly ill-fated love interest;  complicated and interesting characters; breathtaking settings, costumes, sets and props. The added bonus is that we are introduced to an often overlooked 19th century British author, Anthony Trollope AND it's Fellowes himself who gives us the literary critique of Trollope's work in a Hitchcockian way! I found that aspect delightful!

Since there are only four episodes and each are fairly brief, it's possible to binge on the entire season in one evening.

Thanks Amazon and Julian Fellowes for a fun post-Downton evening!
True to the book
I love Anthony Trollope. And I really enjoyed this presentation of Dr. Thorne. The actors were wonderful. The settings were gorgeous, and the plot was most realistic for mid-19th century England.

The actors are all superb in their roles, particularly Tom Hollander, Rebecca Front, Ian McShane, Phoebe Nicholls and relative newcomer Stefanie Martini as Mary Thorne.  Lord Fellowes provides bemused commentary in a fashion reminiscent of the late Alistair Cooke, and he truly does Trollope justice with this lively adaptation.

Based on an novel  Anthony Trollope written in the mid-1850s, this video will appeal to readers of his other works as well as readers who like Jane Austen's works. The story focuses on a young woman born the illegitimate daughter of the local physician's brother, Dr. Thorpe, adopted as his niece. The characters are well-developed and it is enhanced by the period costumes and aristocratic settings are of country houses. It is pleasing overall but  readers should know that although Fellowes is well-known for his ability to dramatize this genre (e.g., Downton Abbey and Gosford Park) this is a predictable rags-to-sudden riches tale in which all the "evil" repent their sins and turn out to be "good" people in the end.

British period piece set in the late 19th Century when some great estates were in financial difficulties that could be assuaged by fortuitous marriages. Beset by conflicts of duty and love, the marriageable sons and daughters grapple with custom, manners, their parents. Interesting characters, unexpected turns, and a happy ending made this series a pleasure to watch.

I'm a sucker for virtually all English period pieces, whether they be dramas about the English royals, or simply of bygone eras, such as "Downton Abbey," which was also written by Julian Fellowes. Clearly cashing in on his extraordinarily successful version of "Upstairs/Downstairs," Mr. Fellowes not only has turned to a book by the 19th century English writer Anthony Trollope for his source, he also turns himself into a sort of Alistair Cooke, making both pre- and post-episode comments. Unfortunately, in spite of a fairly dependable cast and lovely scenery, all is rather hackneyed and cliche, the entire plot and its denouement clearly seen just about from Scene 1. I don't understand why it's referred to as "Season One," as the story is contained in only 4 episodes. Unless the implication is that Mr. Fellowes will be back with another story based on the works of Anthony Trollope. It was diverting enough, but far from the standard set by so many other similar tales. I think a rerun of "Downton Abbey" would be more entertaining.

Doctor Thorne is a four-part television miniseries created by Julian Fellowes (he who created the popular Downton Abbey television series and starred as Kilwillie in Monarch of the Glen.). This series from 2016 lovingly dramatizes the novel of the same name by Anthony Trollope. Doctor Thorne is the third novel in Trollopes Chronicles of Barsetshire series. The Warden (1855) Barchester Towers (1857) Doctor Thorne (1858) Framley Parsonage (1861) The Small House at Allington (1864) Most of his novels are available for download free or for a small fee. The novel is available for Kindle: Doctor Thorne. You can read "Doctor Thorne" without reading the first two novels. Anthony Trollope is one of my favorite writers. Trollopes characters are realistic, complex, confused, conflicted, and self-contradictory. Many consider him to be one of the parents of the modern novel. This mini-series of Doctor Thorne is entirely true to Trollopes novel. I was impressed with the entire production. The first two novels in the Chronicles of Barsetshire series (The Warden and Barchester Towers) were previously dramatized in The Barchester Chronicles. Also available in The Anthony Trollope Collection (The Barchester Chronicles / He Knew He Was Right / The Way We Live Now). Also check out: The Pallisers - The Complete Collection.

It took me a while to get on board with Dr. Thorne, but probably somewhere in the middle of episode 1, I was hooked.  It was a little disconcerting that Julian Fellowes introduced, and ended each episode, but perhaps he was following in the steps of Alfred Hitchcock.  In any event, the information about Trollope was interesting, but I didn't think we needed to be told how to view characters, or the story line.  Fellowes is an exceptional writer, so I'll forgive the excess information.  I thoroughly enjoyed all four episodes, and, of course, the happy ending.

I loved this. My only complaint is that it went by too fast.  Julian Fellowes presents this drama just as Alistair Cook used to introduce Masterpiece Theatre episodes back in the day, and I loved it. So interesting to hear background information, maybe a little clarification, but mostly just to share in relishing a good story with someone who  appreciates it as much as I do.  I honestly wish I could thank Mr. Fellowes.  This show took me back and warmed my heart.  I wish he knew how much this work is appreciated.  I wish he would do this every week, for the next 20 years.

It was presented similarly to Masterpiece Theatre.  Julian Fellowes sat in a chair to introduce the storyline and the scene was reminiscent of Alistair Cooke, who would recap the previous episode and wonder how the plot lines would converge and what would happen to the characters.  All of the acting was superb, the suspense maintained so there was not one boring moment.  The cinematography was beautiful.  Remember the old Masterpiece Theatre?  So much of those scenes were interior.  It's so nice to see a sort of graceful, beautiful series such as this presented with the grand houses, the beautiful scenery and the historical antiquities so accurately.  Bravo, Bravo, Bravo!!  I hope Julian Fellowes continues to produce excellent series such as these.  They will be most welcome, especially as Downton Abbey has ended.

It had some of the Downton Abbey 'feel', but on a different note. Here we have a self-made rich man of the people (Sir Roger Scatcherd) who was an alcoholic and had a spoiled unappreciative son (Sir Louis ) who, for all intents and purposes, was an alcoholic as well. We also have the essentially middle class physician, Dr. Thorne, who took care of the older alcoholic man as well as had a beautiful niece whom the son, Sir Loius, wanted to marry, but she would not agree as she had a love for someone else.  All set in England, of course with some typical scenery as we saw not only in Downton Abbey, but in many of those shows based in 19th century England. Overall, we found ourselves wanting to see more.

After watching one episode, here's a quick take: a short, miniseries, Downton Abbey-like show, but without the great cast and character development. It's got the production values, costumes, and authenticity you'd expect from a Julian Fellowes production, of course. But the pace seems wrong to me -- too hurried. In the rush to fit the entire plot into a 5- or 6-part miniseries, it doesn't have the time it needs to develop the characters slowly, and let them simmer in our imagination as we proceed. Worth giving it a try, though -- it might ring your chimes.

Fellowes' Alfred Hitchcock-intros were a little overdone, but helpful and friendly. I'd give this more stars if I could.  Fellowes (Monarch of the Glen, A most Mysterious Murder, Downton Abbey, et al) has given us another brilliant drama, this time from the novel by Anthony Trollope.  Stunningly filmed and with first rate acting from a great cast this is a must see!  Not only does Fellowes give us a great screen adaptation but before and after each episode he gives a synopsis and a bit of history from Trollope's time.  His fireside chats reminded me of Alistair Cooke's introductions/follow-ups for the PBS Masterpiece Theatre series many years ago.
My sincere hope is that this is just the start of an ongoing collaboration between Fellowes and Amazon!  Amazon should be commended for producing drama of this caliber.

It's a nice depiction of Victorian culture, but I think the series may have been better off without the commentary by Fellowes before and after each episode. It tends to make the viewer feel patronized.

It is a lot of fun -- very entertaining, and the acting/overacting is delightful. For those of us who remember Allistair Cooke as the original host of what was Masterpiece Theatre, Julian Fellowes, the writer of this script and a Trollope enthusiast, does the introductions to the four segments with great charm and wit. I have already watched the entire four episodes three times. There is enough fast-talking smarm for all tastes. Turn on the subtitles. The overarching theme, of course, is GREED, and of course there's plenty of English treacle to send you into sugar shock, if you enjoy that. There's no spoiler alert in this post! Let's hope there will be more seasons.

If you like period pieces like Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice", you will love this. It has all the right elements: a young aristocrat about to loose his fortune and family estate, being forced to consider marriage for money, while steadfastly in love with a beautiful young lady considered unsuitable by his parents. However, the secret surrounding her birth, the money and status she is about to inherit, and whether or not the star-crossed lovers will be together in the end, is the real mystery here. Julian Fellows, of Downton Abbey fame, narrates, and the film will transport you to the 1800's where fortune, vanity and position in society rule the day.

"Doctor Thorne" is a charming adaptation of Anthony Trollope's novel as seen through the lens of Julian Fellowes of "Downton Abbey" fame.  This Victorian tale has very Austen-esque qualities for those that enjoy these stories.  Since this is a Fellowes joint you're guaranteed splendid costumes and sumptuous, grand English country homes and estates along with nicely honed dialog from the characters.  "Thorne" is a romance primarily and revolves around the penniless niece of a country doctor who's the love interest of an equally poor suitor from a once wealthy family.  The one family wants their son to marry money and cruelly discourage Mary Thorne from following through with her engagement to her childhood love.  There are many fine performance including Tom Hollander as the title character, Stefanie Martini as Mary Thorne, Ian McShane as a wealthy baronet, and Alison Brie (who somehow is made to look rather homely here) as a rich American heiress husband hunting abroad.  There's some interesting twists and ultimately a happy ending.  If you like costume dramas and this time period than you'll no doubt enjoy "Doctor Thorne" as well.

This is a wonderful four part series of Anthony Trollope's novel, "Doctor Thorne". Julian Fellowes has brought to the screen this tale of :Lust Money and Greed, in a period when England' s Aristocratic Class controlled the gloriously green meadows, forests and hills.

Predictable but beautifully done. The sets, the settings, the manor houses and castles are absolutely fantastic, as are the costumes. Story-wise, it's not Cranford or Dickens or even Downton--it's a little more like Austen. You pretty much know exactly what will happen but the fun is on accompanying the characters on the journey. Ian McShane plays disaster to perfection and Tom Hollander's performance is flawless--as good as he is at playing villains, it's so nice to see him in a likable role again. And the lead couple are ridiculously adorable. Highly enjoyable.

A lovely light adaptation of a period "happy ending" novel.  Trollope's strength (in my opinion) when compared with his contemporaries was in writing well rounded characters in real world situations without going dark like Dickens and many others did.  Julian Fellowes is obviously fond of the novel and the cast does a wonderful job filling out their roles.  Frank and Mary and determined and naive, Lady Arabella is conniving and selfish, etc.  Tom Hollander carries the series magnificently, giving one of his most thoughtful performances of the last decade.  It's not Oscar stuff but he does it tremendously well.  And the English villages, houses, countryside must be mentioned of course, as they provide our setting and do it beautifully.  Please continue to produce series like this Amazon!

tl;dr - If you're a period piece fan, I can't think of a single reason you wouldn't enjoy this.  Happy watching.

I think Dr. Thorne telling his neice only part of what she should know was selfish on his part. She was avoiding a suitor in love with her because he was from wealth & she was penniless (or so she thought!). The good Dr
 Knowing she was the heir to another Uncle's fortune & was not dead as the other Uncle thought made it necessary she be told
 Also, her being told this same Uncle was responsible for her father's death was only half the story. What is Dr Thorne thinking? Maybe, he is afraid to lose her as he raised her in place of his poor brother who was killed without marrying the girl's mother who also died.

British author (Triollope), British screenwriter (Julian Fellows),, British director, British actors and beautiful British countryside and estates. All set in Victorian England. "Dr. Thorne" is light and predictable compared to Fellowes' "Downton Abbey" masterwork. But If you are hungry for a romantic costume drama, and you've gobbled up all the offerings out there, Dr. Thorne is a yummy little confection. Part of the appeal is Julian Fellowes' armchair introduction, and "debriefing" before and after each episode.

Tom Hollander is wonderful, warm and incredibly appealing as Dr. Thorne. I'm a new fan, and will be binge watching Hollander's numerous movies and tv series.

My only complaints about the production are the incredibly messy and distracting hairdo's and costumes our heroine suffers, and the over-the-top floral headdresses and way-too-bright dresses that stole every scene featuring the female cousins. Darn! Dial it back, pleasssse!

Produced by Julian Fellowes,  this may not have the opulence of his famed Downton Abbey but it has a charm and sweetness that brings to life Anthony Trollope's great literary work.  I watched the first episode after the kids went to bed,  thinking I'd meter out the episodes nightly.  At 3am, I finished binge watching the whole miniseries and it was worth the lack of sleep.  Tom Hollander was magnificent in his role as the titular Doctor Thorne and the subject of Victorian society and it's focus on marriage and connections were portrayed true to the work it draws it's plot from.  I can't wait to watch it again.

Mr Fellowes makes it clear that Anthony Trollope is the author, and that he, Mr Fellowes is merely offering the introduction. As he rightly points out, Anthony Trollope was a prolific and terrific author.  This movie adaption of Dr Thorne is perhaps the best Trollope I have seen on film - which is a shame since there is such a wealth of wonderful material from which to work.
It was an absolute delight to see Ian McShane in his pre-Deadwood days; the only drawback is his very limited screen time.  The rest of the cast seem to appreciate the difference between Trollope and the Austen / Dickens / Thackeray  menagerie that makes one much the same as the next.  All said, this series is off to a great start.

This series is an adaptation of Anthony Trollope's most famous homonym novel. This love story takes place in the 19th century in England with its beautiful countryside and amazing castles and manors. A very proud noble family is highly in debts. The mother is dreaming of her son marrying a  rich heir to save the manor, their standing and probably their honor too.
The Greshambury heir flirts with Mary, the niece of Doctor Thorne. Played by a beautiful Stephanie Martini the young orphan secretly loves the well mannered Frank Gresham too (Harry Richardson). Yet,  never Lady Arabella and her sister would consider such a penniless union between these two lovebirds. You can easily imagine there will be obstacles and sudden developments in the story.
Julian Fellowes (Gosford Park, Downton Abbey) made a faithful and visually beautiful adaptation of the book. Like Trollope he evoked with irony the Victorian era main  problem: the social classes differences. (Let's think of Oscar Wilde with The Importance of Being Ernest). Social origin at the time would determine people's relationship and weddings were consequently a very serious thing for the rich families to reinforce and preserve their place in society and be respected/recognized... However money was stronger than anything : one could be well born with a big castle and a long aristocratic genealogy tree, but one could be excused of not being noble if he/she was full of money (represented by the American heir woman in the series). Thus money made people recognized by/in society.
The endearing characters of this series are of course Mary, Frank and Thorne because they are straight, sincere and honest. They are not as interested in money as the others. Frank would be even ready to work to maintain Mary! In the book main and secondary characters have interesting personality whose characteristics have been very well illustrated in the series. For example, Frank father's is a nice guy, but he is represented as being coward as soon as his wife Lady Arabella is around. Other interesting characters you will see are the De Courcy.
I did not like the Julian Fellowes intervention after each episode. It is as boring as the omniscient book narrator in the book. That being said some ironic comments about the hypocrisy of the Victorian society can be funny and relevant for whom has never heard about Victorian society in England.
In general I think this love story series is a successful adaption of the book. Moreover, the Victorian costumes,the outdoor and indoor  decor not to mention the countryside images, everything is really beautiful

Admittedly spoiled by "Downton Abbey" I found Julian Fellowes's adaptation of Trollope's "Dr. Thorne" somewhat lackluster and  hurriedly put together in contrast.  It upsets me to say that because I consider  him a national treasure. But perhaps I am being unfair.

On the positive side I happen to love English literature and admire Britain's very talented actors. So I was happy to watch Tom Hollander, one of my favorites. I had just seen him play a villain in "The Night Manager" where he portrayed a cold, heartless bastard very convincingly.  In contrast as Dr. Thorne he was kind and caring, the complete opposite - again his portrayal was very convincing. Why is British acting so doggone fantastic? I am happy to say the actors here did live up to my expectations. Bravo to them!  And the surroundings and costumes were splendid as well.

My sincere apologies to Mr. Fellowes whom ,I confess, I shall not easily forgive for ending "Downton" so quickly. I was selfishly hoping they could have gone on at least until WW11. As an octogenarian I keep remembering British courage  in face of extremely difficult odds,
their finest hour as the wonderful Winston Churchill said. How would Downton Abbey have been at that time? So much to work with.

Well I cannot be angry  forever.  After all, Julian Fellowes,  whom I admire, just might have something already cooking!  Hurry up, please. Mr Fellowes. Don't keep us/me waiting. My age, you know.

I was really excited to see this because it is presented by Julian Fellowes, now that Downton Abbey is over. I was hoping it would last a couple seasons at least, but it was just 4 episodes. First let me say, I LOVE ALL things BBC or anything resembling British T.V Series.  I have been a devotee since the late 70's when I first saw "All Creatures Great and Small."  Then, I soaked up any and all British series I could find.  Most I liked or loved very much.  And, of course, Downton Abby is right at the top for quality programming.

So, I was most anxious to watch Doctor Thorne.  I fell asleep during the first episode 3-times.  I finally made it all the way, fell asleep through part of episode 2, and was able to watch all of episodes 3-4.  While the settings and costumes were spot on, and the acting was fine, I just couldn't get interested in this show.  I knew in the first 10-minutes exactly how it would end.  And I was right.  When the plot is so transparent you know 'the star-crossed lovers will run into obstacles, never waiver in their feelings, give the other person up in the name of honor, get together in the end' it just doesn't make the show fun to watch.

Lest anyone say "of course you knew the ending, you read the book" I had never even heard of this author or book, let alone read it.  I am sure Julian Fellowes was true to the entire story, and that's a shame.  I have no desire to read this book.  Most of the time, a good movie or t.v. show will entice me to read the book it was inspired by.

Julian Fellows is one of the most articulate and witty contemporary writers.  With a nod to the past and its mannerisms, he imbues characters with the full range of emotions that novels of the past endowed to them.  Trollope is a natural choice for him as it combines humor, societal frisson and fluidity of plot.  The only thing that I missed was the "direct to audience" voice of Trollope where he would explain or give comment on the norms of the time.  There is not a single author that I would request to do Trollope than Mr. Fellows.  He is why many of us become anglophiles.  By the way, I own every novel of Trollope and suggest that those who love these four episodes indulge in following their original author.

Although from a source novel, the predictable story line would not have been so, I guess, boring, had some (not all) of the acting not been so flat and some (not all) of the art direction so off the mark. Mr. Fellowes made it a point to call out the modernity of the multi-faceted characters from the book, but I found some of the acting to be one dimensional. And I was extremely distracted by the costume, makeup and hair design. Many of the women's costumes were in garish colors not of the period, and in some textiles I'm familiar with in fabric stores today (for example, the vicar's sister was in an ombred silk available at my local yardage store). The women's hair accessories were puzzling--faux flowers in so many colors / types along with trailing ribbons that their heads looked like tacky centerpieces--and everytime someone was wearing one on screen, I kept wondering if this was period correct, who thought this looked good, why did they use so many flower variety on one person, etc. that I'd stop listening to the dialogue. The married women's gowns were generally in more tasteful palettes, although again, the quality of the fabric was lacking, or did not translate well on screen. Also, every woman except Mary was over accessorized - hair flowers in multiple types and colors, hair ribbons, earrings, necklaces, lace and bows at the neck and bustline, brooches, shawls, gloves. It's like they were trying to create opulence on a budget, so they threw in everything but the kitchen sink to demonstrate wealth, with no thought of harmony, balance, the personality of each character, or luxuriousness of materials that would read well on screen. It just hit me what the women looked like, collectively, to me: a Disney production with the cartoonist changing colors and shape of the same features on each character to (weakly) create distinction. I will say some of Mary's dresses were sweet and appropriately simple for her "station" in life. For the most part the men's costumes were well done, in rich muted colors and fabrics for some of the waistcoats and cravats ... save for the footman's Kermit the Frog green uniform, which was jarring to say the least. I thought the interiors were beautiful and well lit, although the Greshman's foyer seemed more Italianate with its cold, rosey-hued marble, so I kept thinking it was filmed outside of England or on a stage set. I likeed Dr. Thorne's offices and home, with the dark interiors and crackling fireplace - seemed appropriate for the town medic. However, a few of the outdoor scenes seemed oddly lit, like I was watching a digitally recorded soap opera, and the overall mood of some of those scenes clashed greatly with the nicely done interior scenes. I would say take a pass on this series and keep searching for a more nuanced (on all fronts) period production.

Julian Fellowes never disappoints. I absolutely love Downton and this series, while very short in comparison, was just as good. I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys shows like Downton.
