delightful, I enjoyed every minute, but disappointed the story was so short!

this is certainly no "downton abbey".  i've not read the book from which it is adapted, but if it lives up to the introductions and end commentary fellowes provides in each episode (ala "masterpiece theater") this series needed to be at least twice as long as it is.  the redemption of the villains comes as a sentence or two on a deathbed and in no way shows trollope (author of the book) as a deep student of character motivations or as having any interest in providing more than two dimensions for his characters, and those two dimensions are layed on as broadly as possible. why only 4 episodes?  there is very little treatment of any backstory aside from this happened, then this happened...no exploration of how events affected anyone and so very little sympathy engendered for any of the characters.  and they are, except the title character and the star crossed lovers, all reprehensible in one way or another.

i was so disappointed in the story itself that i'm not going into too much detail on the production which, while handsome, also seemed hollow. aside from dr. thorne, i've seen better acting in high school plays. even ian mcshane, whom i've always loved, is hamming it up like an easter dinner. it is as if everyone involved had to lay the archetypes (drunk, snooty, angelic, befuddled) on so thickly so the audience would "get it" immediately as there was not going to be time to develop these characters naturally.

i'm a prime member, so at least i didn't have to pay extra for this. such a let down.

I'm not often moved to write reviews, but in this situation I have to comment.  This mini-series was enjoyable to watch.  It was adeptly paced, though predictable.  Fluff entertainment for what its worth.  The thing that killed it for me was Mr. Fellowes' introduction and (especially) deconstruction of each episode.  I understand (because of the overly lengthy prologue) that Mr. Fellowes is enamored of the books, but any intelligent viewer would have taken Mr. Fellows' comments as a form of self-gratification the like of which I haven't seen since English lit. 101.  This mini-series would have stood better alone than with the blathering of Julian Fellowes before and after.
I thought it was wonderful.  I look forward to many more seasons.

Finally! I have been wanting to watch a new Victorian Era film with my 13 year old daughter and I felt that this one was age-appropriate! This was the best film since the BBC put out the most recent Emma, Sense and Sensibility and Pride and Prejudice!! I personally was so relieved that there was no homosexuality, and that the most the main characters did was kiss and it was cut within a short amount of time. I didn't have to squirm in my seat, knowing my daughter was watching too. Thank you Julianne Fellows for keeping this one clean and respectable. I LOVED it! Keep them coming!!

This is a great period drama.  Totally predictable but fun and enjoyable.  If you enjoy Jane Austin, you will enjoy this.  I hope Amazon makes more like it.  I was not a fan of Julian Fellowes talking so much.  The intro about the book and author was interesting but I was annoyed by the commentary at the end of the episodes and usually skipped it.

My only regret was that it was four (4) episodes!  Characters were well developed, situations were utterly believable - my problem was that I  and my friends, expected Julian to be our guide for more than 4 episodes. Who knew Julian Fellowes could develop a piece - I have not read the book - that would answer what happened to the characters, offer possible insight  into "why", address the cultural feelings at this time, give me and my friends  enough time to  discuss/watch each  episode and determine what the next episode would be about.
I think we thought Julian Fellowes has only one bag of tricks ( the many episodes developed for "Downton Abbey") and we were prepared to settle back and enjoy!  We, senior citizens, enjoyed Doctor Thorne and look forward to  the next  Julian Fellowes offering. ( I hope he is teaching a Literature class somewhere to help future writers to learn how to adapt literature written in another period to contemporary times w/o having the characters compromise their truth  - appropriate for the time in history - to engage a 21st century audience.
Always can count on good writing when Fellows is the author.

I don't write many reviews, if any, but this series was fantastic. Julian Fellows has done it again. Love, self sacrifice, honor, duty, and money are the best combination. You will not be disappointed with this series!

Another well-done period piece by Julian Fellowes who has a real appreciation for Anthony Trollope.  In the mid-1970s, PBS presented the Pallisers, a compilation of the Barsetshire novels.  Anyone who enjoyed this will be pleasantly surprised by Dr. Thorne.  The story may unfold a little slowly for those accustomed to the twists and turns of Downton Abbey, but the themes and character development are as interesting today as they were in the 1840s.  Beautifully shot in time-appropriate villages and manor houses.  Enjoy!

But, I did think Fellowes did a good job portraying the feel of Trollope's writing.

I cannot believe this tawdry production passed muster with so many reviewers.  The casting, costumes, script, & production values are completely lacking in the quality which made Downton Abbey so enjoyable.  It also felt dated, like something from PBS 30 years ago.  The fevered plot suffers from a case of the vapors, the secrets are banal and boring, the scenery chewed & gnawed like a shank of mutton.  The opening credits of Downton Abbey alone had more substance and beauty than an entire episode of Dr. Thorne, and sadly, Mr. Fellows' Midas touch has turned to fool's gold.

Trollope has a special edginess to his depiction of Victorian society which is defined perfectly in this production by Julian Fellows.  This story is one novel in what is known as his Chronicles of Barsetshire.  Previous BBC productions of Trollope novels have been extremely successful in both attracting great casts as well as audiences.  This production stands out for the same reasons so I am hopeful that Julian Fellows will follow this with other adaptations from the Chronicles.

It was wonderful, and I highly recommend it to Austen and/or DA fans - almost a hybrid of the two.  Set in 1855, it is the story of a country doctor (Dr. Thorne, played by Tom Hollander (2005 Mr. Collins)), and his niece Mary, who is of questionable birth and has no money but is beloved by many in their village.

Brief plot outline:  A local, wealthy family (the Greshams) has a son, Frank, who is in love with Mary, much to the disapproval of their mother, Lady Arabella.  Lady Arabella and her husband need at least one of their children to marry into a lot of money to save their estate, which is in debt. In addition to Frank, Lady A has two daughters, Beatrice, who seems to like Mary, and Augusta, who might be inclined to be kinder to Mary but is easily persuaded to not do so by her snooty and wealthy cousin Audrina and aunt Lady DeCourcy, played by Phoebe Nicholls of Downton ( who played Lady Rose's mother). There are other characters who figure into how this will all turn out, as well, some comical, some cruel, though not one-dimensionally so.
I binge watched this over two days - just 4 short episodes, and it left me longing to read more of Trollope.  Although not a contemporary of Austen, apparently Trollope's mother lived in the same neighborhood at the same time as the Austens (or so I've read).  I've also heard folks who like Austen will like Trollope's works.

I think it's just as beautiful and cinematic as Downton Abbey. It's a different story line, though, so of course you can't expect it to be exactly the same! It has all the same great themes, though, of class/caste, money, love, and revenge. I also think the debriefing at the end by Lord Fellowes is adorable. If you like Brit. period dramas, you'll like this.

Also, Alison Brie! She's wonderful. I loved her as Trudy Campbell, and I love her in this! There's something so hilarious about her to me. She does the job perfectly as The American Heiress.

I liked the series a lot, but felt that there were substantial swaths of story left out.  I went ahead and downloaded the Kindle book and Audible version as well to see if I was right....and I was. I do think that overall the adaptation is fairly true to the spirit of the book, even though there are some plot points that are handled very differently.

It's really a shame that you can't dramatize Trollope's turn of phrase.  Without spoiling anything, I think I can share the following description of a gentleman who's just been hit by a rotten egg while making a speech, "As the insidious fluid trickled down beneath his waistcoat, he felt that all further powers of coaxing the electors out of their votes, by words flowing from his tongue sweeter than honey, was for that occasion denied to him."  I've been dying to work the word's "insidious fluid" into conversation for the past week...

With a resume touting the makers of Downtown Abbey, one expects to find the very best.  Perhaps the problem is that it sets our expectations a little too high.  This feel good drama is set at the end of the Victorian era where class, 'breeding' and money mean everything.  America is booming with 'new', working class money and the aristocratic ways of excess minus the sweat of the brow are quickly swirling down the toilet.  Rich, aristocratic families are quickly finding that simply owning land can't keep up with the rising prices of living while cities, industry and the tycoons it produced taunt their ideas of 'acceptable' matches in marriages when they face the loss of their homes vs. the acceptance of children of working men.  *egads!*  Doctor Thorne presents us with an aristocratic family in just such a position.  Their lovely son is in love with a commoner girl, the child of a doctor (even he is too common for the family's taste.)  They do their best to dissuade the marriage between the two in the hopes of forcing their son to 'wed money', even if it is 'vulgar, new money.'  Of course, the entire point of the book and movie is to show the shallowness of the rich and the beauty of the more common man.  But in all fairness, the book does allow for at least one good rich man- Frank, the son who must decide to save his family or serve his own happiness by marrying the woman he truly loves.  Watch the movie to see which direction he turns.  I love 'feel good' endings, but I don't love when a movie is, well, badly done.  The film, from the beginning, treats us like children, as if we don't know how we should feel as the characters do and say things.  Even the music is overdone.  When the scene is supposed to be funny or ironic, the music is goofy and funny.  I felt like I was watching an old flick from the 50's!  The acting was also overblown sometimes.  Especially the evil Louis.  Sir Roger Scatcherd was pretty hard to watch as well.  I know a lot of people complained of Julian Fellowes commenting before and after each episode.  That kind of thing doesn't affect me at all if the movie itself is good.  You can just ff through it.  Over all, the film was still fun to watch.  It was something to do while I worked on my art pieces at my desk.  But I would never take serious time to watch it.  That's what's so good about Amazon- once you pay for it, it's free, so no loss.  But I wouldn't recommend paying a penny to see it.  So, let's just put it that way.  Great to fill some time, but not good enough to spend money to see it.

The show is a decently entertaining drama set in Victorian Englandmore specifically, the moneyed class of 1856. On its own, it would be an average or even slightly above average TV drama. But Julian Fellowes (creator & writer of Downton Abbey) is the screenwriter for this series, which is based on a novel that is NOT written by Fellowes. The show is promoted as being "Presented by Julian Fellowes" and thus is meant to draw in the many Downton Abbey fans who already miss the frolicking excitement of British high society. That instantly sets up a comparison in viewers' minds with Downton, and let me tell you, when compared to Downton Abbey, Doctor Thorne is a letdown.

The characters are much more two-dimensional, with the "good guys" being overly pure and kindhearted and the "bad guys" being inhumanly cruel and selfish. The rich American girl is annoyingly conceited. The two young lovers really have no substantial connection, at least none shown on screen. Doctor Thorne is by far the most compelling character on the show, and Tom Hollander does a spectacular job with what he is given. But even so, any one of Downton Abbey's characters are more compelling than him, unfortunately.

As a television period piece, Doctor Thorne isn't bad. If you're interested in 1850s English high society, the show is just decent enough to merit your time. But as a comparison to the brilliant writing and acting of Downton Abbey, the series is subpar.

We may have suspected from Fellowes's complex character treatments in Downton Abbey that he was a devotee of Trollope. This adaptation brings this affection to life in vivid terms. Every character is sweetly drawn, and they are given the benefit of the doubt. Trollope never wanted his novels to have too much suspense, indeed he would spoil his own story with an aside to the "dear reader" if he sensed that suspense was building. But he did want his novels to encourage empathy, which this television series replicates nicely.

This is a rollicking English comedy enjoyed by those of us who are having Downton Abbey withdrawal symptoms.  The typical 1850's stereotypes are rampart.  Handsome young men whose job is to seek out and marry an heiress or better yet an American who has wads of money to bail out the family estate that is about to go bankrupt.  And the daughters of these peers also have to find suitable (men with means) husbands.  Julian Fellowes introduces each episode and then wraps up the episode with his observations of society of the 1850's.  This is easy watching, lush country-sides, beautiful and elegant homes, beautiful people and extravagant costumes.  I couldn't help myself, I watched all 4 episodes in one sitting!

We just can't muster the same enthusiasm for Trollope that Fellowes expresses.  The characters are thin as paper; even silly, even for Victorian standards I would guess.  However, there is a beauty in the settings and historical ambiance that is trademark Fellowes engaging and masks so many flaws in the plots, characterizations, and even dialogue.  And, his arm chair chats with us are pretty fluffy and I just don't buy his sincerity at all.  I just know Hitchcock is somewhere throwing up at a 21st century rip at his schtick!

A somewhat predictable mid 1850's romance set in the English countryside.  Typical characters and plot.  Aristocrats being aristocrats.  Class divisions and snobbery.  'Good' families who have squandered their fortunes, scheming to improve them by marriage.  A good girl whose reputation is tarnished by illegitimacy. An American heiress.  A love triangle.  A rogue (or two), and of course, in the midst of all - the patient, reasonable, good Dr. Thorne.  Enjoyable short series.  The narration at the beginning and end of each episode by Julian Fellowes (of Downton Abbey fame) is charming.
Nicely produced period drama based on the book Doctor Thorne, written by Anthony Trollope.  The acting is excellent.  I would watch this again.

British drama and its humour at its best. Sort of like English cuisine, if you enjoy bangers and mash... you're a happy camper. Mustve been been a treat for Julian Fellowes to get his hands on a real Victorian novel, instead of churning out new eps of that pandering pastiche hes been working on for the last few seasons Solid Trollopian plot (wills and missing heirs and family secrets), great castIan McShane not exactly cast against type as a rough-diamond railroad tycoon; nice to see Alison Brie of Mad Men as the husband-hunting American heiress and Inspector Lewiss old boss as one of the snobbish gentlewomen. Stefanie Martini, who only has one other imdb credit, is perfect as the strong-willed heroine (so much more relatable than those soupy Dickens girls!); predictably, the picturesque exteriors and the dorky Mid-Victorian costumes and dcor are right on the money

Beautifully told story about love and the demands of society in what might be thought of as another explanatory backstory for Downton Abbey fans, though it certainly is more than that.  We didn't know what to expect, but Doctor Thorne turned out to be entertaining and satisfying as the optimistic and principled characters, Frank and Mary, chose their own paths through the expectations and conniving family troubles they faced.  Fun to see Julian Fellowes maybe channeling an inner Alistair Cooke, as he retells what he describes as a favorite work of his favorite novelist, Anthony Trollope.  It is hard for us to believe just how mercenary the marriage process became in Victorian England, but the mixture of Trollope's studied and well-crafted criticism and Fellowes' incredible visual storytelling really did give us historical insights (with possible application to our own money-driven culture), while we learned and laughed and commiserated. We were sorry there were only four episodes!

This was a masterful presentation of Trollop's work.  Julian Fellowes took good advantage of the time he was given to develop the characters over 4 episodes.  The acting was superb.  Doctor Thorn and Mary were given the best possible things to say but the actors had to deliver these lines with the right attitudes and body language which they did quite well.  Everyone sensible loves Mary, and you will too.  But the work is called Doctor Thorne for good reasons obvious throughout the story.

I enjoyed the fireside chats with Fellowes because we did not get to know him with Downton Abbey. I enjoyed his insights and passion about Anthony Trollope's work. Many of Trollope's books are free for Kindle, and I am always glad to find a new writer to enjoy. More of these would be fun -- bring these short series on!

Being a dedicated Trollopian, I considered giving "Dr. Thorne", the film, a four star for the way it drastically truncated and changed some of the critical details of the book. I love Anthony Trollope and was giddy when I saw Dr Thorne pop up in my feed. If you're not familiar with Trollope, this is a good place to start. I have to say that Julian Fellowes did an excellent job of bringing the novel to the small screen, and while it doesn't follow the written work completely, it was pretty close. I'm sure that some of the events were changed for time constraints, and the book certainly had more background info, especially regarding the clergy and the voting customs of the time, but this series did stay pretty true to the novel. Overall I was pleased, and blew through all of these in a long evening.

I really hope that JF makes more of Trollope's works into series like this one. Part of the glory of reading Trollope is that every book refers to characters from previous books until the stories are all intertwined. You really get to feel as if you live in his world, and Julian Fellowes does that well also. I would definitely watch any others he decides to do, and I highly recommend this one.

Filmed in and around stately piles in Wiltshire, Somerset, and Hertfordshire, DOCTOR THORNE convincingly recreates a world of rigid socio-economic divisions where everyone was supposed to know their place and accept it. This is the eternal conflict between money, power, and love that underpins the plot. Pauper Mary Thorne (Stefanie Martini) loves rich Frank Gresham (Harry Richardson), but their path towards true romance is perpetually blocked by Frank's avaricious mother Lady Arabella (Rebecca Front). we have the perfect recipe for a series of conflicts between characters of different generations and different socioeconomic groups. At the story's heart stands the eponymous Doctor Thorne (Tom Hollander), a basically goodhearted person with a penchant for protecting those less able to defend themselves against unwanted social criticism. The script is not without its humorous elements, especially in the comic opportunities given to Lady Arabella and her equally avaricious sister-in-law the Countess de Courcy (Phoebe Nicholls). Like a pair of aging dowagers they stride through the Gresham family seat, knocking everything and everyone aside in their attempts to break up Mary and Frank's affair. Oh what tangled webs we create when once we choose to deceive. I for one am so glad that we have our own individual free agency today to choose who we love and desire to marry.  You will find this film extremely watchable. So enjoy.  Rosemary Kerr.

Julian Fellowes introduces each episode and while his adm,iration for Trollope (who wrote the novel) is sincere and contagious, each episode could use with a re-write for clarity and brevity and character depth. There is an odd low budget quality to this short series. Pleanty of costumes, the typically good British sense of location, fine production values but the acting is off somehow - either too passionate or not enough or some other quality that is not easily identified. It feels as if we are watching second tier actors - unfair of me to say I know. Perhaps there was not enough rehearsal time, perhaps the script was more hindrance than help but sad to say this is no Downton Abbey and is a shade below Mr. Selfridge.

Pleasant enough to pass the time, but don't expect to be wowed. Hollander, Alsion Brie, and Ian McShane all do nice work, but most of the characters are boilerplate cliches. If you like this sort of thing, it's passable, but if you don't see the end coming a mile away by the end of the first episode, you need to read more. There are just too many better things that fall roughly into this category for me to recommend this strongly. "The Grand", "North & South", or classics like "Brideshead Revisited" or "Upstairs Downstairs" offer period costume drama of a much more unpredictable and engrossing variety. "Cranford" and "The Paradise" are also very good, as is "Mr. Selfridge." If you're looking for something to ease the loss of "Downton Abbey" this is just a snack cracker, not a full meal.

As a longtime reader of Anthony Trollope's books, I was pleasantly surprised to see that Amazon and Mr. Fellows had adapted one of his works for television. I have not been disappointed. The quality of the production and the actors is fine. A great deal of information is compressed into the first episode. Once past that, the plot develops at a reasonable pace in keeping with modern sensibilities. Great social satire is rare. Jane Austen, William Makepeace Thackeray and Charles Dickens are the few that stand out besides Trollope prior to the 20th century. In many ways, the Big Four have few peers in our modern era probably because the 20th century was one of the bloodiest in recorded history. This production allows the viewer a glimpse into a more ordered world with mores we may consider to be outdated but with social dynamics which have never gone out of fashion. That's the beauty of Trollope and the other great satirists; they describe behaviors that are universal to the human condition. The petty spite and malice, the shunning of persons not " belonging " to this or that clique or class and the like are universal to human societies everywhere. Don't kid yourselves: it's all still there, wearing different clothing and speaking a multitude of languages and it hasn't changed. That's why we can laugh at our Barchester Towers because it's Our Town.

This read like a romance novel, which I liked. The casting was great, acting good as well. I was left at the very end with a feeling of 'Huh?' as the story wrapped up so (supposedly) happily, with the building conflict being swept away with some very predictable and convenient happenings. I think it could have been stretched to 5 or 6 episodes with some great twists (maybe Mary has left the area for a whirlwind tour to escape her broken heart, maybe Frank has gotten himself betrothed tot he wealthy American who refuses to let him go, etc.).
And the silk flowers in the girl's hair looked very fake - were they supposed to appear as real flowers? Hmmm.... Mr. Fellowes did much more intriguing work with Downton Abbey.

I really enjoyed the first season of Doctor Thorne. The story line was very entertaining and humorous. It takes place during the mid 1800's in a village in Greshamsbury, England. It's an age old story of how love can be destroyed by money, power, and meddling family members. The acting was very good. Tom Hollander, who I first discovered in Pride and Prejudice,  does a fine job as the kind hearted Doctor Thorne. I  also enjoyed each recap that was given by Julian Fellowes at the end of each episode. My only complaint would be that the season ended too soon and I was left wanting more.

I loved this period piece story. They show the people, places, and times of this period in history. This story was another view (as compared to the many Dickens stories) of the 19th century England. I will definitely be watching for season 2.

Overall, I liked the episodes, and am grateful for almost any depiction of 19th century mores and costumes.  However, I found some of the dialogue and acting a bit flat.  For instance, I sensed merely warm regard, not an overwhelming passion between the young lovers -- notwithstanding the emotional restraint of the era.

Please don't take this as any indication that I will not watch a second season, however.  I fully expect that the series will get better!

I have to admit that while I viewed a few episodes of Julian Fellowes' Downton Abbey and thought them very well done, I was never roped into the high-class soap opera. But I enjoyed this four-part series of Dr. Thorne, based on Anthony Trollope's novel set in the same era as Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice. Julian Fellowes introduces and concludes each episode with a cozy fireside chat full of interesting observations. Mike Hale's review in the NYTimes [...] asserts that Julian Fellowes played up his best impression of Alistair Cooke, the British host of PBS Masterpiece Theatre from 1971 to 1992. However, Fellowes' presentations reminded me more of Sir Alfred Hitchcock hosting his TV programs. Listen to the music--the minor melody and use of bassoon often mimic the theme song of Alfred Hitchcock Presents. Just saying... maybe Mike Hale is too young to remember this?

It still has that "drop dead" beautiful cinematography of many British costume dramas, so visually fun.  A good show,anyway.

Our story as human beings is like a play that is played by different actors wearing different costumes depending on the period but whose story line is the same. The TV series "Doctor Thorne" which is an adaption from a novel, is just that. It is a snapshot of the England Victorian era. I remain convinced that had the original author of that novel come back to life in the beginning of the 21st century and had decided to rewrite that novel, he wouldn't have a lot to change to change in the story (perhaps show some computers on some desks and put some tablets and cell phones in the hands of the characters, better yet show the privileged ones driving in one of our modern luxury cars instead of showing them riding on horse's back and carriages pulled by horses).

Julian Fellowes had used his talent to bring to the screen a story forgotten by so many English historians, "the story of the customs and habits" of an era. It is not at all difficult to recognize any human being of any history period through the characters depicted in that story. Lady Arabella doesn't want to lose her life style as an aristocrat and therefore she couldn't care less about her own son's love for the penniless Mary. Lady Arabella want her son to "marry money". And she is helped in that endeavor (or should I write 'endeavour') by her sister. Sir Roger Scatcherd's son, Louis, had learned the hard way that this father's fortune can't buy him happiness and most importantly, penniless Mary's love. The main character, Doctor Thorne, strikes us as a balanced and rational being. He recognized the power of money but at the same time is not intimidated by it.

Doctor Thorne is also a story of human betrayals. Case in point: Lady Augusta Gresham (played by Gwyneth Keyworth), one of the two Lady Arabella's daughters, confided in Lady Alexandrina de Courcy (Kate O'flinn) that the family's lawyer, Gatsby, asked to marry her. Using the social stigma attached to any person at that time who made a living by 'working for others', Lady Alexandrina advised Augusta to reject Gatsby's marriage proposal. Turns to find out it was because Lady Alexandrina wanted  the lawyer for herself. The acting is superb, the photography breathtaking and the characters' costumes could not be more pleasing to the eyes. Every episode left the viewer asking for more.

 Doctor Thorne is not just the story of the english Victorian era, it is the timeless story of us in which everybody is in pursuit of money and the one who is lucky enough to put his or her hands on it will rule as king or...queen (in the case of Mary Thorne).

 To Julian Fellowes, I would like to say this: I am thirsty (already) for the next captivating (or should I say 'bewitching') story that you will bring on screen. Be honest with me, should I hold my breath?

This 4 episode series was fun to watch! I really hope the show continues!

Thanks to the success of Downtown Abbey, Julian Fellowes has been given carte blanche, with a limited production budget, to do what he wants next -- a tepid imitation of Alistar Crowley's Masterpiece Theater complete with red velvet armchair as Fellowes narrates intros and outros of gag-worthy episodes adapted from a story by Anthony Trollope. The writing is DULL, the characters predictable, the story hackneyed -- lacking any hint of irony or wit. And no, Trollope, prolific as he was, is not (to disagree with Fellowes) on par with Dickens or Jane Austin -- he's a poor man's version of both. Pretty dull stuff and the budget didn't include ace scriptwriters or directors who might have whipped the show into something worth watching. Fellowes as writer, producer, head cheese maker is old-fashioned and insipid -- he needs an executive producer who'll tell Fellowes to go hunting and leave the show to a team of clever writers and directors but it's hard to breathe life into a story that's DOA.

Although I had to adjust after 6 seasons of looking at the Downton Abbey estate and nearby village to looking at the various estates and the village in "Doctor Thorne", it was a quick and easy adjustment. The Brits write more tightly than the Americans; hence, this spry debut season is accomplished in just 4 episodes. I thoroughly enjoyed it, even though we, the viewers, know the truth about Mary Thorne rather early on and wait for how and when the news will be delivered to the others by the morally impeccable Dr. Thorne, who has the best sense of timing of any mini-series character ever! It was delightful to witness the characters maneuver the rules of society while knowing their places--to the good and to the bad--but for those who believe that love triumphs over money and power, "Doctor Thorne" will only reaffirm that belief. I wish that season 1 had been more than 4 episodes, simply because I am greedy for interesting drama with well cast actors. Now I wish that a season 2 could follow soon, very soon! For those viewers who love to see the rolling English countryside, the vast country estates, and the lives within, and who want a strong, well written plot line, "Doctor Thorne" more than delivers.

If you loved Trollop's book you'll probably be disappointed in this film adaptation. Fellowes made several changes to the story that take away from Trollop's intent, to discuss the growing obsolescence of the English peerage and the hypocrisy involved in the idea of marrying for wealth. I enjoyed Ian McShane's portrayal of Roger Scatcherd. I thought Tom Hollander and Stefanie Martini were well cast as Dr. Thorne and his niece, Mary. I liked Harry Richardson as Frank Gresham, but I thought he was a bit too conciliatory and eager to please. Mr. Moffat and Sir Louis Scatcherd were both completely miscast as was Squire Gresham. Lady Arabella, her daughters and sister were well-done although the rushed script forced Lady Arabella to look even more hypocritical and narcissistic than she should look. Cutting the election down to bare bones missed some of Trollop's best quips and most amusing moments. Eliminating Frank's horse whipping of Moffatt undermines the strength of Frank's convictions as Trollop wrote him. Making Sir Louis a menacing, dangerously arrogant drunk instead of an absurd, effete arrogant drunk did not improve the story at all for me and undermined Trollop's point about the ridiculous significance wealth plays in increasing status.

Doctor Thorne is a large full-length novel and could have been adapted into a complete and interesting season instead of four truncated episodes. It does not have the lush atmosphere and direction of Downton Abbey. The direction here is stagey, employing a lot of theatrical techniques that are both unnecessary and ineffective when used on film. McShane walking through town and being importuned by all and sundry is one of those moments. Another was the election debates, played as though on a divided stage.

Middle and upper class women (and men) of this era had little chance at a comfortable life if they did not enjoy ample unearned personal income or marry a wealthy spouse. Thus the hunt begins. But gradually I see the typical Austen plot becoming more subtle and interesting as we begin to view these increasingly complex characters through Trollope's less stylized eye. It's waxing more promising. Am glad I stayed with it and will know more after Episode 4.

If one turns the page on Downton Abbey and views it in the context of a Jane Austen novel, it's quite good! That sounds like faint praise, but some of the actors couldn't quite pull it off, in my opinion. In Downton Abbey, every single one of the actors became the character they played. The other issue with this new one, Mr. Fellowes, is that our American ears cannot catch all the dialogue when the accent is rather strong. Even running the sound high, I wasn't able to understand everything that was said.

I watched all episodes in two evenings, which was nice, though I did wonder if things "wrapped up" a bit too quickly at the end.

I watched all four episodes in one sitting, and found the acting, costumes, set design, and direction all top-notch, which is to be expected from studios who have mastered those arts.  The story was a sweet romance, if not exactly ground-breaking.  However, Julian Fellowes does little monologues at the beginning and end of each episode and, no matter how much he tried to insist that the characters were complex and multi-faceted, I had to respectfully disagree.  Perhaps in the original source material, which I have not read, but in this adaptation the "good" characters are readily apparent and the "bad" characters border on cartoonish.  But, hey...sometimes that's just what you want to watch on a lazy Sunday.  The only stand-out performances were those of Tom Hollander as Dr. Thorne, and the character of Louis Phillipe who, while definitely a "villain", was probably the most complex one in the whole series.

I was hopeful for this mini-series based on the trailer, but several things I found frustrating to the point that I don't know that I would watch another such Julian Fellows/Amazon mini-series unless they modified some things.
1. This must have been made on a pretty low budget. I know we're all spoiled with Masterpiece Theatre and BBC period dramas, but... Where were the extras? Many scenes felt sparse. The show definitely had a feel of being on a set.
2. The only strong character in my opinion was Dr. Thorne. Where did they get the rest of the actors/actresses? Out of theatre school? They came across very amateurish and unable to really grasp and portray the depth of their characters, especially Mary, who looked and acted very modern and had a strange way of expressing herself that made me wonder at times if she was an American doing a British English accent. She came across almost sickeningly sweet.
3. What was up with all the drone shots? They felt like drone shots. Maybe they strapped a cam to a Amazon Prime drone and delivered packages at the estates?
4.  The filters or post-processing done on the scenes with many of the women had too much of that "softened" effect. One camera would be sharply focused on a male and the next camera on the female is all fuzzy and "romantic" looking. Did not like that.
5. Strange camera angles on Julian Fellowes at times. Under his jaw? Odd. I think the intro would have been sufficient, but not two chats with Fellowes. His personality isn't particularly charming.
6. Wasn't sucked into this like Downton Abbey. Story/plot just to blase. And I LOVED Anthony Trollope's "The Way We Live Now" with David Suchet. That has a marvelous plot and fantastic acting. If you want a real flavor for a Trollope-set-to-film, try that one.
Lovely!

Nowhere near Downton Abbey in quality, but and easy viewing with a happy ending and
outstanding photography of English manor houses, castles, and landscapes

Well-acted as usual from the British, so it's always enjoyable from that point of view.  The story's not great but Julian can only adapt it,  not re-write Trollope's novel.  You'll enjoy this if you don't set your sights too high.  Austen it's not.

I am quite an Anglophyle and, while I did not like Doctor Thorne as well as, say, BBC's production of Pride & Prejudice, I did like it very much. The writing and performances (especially Tom Hollander) were excellent, as were the locations and costumes. This is from one of Trollope's novels I have not read, therefore I was unable to compare the series with the novel. All in all, I found the series very entertaining, and I binge watched it as soon as my husband left for the day so I could enjoy it uninterrupted. Bravo to Julian Fellowes (shades of Alistair Cooke) and bravo to Amazon for producing this fine series. Now, please do more in this vein.

The photography of the English countryside was the only high point of this otherwise uninspired drama. The arc of the storyline was tedious and predictable and the characters were implausible to the point of cariacature. The villain of the piece, who produced his little silver flask with the regularity of a mechanical wind-up toy, was the most egregious example, but they were all pretty silly. It's hard to believe that this dull production was created by Julian Fellowes.

I so love Julian Fellowes, and his beloved Downton Abbey that I felt, if only for a moment,  I could return to those memories it would be wonderful.
My mistake, Doctor Thorne is not, and, nor should it be, compared to Fellowes previous Masterpiece. As a short series, it is rich in scenery, costumes, and the mannerisms of the titled and the rich working class. Beyond that, I found nothing of great interest in either the plot or the acting - save a few. Tom Hollander as Dr. Thorne was a wonderfully sympathetic, and gentle man. Ian McShane as Sir Roger is the crotchety old man, who founds his soul before passing. My only complaint with him is that he wasn't on long enough. The younger cast members are all attractive and, do their best.
All in all it's viewable, but leave Downton in the past, where, sadly, it now belongs.

Wonderfully cast, excellent ending. How Julian Fellowes wrapped this up so neatly in four episodes is a marvel. Production is exquisite. You'll want much, much more of Dr. Thorne. His dance with the American heiress in the last episode leads you to wonder if there is romance in his future. The doctor's skill at treading the tightrope of secrets to the glorious end of this story is worth watching. His role is masterfully played.

This series based on a melodramatic story, and rendered in an overly sentimental style, with ridiculous circumstances and lucky coincidences, is topped by a swollen-headed and superficial narration by Julian Fellowes.

A few decent actors do their best to try and lend importance to this drivel, but its cartoonish, 1-dimensional characters seem like they came from a child's concept of how characters should be: a saintly and beautiful girl, a dashing and loyal suitor, an evil stepmother, kindly father figures, a drunken mess of a hateful villain, the villain's croney sidekick, and an old crone, etc, etc.  The "good" characters are not materialistic, and love and sacrifice truly.  The "bad" ones are selfish, grotesque, rude, and greedy.  There are no penetrating, multidimensional characters as Fellowes would like us to believe.  A person feeling a moment of regret does NOT a multi-dimensional character make - especially a last gasp at humanity on their deathbed -- talk about contrivances!

The "well-bred" and high born characters in the story behave like commoners, whereas the lower-birth doctor and his illegitimate "niece" are their superiors in both manners and grace?  Highly unlikely!  A titled son and heir-apparent of a large estate dating back many generations, then risks squandering every birthright for a chance at uniting with a "bastard" girl and a life with no prospects other than common work, such as trade or some other "lowly" job (the same work that we know has been despised by titled aristocracy since time immemorial), knowing that his family would also be turned out forever as a result? Again, improbable.  Improbable too that he would grow up to have a heart of gold and not care about any of the trappings of his day and age, and even go so far as to declare that he hates money.  Haha, you have to laugh.  It only works in Cinderella cartoons, outside of animation it just makes you laugh.

The actress in the lead role did her best, I can't fault her, nor the doctor.  Then we meet either these selfish women, or else look up to an angelic, faultless martyred female character.  The villain was so ridiculously portrayed, he might as well have twirled a mustache around his fingers as he spoke, drank and spewed (the expected) poisonous words endlessly.  The day is saved by a trite and forced Deus ex machina obvious plot device, which is actually revealed very early on and is alluded to throughout (as what will save the day).  Need I say more?! There's a reason why we've never heard of this author, because this novel, and I suspect much of his work, is feeble and wallops one over the head with its clunky, hackneyed devices and cardboard characters.  Then afterwards, Fellowes sounds like a fool summarizing each episode; I felt embarrassed for him.  Overall, a disaster!  Well, at least the costumes were interesting to examine, as well as the sets.

But I was SO incredibly disappointed with the quality of the hair and makeup and the costumes on this production! I've been spoiled by the golden touch the Brits seem to have when it comes to getting things historically accurate...it's surprising to see something with Julian Fellowes name on it be so sloppy. There were times when Stefanie Martini's hair was so horribly '21st century' I was apalled that they let that slide! No LADY of that time would have been seen outside of her bedchamber with such un-coiffed hair under her bonnet. After Julian Fellowes went to such crazy lengths to be historically accurate in every little detail with Downton Abby...why wouldn't he at least make sure they had a decent hairdresser on set?

Perhaps my expectations were too high but Dr. Thorne was a bust for me. The production values were glittery but other aspects were lacking or just wrong. Having Julian Fellowes do an Alistair Cook-type commentary between the episodes boded ill at the beginning but the biggest mistake was casting Tom Hollander as the virtuous Dr. Thorne. He is a wonderful actor but not in this role. Maybe I have seen him too often with that mischievous, up-to-no-good twinkle in his eye but it was impossible for me to buy him for a minute as the kindly, heart-of-gold doctor. Fellowes claim that Trollope is on par with Dickens and did he say Thackeray or Austen did not bear out in the story he chose to present. Predictable, pat and far too many coincidences. The actors did their best and performed abley given the material. The one exception would be the woman playing the part of the niece. She seemed out of her depth with little smiles at inappropriate times, just not the person to carry such a pivotal role. I truly wasn't expecting Downton Abbey but was sorely disappointed that anyone thought this would please that audience as a follow-up.

Julian Fellowes, the charmer Killwillie from Dalton Abbey, is the host introducing each episode of this new Series which he adapted from an 1858 book by Anthony Trollope.  The plot centers around a Mother who goes to great length to be sure her son will marry into wealth even though he has already fallen. for Mary who is anything but wealthy.  The plot has all the Victorian Elements, Secret family histories, finding your way into the upper classes, dressing the parts.  Julian Fellows presents Doctor Thorne is  entertaining and amusing.

As a genuine member of the English landed gentry, Fellowes is perfectly and articulately well qualified both to review and to critique its past periods of splendor and increasing decline. Who better these days, given his splendid "Downton Abbey" masterpiece? Yes, resoundingly another triumph, as he depicts the inevitable struggles of the over-staffed and over-spent rich, while the merit-driven middle-class increasingly make their presence felt. Great stuff!

I love English dramas. It's like being in England.  This is a rendition of one of the oldest novels ever. It's a kind of fairy tale where the good are rewarded and the misguided get their comeuppances.  Young people might need a disclaimer: the fairy tale may be true as metaphor but the kind of justice portrayed in this series may take a life time or they may never see it. For the young--don't count on your life being like this tale.  Few people rarely are the secret children of surprising parents and almost no one is as smart and good-looking and good as the protagonists.  We old ones enjoy the fantasy.

It was enjoyable but entirely predictable. In one aside from Julian Fellowes direct to the audience, Fellowes says that none of Trolloppe' characters are entirely good or entirely bad. If that's true, I found it to be a dimension poorly represented in this adaptation: Sir Louis, Lady Arabella, Alexandrina, & several others are completely one-dimensional; they could each be summed up with one strong adjective. It kept my attention, but I wouldn't bother watching it again. It has none of the twist & subtle plot points that Downton Abbey led me to expect of Fellowes. After looking forward to Dr. Thorne with interest, I'd say I'm moderately underwhelmed.

I feel like Julian Fellowes is a one-trick pony.  If you like that trick, here is yet another one. It's about people marrying for status and/or money in Victorian England. It took me forever to actually stay awake enough to get through the first episode. After falling asleep 2 or 3 nights in a row, I finally got through the whole thing by watching it during the day. Everybody does the best they can with familiar themes and material.  You can pretty much guess how it will all turn out from the first episode (if you can stay awake, that is.)  Particularly annoying is that Julian Fellowes taped little Masterpiece Theater type intros and outros for each episode.  He is no Laura Linney (or Alan Cumming!) that's for sure.  This feels like a bloated vanity project to me.  I'd rather watch the first season of Downton Abbey over again.  Just the first season, though. When things still seemed fresh and a little less formulaic than the series became.

Really enjoyed Season 1.  Will there be a Season 2?  That question was not answered.  If you loved Downton Abbey, you will love Doctor Thorne.  In Doctor Thorne another Mary is a central character.  This Mary is played to perfection by a delightful Stephanie Martini.  Her Mary is an absolute angel, but with a questionable birth.  She is Doctor Thorne's niece and thus part of the working class.  She loves Frank, part of the gentry upperclass, but he has parents who have squandered their financial position and his mother bans Mary from their estate in hopes Frank will marry someone with money.  Frank is hopelessly in love with Mary, but is still torn about helping his parents out of their financial mess.  Will Frank marry Mary or will he marry money?  The ending is a hoot, except for poor tipsy Louis.  You see, poor drunken, rich Louis is also in love with Mary, but Mary is not in love with Louis.  She loves Frank, but is convinced by Frank's conniving mother to drop Frank so he will be free to marry money.  Mary's uncle, wonderfully played by Tom Hollander, knows some secrets and plays a key roll in steering all players to the hoot of an ending.  Outstanding performances all around with a fun cast!

Julian Fellowes is a genius!  Doctor Thorne is a thoroughly enjoyable story.  Although not at all like Downton Abby in language and acting, I suspect that Fellowes tried to bring out the characteristics he found in the novel he adapted. The combination of familiar faces (from BBC productions) and new talent was perfectly done. I was in the middle of the first video when I realized that the adaptation was not being overacted, but simply following the style Fellows intended.
A great adaptation. Casting and scenery were perfect.
It was outstanding.
Very well written and performed.  Love the narrative given before and after by Julian Fellowes.
Excellent series.
I greatly enjoyed this story.  The actors were superb and 4 installments seemed just the right length for the series.  I hope Amazon will produce more series of this shorter length!
I enjoyed the series

True to his taste for all things Victorian, Julian Fellowes has again given us a wonderful screen work. Characters were fleshed out, costumes were gorgeous,the story line was luscious apparently true to the novel by Anthony Trollope. It was much shorter in length than most of Fellowe's dramas only, I believe, four episodes. The whole movie went by too fast. I loved every minute of it.
Loved it, was disappointed it didn't run longer than the 4 episodes.

Great!

It was fun. While the plot is relatively predictable, it has a feel-good resolution with virtue and forthrightness triumphing over greed.  Although this production is just the right length it would be fun to follow these characters through other adventures.
It was marvelous!  I'm looking forward to Season 2.

I'll follow Julian Fellowes anywhere.  The story had everything I love, gorgeous scenery, stunning, sweet heroine, wicked villain, breathtaking costumes, decent characters and a good storyline.  It helped a lot that Julian introduced each episode.  It helped me understand and appreciate the story and the storytelling so much more.  I watched Episode One about 9:00 one night and stayed up until 12:30 to watch all four episodes.  I couldn't stand to wait to find out what happened.  I'm not familiar with Anthony Trollope's writing, so it was wonderful to have it explained.  It's not Dickens or Austen.  I'm so happy I heard that Julian Fellowes had written another series.  It was a real find.
Very good dialogue.
I enjoyed it although I'm a sucker for period pieces. It was a bit predictable but all in all an enjoyable production.

This is by no means on par with Downton Abbey.  Having never read anything by Anthony Trollope, I can't say whether Fellowes banalized the story line or whether Trollope achieved this on his own.  There is very little sparkle to the plot whose resolution is telegraphed early in the series.  Nonetheless, the costumes and settings are handsome indeed.  And the British actors (none known previously by me) are uniformly good within the confines of the stilted dialogue and plot.  If you are already a Prime member, give it a look.  But I wouldn't join Prime for the chance to view this one.
Loved the doctor and the story.  Especially loved the format with Julian Fellows narrating the story.
Excelent

Fine adaptation of a work by one of England's finest novelists.  From Trollope's best series--the Barsetshire saga.  The only sour note was the arch-villain--who seemed a bit too disgusting for belief. Let's hope Fellowes will go on to do the author's even finer works in the series:  The Warden, Barchester Towers, and The Last Chronicle of Barset!  If you liked the TV series based on Trollope's The Duke's Children, from another of his sagas, you will probably like Doctor Thorne.

Julian Fellowes is a welcome narrator for all of us who miss Alistaire Cooke and I appreciate his enthusiam for Trollope's book.  I hope Fellowes will introduce many Masterpiece Theatre series in the future.  Trollope has his fans, but for me, Jane Austen is a much more insightful, honest story-teller.  Many of her heroines are complex, seemingly real people--they have their faults, which makes them appealing.  Trollope's heroine in this series is a bit too saccharine for my taste.  The plot was predictable, the good people were too good.  Maybe the bad people weren't all bad.  But that doesn't make this story truly compelling.

There's a vast supply of material, without having to turn to Trollope's lesser works, as Whit Stillman has done with Jane Austen's Love and Friendship (really Lady Susan).

I'm a big Trollope fan, and I also enjoyed "Downton Abbey" and "Gosford Park" so I was prepared to like this a lot.  However, even with a total run time of just under three hours for all episodes combined, the story seemed to me to be a bit rushed.  In the book Mary's exile from Greshamsbury Park was much more painful because of its long duration.  Also, the actress playing Mary (Stefani Martini) was just a bit too angelic.  Alison Brie is too young and too attractive to convincingly represent Mrs. Dunstable.  I liked Rebecca Front's interpretation of Lady Arabella Gresham.  I thought that the colors were too brilliant and that the presentation of the story was too upbeat--not all of Trollope's novels have happy endings (e.g., "The Small House at Allingham"), and those unfamiliar with "Dr. Thorne" might have enjoyed not having the ending implied by how the series was shot.

I remember being enthralled as a young girl with the dramatizations of Trollope's Palliser novels on Masterpiece Theatre.  It is truly a delight to watch this wonderful Dr. Thorne dramatization deploying some wonderful character actors that are familiar to many of us who have watched British cinema over recent decades.  Having Julian Fellowes preface each episode with a plot, character, and historical context overview is so very helpful to the viewer.  I studied British and Irish history in college and am a true Anglophile, but even I have learned so much by having Julian Fellowes set the stage before watching.  Trollope is an English genius, whose books transcend time and nationality.  He, like Shakespeare, understands human nature and motivations like so few can.  I just adore this program, and I hope Julian Fellowes will introduce the American viewing public to many more dramatizations of those iconic novels that form the backbone of his patrician background. To me, Dr. Thorne reminds me of my late  grandfather, a dedicated physician who worked in Pittsburgh during that city's industrial prominence.  He saw a lot of the human condition and treated everyone with respect, no matter the complexities and contradictions of their lives. He was a great doctor in the Dr. Thorne mold.  This show is just first rate, so please keep them coming. PS, Bosch is over-the-top wonderful too.

A delightful cast of characters, even when they are your Victorian heroines and heroes, or the dastardly drunks and those obsessed with money and English honor. The turn of fortunes and the manner in which Doctor Torne and his beautiful neice Mary face humiliation and eventual victory is a comedy in the true Trollopian vein. And yet, as Fellowes in his droll Hitccockian fashion reminds us, there are levels of deep humanity even in the worst of them...and by extension...us as well.

I've only watched 3 of the 4 episodes in Series 1, but am hooked. Like Downton Abbey, the poor British aristocrats must marry rich women to keep their life of luxury, but who is really poor? or rich? It's a Cinderella story (so far), with desperate royalty (the wicked witches) and kind hearted souls. Julian Fellowes, and his hero author Anthony Trollope, create a very different landscape than the upstairs/downstairs Highclere Castle, and I am enjoying!

Wow! A series that does not revolve around murders, wars, and other issues like these. This series is absolutely delightful, and I did not want it to end. Great writing and acting, and the story is about love and caring. I only hope that Amazon will have more productions like this made. We need these kinds of stories to give us hope that maybe, just maybe, such productions can be made available on streaming into American homes. I recommend it highly, and the maximum of five stars does not give this series justice! I will be watching this series more than once, guaranteed...

Julian Fellowes thinks he is Alfred Hitchcock in this presentation, making sure to tell us what was to come at the start of each segment and then telling us what we saw at the end.  This detracts from the viewing experience so you may wish to fast-forward past him, you will miss nothing!

If you enjoy British period pieces, then by all means partake!  Trollope's story exposes the hypocrisy of the era, the tail end of the feudal system giving way to kings of commerce rather than of birth.  It is unremarkable as a Dickensian plot with Dickensian characters carry out their assignments to the end.  It was a pastry rather than a meal.  Three stars.

Nice tidy little story, beautifully acted, with many light whiffs of possibly heading toward the tremendous scope of Downton Abbey's greatness -- but, alas, ends up having neither the poignancy of Fellow's great work, nor its intricacy.  Its a sweet little tale, well told a thousand times over, helped by Fellow's skilled hand but ending up, nontheless, no more memorable than any other moderately successful "boy meets (unacceptable) girl who eventually Triumphs Over All, and in the process, Forgives Meddling Soon-to-Be Inlaws, whom, we hope, Meddle No More In The Future".  Aaaaagh!  Hopefully Fellows will write something as powerful and meaningful as Downton Abbey soon again.  Meanwhile: Dr. Thorne is fairly endurable after Downton, but only hints at Fellow's tremendous skill.

I haven't finished the entire series yet, but what I've watched so far has been excellent.
1. The characters are rich and complex. I love the former Mr. Collins from Pride and Prejudice, as Dr. Thorne. He is lovable and warm, especially with his niece. Really the entire cast is excellent
2. I love the way the story is being revealed with juicy little secrets along the way. The story is interesting and exciting, but completely acceptable and appropriate content for me to watch with my teenage niece.
3. The costumes are well done and the scenery is beautiful.
4. I really enjoyed Julian Fellowes introduction and summary of the episodes. I never had heard of Anthony Trollope. It is nice to be introduced to a new author; now I can't wait to read his books.
5. Frank, is played by a handsome young fellow.

Good job Amazon...I am thrilled this is available to me as a Prime member. Keep them coming!

This is very much about the England we should know and not the one we feel we must be fed with in our American world of sufficient crises and daily newsfeed. Life paced differently is generally bland in our modern view. Earlier generations felt the depth of this mellow pace. It is for this reason that I treasure Jane Austen and Elizabeth Cleghorn Gaskell equally as much as Lee Child and Jo Knowles.

Oh this was simply a most beautiful movie!  I loved the actors, the shots, though the exterior establishing shots did get a little annoying because I did wish they could come up with a better way of introducing us to the different locations, but then again those are often neglected during post-production as they try to turn out the film in it's entirety!  :) Oh indeed this was quite a splendid film, as film it must be only being around 3 hours in length!  :)

This was exciting,  riveting, happy,  sad and on the edge of your seat series.  The characters were believable, the costumes very well done and the scenery was breath taking. Julian Fellowes has done it again. I'm excited to see what he will write next.

I was delighted to hear of another Julian Fellowes production so soon on the heels of the beloved Downton Abbey series. Trollope is not an author I have had time to read, but based on Fellowes' warm recommendation, I downloaded the novel simultaneously with starting to watch this mini-series. The 4-part series, though entertaining and beautiful to behold, feels like the Cliff's a notes version of Trollope's lush novel. So much is left out or condensed that it all feels a bit rushed. I stretched the series out over a 6 day period, but have read only ~40% of the novel during that same time. So much of the novel is omitted, that the video series feels like a weak imitation. However, rarely do I find a screenplay adaptation of a novel to be as engaging and entertaining as the written word.

Nevertheless, if you enjoy British period pieces, and you don't intend to ever read the novel, this one will not disappoint. The castles are gorgeous, the countryside magnificent, and the costumes impressive. The plot is the predictable, oft-repeated struggle of the upper classes to retain their wealth at the expense of marrying for love. It is always of utmost importance to marry into one's own class, and failing that, to "marry money". So we know from the outset that the young master will have to marry well to right the sinking fortunes of the Greshams...we just don't know who the lucky lady will be!
I couldn't stop after the first episode and watched them all back to back!!!
Poorly written and boring. Not at all entertaining. And I  love period pieces, but this story just dragged.
Delightful period drama.  Great acting, fantastic costumes, horses and carriages, intrigue.  Enjoyable to watch.  Recommended if  you like English drama.
Lovely light way to spend an evening. A complicated love story. Many threads that come untangled in the end. English drama which I love. Photography, acting and scenery is stunning.
Great scenes, costumes, and actors. Would definitely recommend any one to watch it.

While this sort of show typically does not entice me it is exactly the opposite for my wife. I will admit that I was probably as or more eager for each episode to start. I have posted this hoping my wife nor anyone else I know will ever know my true identity. I have not watched a lot of the shows many others have referenced in their reviews, but I enjoyed the show. It reminded me of cross between an old western, a soap opera, and keeping up appearances. Is this thing still anonymous?
I really enjoyed this show. It was a funny, quirky love story.
I don't know which was worse, Jillian Fellows impersonation of Alfred Hitchock, the costumes or the shallow story line.  This can't hold a match stick to Dowton Abby

It's not Downton Abbey, but then what can compare.  Could've done without the opening and closing remarks by Fellows in the last three episodes, the story wasn't as complicated as he made it out to be, and the audience should be allowed to make their own character evaluations.
Doctor Thorne is wonderful! It has a very different feel than Downton Abbey but is one that can stand on it's own. Beautifully done!
There's wayy too many white people in this show. No flavor, and the writing's dull

We thoroughly enjoyed Doctor Thorne for a date-night-in binge watch costume drama. There's so much available entertainment that that is dark, angst ridden, and disturbing - this is not that kind of series.  It was clean, light and entertaining.  Although it is not completely without some thought-provoking themes.  Does our culture value goodness and innocence enough?  Doctor Thorne does a great job in exploring some Victorian attitudes, both positive and negative.  The introductions and conclusions by Julian Fellowes reminded my husband of Alfred Hitchcock, and they were, indeed, a bit campy but we loved that about the show and thought it added to the charm.  All in all it was a refreshing, but updated, throwback to some good vintage television and we wish they would do more - how about some Wilkie Collins?

This is totally clean to watch with the whole family.  English Lit teachers looking to take up some of that end of the year downtime in the classroom might consider this one.

If you're a Jane Austen fan, then you'll enjoy this adaptation of an Anthony Trollope novel. The characters actually follow a more understandable motivation than many of Miss Austen's characters. Some are more well rounded than others, but that may be a product of the adaptation rather than the underlying novel. What I do really appreciate about Julian Fellowes' adaptation is that he kept the pace moving without it feeling rushed. Coming in at around 3 hours total, the show is what I would describe as a the perfect length. The sets, scenes, and costuming are beautiful, as to be expected.

If you're fan of  Ian McShane (Deadwood), you'll love his role in this. He plays one of the main supporting roles, and actually has one of the most interesting backstories and one of the most in depth character developments.

While some have objected, I enjoyed the episode breaks with Julian Fellowes providing commentary. It reminded me of the old Materpiece Theatre.
Very entertaining!
More please!
I really enjoyed it.
Enjoyed it very much
Loved it! Light, happy, endearing...please do more, Julian Fellowes!!!

I must say that I enjoy period dramas immensely. To me they're often pastoral and as pleasing as a lovely painting. The Story is a bit predictable, but well executed and worth the view. I like Juian Fellowes, and Tom Hollander is quite good in this role.

This is a sweet tale set in the splendor and prejudice of an age gone by. It was an enjoyable evening's viewing. Julian Fellowe's adaptation of this novel is Downton Abbey Light. The casting was fabulous, as well as the scenery and costumes. Definitely not memorable but well worth the watch..

This short series is not only well done, but a lot of fun and it's obvious that all of the makers (writer, producers, actors, director) were having fun as well.  If you liked "Cold Comfort Farm" you will love "Dr. Thorne."

The show is quite good but at times very slow. The commentary before and after is very annoying however. If you get quite tired of very quickly, and frankly so much of it is either obvious or, if you are paying attention, a spoiler.

Found it quite enjoyable!  Finished it in 2 days! Yes, a bit predictable but I like a short and sweet ending. Loved the actors, costumes, scenery and storyline. I've got to get my fix in of this time period since Downton is over. It's no Downton but it will do very well. Again, quite enjoyable!

Within the first half hour, you can guess the whole story pretty easily.  The audience knows too much from the outset for there to any real drama.  There's a comic strain to show with some overacting, possibly done purposefully, but it makes it hard to take any of the characters seriously.  The show has a rather retro-feel, with it's gold old-timey font and Julian Fellows introducing and concluding each episode with an air of academic analysis (even though the story is very easy to follow and the emotions of the characters are obvious. It's like some kind of simplified Masterpiece Theater - maybe the Brits working on this show felt like they had to dumb it down for the American audience?).  Too neat and feel-good for my taste, Beautiful costumes, scenery, and people make the show tolerable.
FIIIVE

While I found the plot very predictable, that doesn't mean it wasn't a lot of fun to watch. Ian McShane and Tom Hollander were both a lot of fun to watch, as they always are. The little dramas and rivalries of the characters were highly entertaining. My biggest problem was with Fellowes insistence on telling the ignorant viewer what was to happen, and then reinforcing what did. It wasn't a terribly complicated story and didn't need to be bookended by his pretentiousness. It would be a better story without him.

An enjoyable (and pretty predictable) love story in the style of Jane Austen.

Enjoyable adaptation. Hope to see more of Anthony Trollope's works on Amazon. My husband (English major) introduced me to Anthony Trollope years ago. Would love to see more of the Barsetshire or Palliser novels. The costumes and scenery were wonderful. It is so good to see classic literature  available in movie format. Makes me want to reread the novels. Thanks Amazon.

This adaptation does nothing to improve one of Trollope's blander and more predictable novels.  Everyone is played as a pattern copybook character, and you can only pity the actors, who have to contend with tawdry direction on top of an airless script.  (Though they do seem to bring their own woodenness to their roles.) The best character in the book, Miss Dunstable, is completely eviscerated, changing from a plain outspoken "middle-aged" spinster (by Victorian standards) to a pretty American that plenty of men would be attracted to. And just to make it even more stultifying, the producer lectures us at the beginning and the end of each episode to reiterate what each episode makes abundantly obvious. There are so many better Trollope novels that have more complex characters and plots.
The series was amazing!  Our family loved it better than any Jane Austin's book adaptions.  Trollope's books have finally been adapted!!!!
True, it is predictable, but it was still lovely to watch.

It was a fairly predictable love story, but that isn't always a negative for me. It is definitely a feel good movie with love triumphing in the end; however, they worked so hard on fitting everything in the four episode that you can't really get into the characters. It came off feeling a little insubstanial.
The plot was fairly predictable, but I enjoyed it anyway. If you like period dramas there's a good chance you'll like this one too.

I concur with the one-star and two-star reviewers - this is telenovella-type pablum with one dimensional characters dropping leaden dialogue as they trudge towards the most predictable ending possible. Was the novel by Anthony Trollope really this bad? If so, then Barbara Cartland was Anthony Trollope in a former life.
I thoroughly enjoyed it. I would recommend it to any Victorian era fan.

This was a wonderful period piece. I wanted to give it five stars for the wonderful acting and beautiful costumes but alas the writing forced me to score this one a four. Even with the very companionable Julian Fellowes leading and ending each episode with commentary on the plot and characters it was easy to predict how this would turn out. Still ,all in all,I would highly recommend this drama for all those suffering from Downton Abby withdrawal. If I might add a aside ,I hope all the production people who green light Prime original content get a nice bonus this year. Compared with the awful treacle Netflix is producing ( aside from a couple of outstanding shows )Prime time original programming with it`s great production values is far ahead of the competition in quality and content......well done !

I did not have high expectations after reading the reviews...I loved it though.  It isn't Jane Austen, but it is fun with likeable (and disagreeable) characters, beautiful scenery/settings/costumes...I recommend it!
Love Historical Dramas, it was not too dark like one of the Bronte sisters.  Witty, dainty, love Tom Hollander.

Enjoyable as is all of Julian Fellowe's work. Could have done without Fellowe's rather long, rambling, slightly condescending intro and recap. While not the caliber of DA it was light, entertaining with great costumes -super location with gorgeous scenery. More please. We are starved for decent programming in the US.
Wonderful, well written and acted, luxuriously filmed. Stayed up too late bingeing it.
I really enjoyed this miniseries.  It doesn't have as much drama/things going on, as some have pointed out, but that is actually a nice relief from the routine.
In an age of nothing but fast-paced action-packed and sometimes outright stressful television, it's a relief to find jewels like this one. The writing is fantastic and the scenery is gorgeous.
If you like Downton Abbey, you'll like this.  It was a great historical drama set in the 1850's.  The story l had moments of laughter and drama.  I hope they continue as a series!

Add this to your watchlist NOW!
As wonderful as it is to watch the first time, I am enjoying it even more the second time. I found the relationships between parties difficult to decipher the first go-around because I was so spellbound by the story, but now with the second viewing, I am enjoying the acting even more!

Tom Hollander and Ian McShane (and some free time) are the only reason I even bothered watching beyond the first episode. I am really trying to understand the 4 and 5 star ratings. There was nothing special or even remotely inspired about this mini-series. To be honest, the trailer was more entertaining.

My suggestion would be to read the actual book and/or listen to the audio book.

I love Trollope and this book as much or more than Fellowes does, so I was really looking forward to this. On the other hand, I quit Downton Abbey mid-way through season 2, so I had concerns about what he would do with this book. And what he has done is to so Fellowes-ize it that almost all of the charm of the novel is lost. Everything is stated with such sledge-hammer obviousness, that it's almost painful. Unfortunately, good actors are in the position of having to say these lines. Alison Brie is Miss Dunstable, an actress I enjoy playing a character I love. The character is intelligent, practical, and humorous. So why does she come off as arch  and artificial in her opening scenes? I suspect she was directed that way. I really like Tom Hollander but he is given nothing to do here but look concerned.

Phenomenal show!  Very clean, family friendly show.  Some topics may not be suited for younger viewers (infidelity, born out-of-wedlock), but so well done, it draws you in and you don't want to stop watching.  The actor who plays Dr. Thorne is superb!

Doctor Thorne should be marketed for young people! Make no mistake, Doctor Thorne is not Downtown Abbey. But it doesn't have to be! I've watched 3 episides so far but the The "PG-14" warning" has made me laugh. There's been no real violence. Unrequited love and longing, certainly, and some posturing, but mostly just fun characters, costumes, and an easy to follow story line. Julian Fellowes' introduces and then and "debriefs" to help us Americans. For adult watchers, its silly and fun. For girls, it could be more than that. If your daughter doesn't get why you like Downtown Abbey, try Doctor Thorne!

Amazon Studios and Julian Fellowes have provided such a treat to those of us who can not get enough of the adaptations of classical novels that have been so well done by Masterpiece Theatre.

Not only is the casting superb but the costuming and settings combine to make this drama a visual feast.  Anthony Trollopes novel focuses on relationships in class conscious Victorian England.  The actors bring the characters to life and are a joy to watch.

Julian Fellowes introduces each episode as well as offering a short commentary after each concludes.  It is reminiscent of Alistair Cookes role of host on Masterpiece Theatre.

I loved this adaptation and hope that Amazon Studios will join forces with Julian Fellowes to provide more of this type of quality viewing.
As good as Downton! Only negative is it had to end so quickly. I just hope Mr. Fellowes just keeps rolling and follows up with many more.
I didn't think that I would be too crazy about this show but I decided to give it a go. I LOVE THIS SHOW!!! It is wholesome and the storyline is full of color. I definitely recommend this!

Truly delightful.  Took me a while to warm to the characters and the light approach in the first episode, but once over that the series became a good candidate for binge watching.  Expect beautiful English estates and villages, fine acting, and, of course, some predictable plot turns.  But who would want it any other way?  We can only hope that Amazon has already contracted with Julian Fellowes to produce more of Anthony Trollope's stories.  I'll be watching, if they have!
Loved it.  So nice to be able to finish it in one evening.  A great love story, a bit predictable, but pshaw.  Beautiful sets.

Julian Fellowes' name carries so much weight and this was so light-weight.
He gave us such depth in Downton Abbey and this is shallow.
This was a huge disappointment.  Fluff indeed.
Enjoyed it thoroughly,Delightful production. I hope Julian Fellows gives us more.

Cinematography reduced the actors to talking heads.  Goofy music turns the whole series into Regency camp.  Last of all, the blocking for the scenes indicated a sense of urgency that left the characters looking cold and distant, as if they had met the same day of filming.  Didn't really enjoy the "modern" rewrites, either, though the actors did what they could with the script they were given (only one or two glaring weaknesses in the cast, and they were all peripheral cast members).

I've enjoyed the Barchester series (with the help of free Kindle downloads), and one of the great virtues of the novels is what Trollope can communicate when his characters aren't speaking.  But Amazon seems to have rushed the production of this iteration, and has sadly reduced Barchester and its inhabitants to a vapid, 2-dimensional cartoon.  Maybe some people prefer that style (and are not shy about approving of it, if the Amazon reviews are any indication), but for the fans of the novels, this version of Trollope's work falls pretty far below an acceptable standard.

Delightful!

Light-hearted, witty, and slightly sarcastic in the British-style.

Beautiful settings and costumes, with a great cast.

Julian Fellows' fireside introductions are reminiscent of Alastair Cooke's Masterpiece Theater introductions.

Makes me want to go back and reread Trollope (after ?30+ years!!!). :-)
Predictable and not complicated story. Loved Downton Abbey, but this is a weak effort by Fellowes (or perhaps the author).

This is an OK english country-manor costume drama. However I thought the intro/extro by writer Julian Fellowes were too "precious". I got the subliminal message that this was created just to engage the fanatic Downon Abbey fans. Sort of "kitsch" in my opinion.
