But i did really enjoy the performances of Tom Hollander and Ian McShane. Especially McShane. A relatively small part, but he made the most of it!

This reminded me why I love Jane Austen so much, even though it wasn't an Austen story. I love the simplicity and innocent messages. It also reminds me that people have always been people. I appreciate stories that almost move beyond the times and expose the ridiculous and sometimes cruel in human behavior. The conventions have changed, and the world may seem more free but the truth is that you will find superior, snobbish people everywhere, quiet people, broken people, etc.
Stories like this, even if not considered very original, are important because so many of us live the same lives. The manners and social graces may have changed, but we all face times when we have to choose between ideals and practical "real-life" concerns. This movie is enjoyable, and I couldn't help but relate to a few of the characters.
I really enjoyed this series and i recommend it to anyone who likes historical drama.
Very very good. Nice to watch a lovely normal love story. Very entertaining!

I see some people saying it was boring, actors weren't good, etc. I think this was a fantastic production and I felt very involved in the somewhat predictable, yet very satisfying story. I'm a 'happy ending' type of guy so it worked very well for me. If you're a fan of Victoria England shows/stories, I'm sure you will enjoy this short production.

Absolutely marvelous!!
I watched the entire series of Downton Abbey and when I got win of this new Julian Fellows Drama, I just couldn't resist.  I watched all 4 episodes in one day and fell in love with his writing all over again.  Its romantic, scandalous and beautiful.  I love love loved it! If you loved Downton Abbey, You will love this as well!
I enjoyed it. Good, clean storytelling.
we loved it.

Horrible, horrible: story, acting, actors chemistry, etc. Half a star at best. Such a predictable story, the ending is basically fed to you from the first episode.  The Mary's character is so stuck up and somewhat brazen, she warrants no compassion and does not deserve the audience rooting for her whatsoever. After the third episode, I found myself wanting something really really bad to happen to her, maybe like murder, just to save the story. Ugh, and to think I bought 4 tubs of Haagen Daaz for that drivel. And what the hell where those briefings??!!  I think maybe Julian Fellows is a one hit wonder.  Amazon, up your game, you are no Netflix just yet.

That was fun, even if Trollope might be a tad too pollyanish for us moderns, even for those of us who appreciate the Burkean world-view implicit in Downton Abbey, where the "great divide" is ameliorated by the awareness both upstairs and downstairs possess of belonging to their own little platoon.  (As was ready to view, in contrast to how the treatment of servants in Doctor Thorne accorded to the historical norm.)  Julian Fellowes is fine and elegant in his presentation of the world he graciously has revived for us.  Only one thing was missing--well, almost; there was a good instance (I'll let you guess where it occurred)--and that was the catalogue of zingers that only the Dowager Countess of Grantham can, like the ships Homer set against Troy, launch.  But then, perhaps only when collaborating with Maggie Smith is Julian's writing so inspired.  Might he someday disclose that she was his muse?
Excellent period piece and I really liked Julian Fellows introductions and summaries as well.  Highly recommended,  streaming at its best!
Terrible, and the producer at the beginning and at the end was so contrite, wanna-be-alister cook disaster
I do enjoy period dramas.  Thoroughly enjoyable entertainment.  This series gave me good reason to read Mr. Trollope's other books.
I loved this show ! I want more please . The plots are so awesome I want to watch what is going to happen next !

I can't believe this mediocre little tale was too much of a ratings competition for Indian Summers. This is a simple story. Too simple. To the point that you figure out what the ending is going to be in ten minutes. And, that is exactly where it goes, without any kind of finesse. Think Harlequin novels minus the sex and intrigue. Pretty people in pretty costumes with a ridiculously condescending introduction and end speech by the creator of Downton Abbey.
does Fellows blubber on in every episode?
Huge fan of the Victorian era pieces over the past few years. While the plot never seemed to be in doubt the direction and performances kept the interest. Well done all around.
Absolutely loved it!
Loved it!
Fantastic! As much as I love the epic and long series, it is such a nice reprieve to have a properly executed mini-series. Well-done, Amazon!
d
Loved it!

Not as rich or exciting as Downton Abbey. Not as compelling as Poldark. Not as deliciously light and decadent as The Paradise. However, I am a fan of Tom Hollander and Ian McShane, two fine actors and there is some other fine acting among the other performers here as well. There is a richness of story, but fans of such great British writers as Dickens, Forester, Waugh, et al, know this content well and will find this series predictable. The adaptation by Fellowes is credible, I suppose, but Fellowes' presence and commentary pre and post episode is cheesy, unnecessary and smacks of trying to wrest or cash-in on the Masterpiece Theater imprimatur from PBS, of which this production is neither Masterpiece nor PBS. Nonetheless, I am thrilled Amazon is financing such productions and content from such fine writers, keep it up, but don't push it.
Excellent romance
I loved this!  Perfect for those in Downtown Abbey withdrawals.  The ONLY downside of this is that it's only 4 episodes!!!
Loved it! Give us more!!!!!
I absolutely loved this.  I watched it all in one sitting and thought it was wonderful!  Julian Fellowes is such a good story teller.

so incredibly boring. none of the actors are very good, none of them have any chemistry. the script is so boring, no cleverness or quick wits in this group. julian fellowes got it right once in his long, boring career, just like a broken clock. i hope amazon doesn't give him any further chances to bore me to death.

I'm not as exacting as some of the reviews I've read. I enjoyed this all-too-short series and will be hoping Fellowes has more up his sleeve. I'd like to see how he handled Dickens--David Copperfield, for example. Attention to detail and excellent acting helped overcome any Victorian predictability in the plot.

I watched the 4 episodes entranced as I truly like Anthony Trollope and this production did not let down. The costumes, set, actors, dialogue and intrigue over money was done impeccably. I enjoyed Fellowes presentation, I liked the characters and period. In short I recommend it to anyone who likes period drama in the same vein as say Jane Austen to name one.
It is well worth your time and I hope that there are more adaptations for the screen.

Well done
Enjoyed this short series by Julian Fellowes. Kudos Julian, well done!

I am enjoying Dr. Throne...Julian's intros and recaps are Hitchcockesque, which I think is amusing. The costumes are wonderful, the acting is good, so far. I like the lead actor, who was in Pride & Prejudice 2005 and I think the story is intriguing. The characters are still developing so, again I will say: "So far." This story is set in the mid Nineteenth Century and therefore, not like Downton Abbey but it is quality work. We shall see as the series unfolds.

I am very impressed with this Amazon production.  The acting is outstanding and we enjoyed it immensely!  Also, forgive me, but I cannot help but snicker at some of the petty, negative reviews, particularly those that suggest that the introductions by Julian Fellowes are somehow ridiculous.  On the contrary, these are obviously and deliberately intended to evoke those of Alistair Cooke and Masterpiece Theater and, as such, are great fun and very well done!  Bravo, Mr. Fellowes and Amazon, and please keep productions in this genre coming!
It was predictable, but fun to watch. I can't get enough of this time period!
Awesome!!!  I loved every minute of it!

A fantastic period piece. Julian Fellows has thrilled us again with a fine adaptation of another British novel.  Brilliantly acted, well directed, and set in a gorgeous part of Britain, Dr. Thorne is sure to delight anyone who likes a well-done drama/romance.
Outstanding presentation. I could not stop watching it to the end.
I absolutely loved this story!  Stay with it and you will too!!  It is like reading a superb novel.....one in which is in your hands.
This was a great movie. The streaming was great on my laptop! Enjoyed this very much
Delightful!
I want more.... I loved the fairy-tale ending!
What a wonderful movie!

As a Downton Abbey fan, I was thrilled to see Julian Fellowes' Dr. Thorne was coming. I just watched all four episodes. It is as exhilarating and beautifully filmed as I would have hoped. Great characters and acting. Thank you Mr. Fellowes and Amazon for bringing this art to us.

I hope they make a second season! Love the way Julian Fellowes narrates at the beginning and end of the episode giving background on the story and Trollope; he reminded me of Alistair Cook and Masterpiece Theater. Loved the entire production. More, please!
This series was thoroughly enjoyable!  It definitely leaves the viewer wanting more...Perhaps a season 2? If you enjoy period movies, this is the show for you!

three stars translates to: it's ok and it really is just ok. Julian Fellowes must realize our expectations are higher thanks to his other creations.  think of this a a cute simple stop gap as you wait for masterpiece theater. heads up Julian Fellowes does an intro to every episode.

A nicely done period piece to while away an afternoon. Fellowes always does an excellent job and this did not disappoint. There was plenty of characters to like and to hate and a big moment at the end that had me laughing out loud.
Excellent in every aspect - worthy to be ranked with the best.

Lovely scenery, and in an uncharacteristic sunny summer in England.  Several mainstay British actors, but a nice cast of more unknowns who helped a bit.  Nice acting as well.  Unfortunately, by the end of episode 1, the formulaic "British Period Piece" was under way, which I found disappointing.  Don't get me wrong, it's one of my favorite genres, however this really brought nothing new to the table.  Unless you are considering the part that Mr. Fellowes played, and I'm not certain that really was a contribution.  While espousing the writing prowess of the original author was quite nice, he was otherwise telling us what we were going to see, or what we had just seen.  It was in a bit of an over-the-top way, and I'm capable of figuring out what I've just seen.  Even Alistair Cooke never rambled on so much.  Sorry Amazon, this just was nothing new, and did disappoint.  It was lovely scenery though

I enjoyed watching this, however as with most, the books are far superior.
I'd recommend reading any of Anthony Trollope books.  I read everyone of his books on my Kindle and most of them were free.
Julian Fellowes before and after appearances were a bit Hitchcock-ish I thought.
Really worth the time!
This was a great mini-series.  I hope Amazon brings us more like this.

Say what you will, flat characters, cross between P&P or Cranford (I've been to Lacock and recognize the route to the old horse stables).  This is light, airy, and a reasonable adaptation of novels of the time.  If you're looking for a Britsh costume drama that's easy to deal with, this is it.  The good news is that all the Trollope books are exempt from copyright, so the entire series is free (or mostly free) in the Kindle store.

It was wonderful.  I was excited to see another film by Julian Fellowes & this one was a total triumph.  I was following his work long before Downton Abbey & loved him as Kilwillie in Monarch of the Glen.  His hosting the show at the beginning & ending of the episodes added a lot to the overall experience. All the actors were perfect for their parts & the scenery was jaw dropping for this SoCal girl.  Can't wait for Fellowes to come up with his next effort.
Simply amazing!!!

This was a total disappointment. I actually watched 2 episodes with no fast forward and skipped my way through the 3rd. It was only then I realized there were only to be 4 episodes..
 but at that point I had no interest left in coming to the end of the story. Julian Fellowed little chats at the beginning and end of each episode were ridiculous. They shone no light on Trollop or his characters or the value of the story. I guess that most people who viewed this had never read the author's works but indeed my stint as an English major lead to having to read much of his work and I loved it! I wasn't looking for a Downton Abbey experience..just something delightful, heartfelt, embedded in the history of mid- 19th Century and was disappointed on all those fronts and more.
I love it!  Great Entertainment and such top notch actors!  Thank you Julian Fellowes and Amazon.  Hope to see more in the future!
Series ended too soon.
completely enjoyed season 1!
I couldn't stop watching, even though the ending was as predictable as ever, I loved every minute of it and couldn't help but cheer the ending! How marvelous!
Great cast. Mediocre story telling. Could barely finish the series. A far cry from the compelling story line of Downtown Abbey.

Well... I definitely watched these pretty quickly. Did I feel like they were a downtown Abbey replacement? No, not so much.
The story is a good one. I have read and re-read the Austin and other similar works very frequently, and I think I'll give this series a go.
Why was this disappointing? Well, first off, I find the explanations done by Julian fellows both before and after each episode slightly insulting. I'm intelligent enough to understand what's going on without his needing to explain it to me....EVERY TIME. Also,I think it might have been helpful if it were presented on a weekly basis. However, presenting it in an on demand format with binge watching easily available just seemed insulting.
Ok, once I got through that... generally I knew how the series was going to turn out before the end of the first episode. Ok, that's kind of a given for these novels. The issue for me was there were no charming twists that make you think even for a moment that things aren't going to turn out just right. And while one of the characters gets his just desserts, no one else really does.
 Ok, if the two issues above didn't knock it down two stars, here's the thing that did it for me... the characters ended up being caricatures rather than real people to me. I just didn't feel like Julian Fellowes brought his A game. I think the directing could have been better since so much if it felt very overacted in a bad way without the depth needed to pull it off.  Also, I'm in full agreement that some of the casting could have been better. I am not sure if Mary was described as blonde, but most of the best beauties of that period were darker. I also think many of the characters ended up looking very strange, especially the families, when they all stood side by side, it was sort of horrible no thought was given to the fact they didn't look like each other a jolt.
Anyhow, if you don't have anything else to do, give it a shot. It is enjoyable, but not downton quality.

Found Julian Fellowes' adaptation of Doctor Thorne quite enjoyable, but as someone who has read Dr Thorne twice, I was a bit taken aback by how quickly the plot moved along.  What took Trollope 400+ pages was managed efficiently in four episodes.  It was certainly more 'modern,' also, with Fellowes eschewing the sometimes painful Victorian reluctance to speak straight and having characters just saying what was going on, and who was who, without the hemming and hawing about 'indelicate' matters.  Probably all for the best, and certainly more likely to appeal to today's viewers.  Any chance there will be a season 2?  Doc Thorne and Miss Dunstable, converted to an American (I wonder why? to make her straight speaking more acceptable to the snooty Brits?), have a bit of a story to follow, too.  In fact, why doesn't Fellowes adapt all the Barsetshire novels, condensed the same way? Not to mention the Palliser series.  I love Trollope, too, and would avidly watch them all, on steroids or not.

I thoroughly enjoyed the four episodes of Dr. Thorne, and the discussions with Mr. Fellowes. Part of the charm for me is the beautiful scenery, the lovely outfits and the English language as spoken by the Brits. Of course this is no Downton Abbey which I adored, but how could it be in four episodes. Keep it up Mr Fellows and Amazon. Give us more!

I thought it was so Great. am sad that it had to end.
I am encouraged to read the writing of Anthony Trollope

So charming! I watched the whole season this weekend and it was such a nice escape. Beautiful costumes and settings, fine performances ( I especially loved the excellent Tom Hollander as the good doctor himself). Hope they'll continue the series with the other novels.
Anyone who enjoyed the classic BBC series "Pride and Prejudice" will enjoy "Dr. Thorne" as well :)
Wonderful period piece.  The costumes and sets were amazing and the characters relatable.
This show is very good. The acting is impeccable! The story is predictable, but I still couldn't stop watching. Thank you Amazon for bringing us this show!

The acting, as always, very good.  Tom Hollander superb.  The story itself was too obvious and predictable.  Certain characters were so over the top that they seem more like caricatures ie. the drunken heir, the mother. This falls far short of Pride and Prejudice or Downton Abbey.
Another winner by Julian Fellowes

It was not Downton Abby, but I did enjoy it very much. This is the kind of story (and period--1800's) I like. Stayed up past my bedtime to watch the fourth episode! I look forward to more Anthony Trollope stories from Julian Fellowes.
Certainly not the quality of Downton Abbey,  but very good nonetheless.  Very predictable.  If you like this time period,  you'll be thoroughly entertained.

Thank you Julian Fellowes. Heroes and villains. What a lovely end of the day watch. I just love Frank's character. I really love them all. Great chemistry. Please make more films from Trollope's literary treasures.

Julian Fellowes is my personal hero!  What a lovely series!  The visuals are stunning and the colors pop even on a computer screen.  The acting is superb and the characters are so well drawn out that they are not stereotypical.  Even Louis was sympathetic.  I loved this series and I need more historical romances like this!!
Nice for a little binge watching.
This is such a wonderful adaptation of Doctor Thorne.  Julian Fellowes did a great job as usual with this mini series.  Great actors were chosen too.  I loved everything about this!

What this series lacks in depth and realistic response to tension, it makes up for in wonderful acting, delightful exchanges, the most gorgeous of costumes for both men and women, and scenery to dive into!  Granted, I've watched all Jane Austin books and even read a few, and every other period piece on the BBC, contemporary films and the old standards.  Would that life would end up so happily!  Meanwhile, we have this period piece and it goes down like warm chocolate cake with chocolate sauce and chocolate ice cream.  A harmless and satisfying indulgence.  In this case, familiarity brings about it's own rewards.

This is but a touch below the level of "Pride and Prejudice" The author, screenwriters and actors did such a wonderful job in bringing this story to life. People would like to say that Dr. Thorne is predictable. I would like to say stories in the developmental stages of literature from the time period from which this stems can be thought of this way. On the other hand the period in which we live now has only been cheapened by Hollywood and does this sort of literature no justice. The crux we have to look at here is that this story was brought to life in the most wonderful of ways and allows the viewers to feel for the characters and what they are trying to accomplish in the world that encompasses them. Julian Fellowes alludes to it himself that this story is to show the complexity of characters and the concept of nature which calls for a balance in life will it be moral, political, or legal theory. If you are to watch this story or read it do so with an open mind free from the cheapened love stories of today.

What a wonderful delight-I do so enjoy Julian Fellowes and his various presentations.
A real treat!!  Thanks for another successful production well done!!

I was NOT disappointed. In true British drama fashion, this show pulls you in and captivates with characters that you love right away. I loved every moment. I just wish it were longer. However, I must say Mr. Fellowes did a much better job with the final episode. Unlike DA, whereas, the ending was rushed and jampacked with storylines. If you watch this, you will find yourself on a binge. Enjoy!

We did watch all the episodes but they don't compare to the story quality of Downton.  To be fair, Downton should stand on its own as the story and time periods are different but, because Mr. Fellowes is involved, the bar for quality and content is raised high.  This series is enjoyable but just okay.

Also, Julian sitting in the red chair is a bit weird, and not sure if they meant to, reminds me of Alfed Hitchcock - lol

I don't post many reviews but after watching this series, I just had to. I'm a big fan of Julian Fellowes after Downton Abbey so I was curious to watch. The series is beautiful and cringeworthy in all the right places. There are some plot points that I feel weren't fully addressed and I'm going to download the book to see if it was a limitation of the medium or if the author really left it open ended. (The book is available for free on Kindle.) Despite this, I had to watch in one sitting because I couldn't pull myself away. Definitely worth the few hours investment!

Well done presentation of a good story. Wonderful filming locations and costumes. Julian Fellowes did a great job writing. His Alistair Cooke impression is great as well. Fun watching. It is nice to see a quality production for this period story. There are few film stories in this time setting and this was very well done.

Thank you!  Thank you!  Once again Amazon brings us GREAT entertainment!

I thoroughly enjoyed myself!  It was absolutely addicting!  Hollywood just can hold a candle to this kind of movie making and storytelling.  The BBC and English movie makers have something really special in this area.
And for me Anthony Trollope is right up there with Jane Austen, the Bronte sisters, Gaskell and Alcott.

What a treat to hear the insights, thoughts and opinions in the epilogues of genius Julian Fellowes.  .

It is always a joy and great pleasure to see the craft and artistry of Ian McShane, Alison Brie and Tom Hollander.

I really wanted to like it. I love period pieces, and I watch pretty much anything that is set in the 19th and early 20th century. I also wanted to believe Julia Fellows when he promised me complex characters and twists. But there were none. Not one. And Dr. Thorne et al. where about as multi layered as the toilet paper at the airport. Nor did any of them have any chemistry with each other. I did watch all four episodes, hoping that I'd be surprised at least a little while enjoying the scenery and costumes. If you are looking for a story to go with those, you might want to skip this mini series.
If  you are a fan of Sense and Sensibility you'll like this.

Sooooo good!!!
Still love Downton Abbey, but this is a great second best!!!!
These series are my favorite. Will always watch more.
Simply Lovely!  A happy ending indeed :)
we need more shows like this!
What a delightful little series. My family and I enjoyed it greatly and it was child approved and safe

What a wonderful surprise! Or rather, it surprises me how delighted I am by Trollope. I've loved Julian Fellowes' work since Gosford Park. After Downtown Abbey's final season, I'm glad to have more from Mr. Fellowes and to discover another 19th c. author. The story involves layers of dilemmas facing young lovers due to family expectations, a will's last-minute codicil, financial ruin, jealousy and ultimately happy endings. The actors were wonderful and the resolution satisfying. Fellowes' astute introductory remarks and his sums at the end added to the pleasure--especially if you can recall Alistair Cook on Masterpiece theater. Trollope was a prolific author, so I hope there's more to come.

I really liked the new show. I really liked the introductions and the conclusions by Mr. Fellows.  I hope he continues to make more and more episodes! Great story, great casting, great filming....after only viewing the first two episodes I am already a fan. Keep'm coming!!!!
One-dimensional in character and plot, and without the humor or witty dialogue of Downton Abbey. I was surprised how lame this was.
I loved the story, it was well done.
Well done ... a little too predictable but a good story and worth the watch.
Easy to watch and smile at.  Great period story with the Doctor's favorite - a happy ending.

It checks a solid number of boxes, but as has been stated many a time, the plot was not terribly original. There was good British humor and a peek into the life of the times, but it was terribly rushed and several major details to the plot are skipped entirely after having been mentioned. A great deal of deus ex machina was all that kept the story going. In all, it was a cute little love story, but expect no more than that.
We loved it.  We want more...
This show is so hilariously horrible, you can't stop watching.
Wonderful.  Love the introduction from Julian Fellowes.

The series was wonderful! I would like see more of this type of production. The characters are well developed, the story line intriguing and the acting superb. Doctor Thorne is as wonderful as Jane Austin's works. Bravo Amazon Prime for rendering such a joyous, uplifting series!
Clean (no swearing or sex), wonderful 1850's England drama!  If you love Jane Austin, you will love this!
enjoyed it.

If you're dying for a period costume drama this will probably do.  It's just very rushed and less complex than Julian Fellowa would have you believe.  He does an intro before each episode, much like Laura Linney does before masterpiece theater, and he keeps telling the audience how multilayered each character is, and how not everything is at seems.  And then he goes on about a supposed love triangle that is very nonexistent.

It's pretty irritating when it turns out that everything is as it seems and all the characters are little more than cardboard cutouts.  I imagine I would have enjoyed the story much more had I not been waiting for the story and characters to surprise me as I was told would happen by Mr Fellows before and after each episode.

I suppose I shouldn't have expected much out of the man who made Mary  Crawley to be such an incredibly unsympathetic character and did everything to try to make me like her to the point that I had to jump ship in the middle of Downtown Abby season 5.

And yes, I do know that Doctor Thorne was adapted from a novel written by Anthony Trollop and is not Julian Fellows original work but I can see why Fellows is quite a fan of Trollops writing.  I, however, don't imagine I'll go out of my way to watch anything that Julian Fellows has attached himself to in the future.
Excellent story line,  fantastic characters, scenes that don't rely on nudity,  and a new author to read. I hope Amazon continues to produce more shows like this.

I would have loved this story to be stretched out into more episodes where we could have explored each character more in depth. But it was good the way it was done too. Just a lot was skipped over that I feel would have really enhanced the story. Great acting. Beautiful settings. Wonderful plot. Even though I saw the end coming from the first episode, it only enhanced my enjoyment of watching everything I'd predicted come to pass. One thing I didn't see happened in the very last 5 minutes of the last episode and I wish that had been developed quite a bit more throughout the episodes because it made me very happy. Anyhow, overall a great show. Give it a try. I think you'll like it.
I very much enjoyed this clean Show. The whole famiy can watch it, without embarrassment ( no sexuality or cursing ) Beautiful, i love if
Great performances! Would have liked more episodes. Can't compare with nor replace Downton Abbey but enjoyabke!

This was all about Julian Fellowes, wasn't it?  I knew this at the onset, as self-aggrandizement poured through his ultra British persona, as if the deeper his aristocratic accent, the more the Downton Abbey-philes will hasten to viewing his god-gift to us.  After all the hype and I'm sure the expense put into this fiasco, one cannot avoid the immediate slap in the face to all the expectations--the cinematography lacked 19th century mood, the casting was ridiculous, as one reviewer said, a GQ tween; the actors were poorly directed through a very poor script.  Sorry for this rough review but for one who adores British period pieces, and the list is long including Upstairs/Downstairs, Downton Abbey, The duchess of Duke Street, Poldark, The Way things Were, The Forsythe Saga,  to name a few, this kind of marketed pablum needs to be called.
Loved it!  If you are a fan of Julian Fellowes, you will not be disappointed.  Highly recommend this series!
love loved this!! thank you once again Julian Fellowes! I thought it was a great adaptation of Doctor Thorne!

If you're a real fan of period drama, this will suffice if you're itching for something new, but really, I'd rather re-watch any number of old classics available than this. I highly doubt I'll ever come back to this. Julian Fellowes' episodic writing has always been a bit weak; the first season of Downton showed how he rushes as if he's writing a movie, and then suddenly remembers that it must go on for quite awhile. This is the same. However, with Downton, the difference is that what's great about Fellowes is that he has a panache for writing great dialogue zingers, and his characters really come alive through the dialogue. Here, he isn't the source material author, and the dialogue is really rather droll. Also, the cinematography on this project isn't as good -- so it's nowhere as lush and beautiful as Downton was -- many shots are made with shallow depth of field, so much that it really seems as though it's a camera trick so you don't realize they're on a set, not outside, and the background is actually a painting. There are few shots where it seems as though they're really trying to make the most of the rented estates by ubiquitously showing architectural splendor, but it's not done very well.

In broad strokes, this is very much like an Austen story, with class lines getting in the way of love, and then throw in a dash of Wuthering Heights. However, like Fellowes, Austen also had a panache for dialogue, and herself seemed to have a much more natural wit in her writing than Trollope, allowing us to be amused by her characters. Here, there's really nothing but the plot line, which we're all too familiar with.

Finally, Julian Fellowes hosts as if he's Alistair Cooke, and I have to say, I found that really annoying; presumptuous even.

So, in sum, Dear Amazon, please continue with the period drama productions, but fire Fellowes and definitely get a new cinematographer.

Perhaps the fault of this mediocre and painful melodrama lies in its being crammed into 4 episodes. Nearly every action feels forced and trumped-up. The endings come off as trite and rushed, not triumphant or cathartic.
And they achieved all that nothing despite a fine cast. Oh well. At least it was pretty to watch.
Loved it.  Great story telling again by Mr. Fellowes.
Julian Fellowes does it again,,,a most enjoyable adaptation.
The story felt rushed and underdeveloped. It could have been so much better.
The scenery, characters, and story were just lovely!

Julian Fellowes goes "full Masterpiece Theatre" here, including the Alistair Cooke introductions and wrap-ups. Great fun; not serious but pleasant to watch, although more predictable than a Jane Austen, which says a lot!

Acting wasn't as good nor was the plot for typical British fare. You knew what was to happen before it ended. I imagine this series was actually done long before downtown abby, despite what that pretentious guy said. Ho-hum, killed a few hours.

Dreadful.  First there was Gosford Park--a work of genius by Altman.  Then Downton Abbey was spun off...engaging and beautifully acted.  Now comes Doctor Thorne, hitting bottom.  Nothing in common with the first two except the magnificent English countryside.  Clumsy acting, predictable plot, same old same old.  Only Tom Hollander comes through with fine acting, as always.  Aren't our appetites for this stuff finally sated?
It was just ok but predictable.  watched all 4 episodes this morning, it's raining so it was a good way to relax.
If you want to experience Trollope,  try "The Way We Live Now." (film)
I loved this show. I hope there is additional seasons to come. excellent English drama...

I have loved Julian Fellowes since I was a young girl. Even later, when he killed Mathew, I stayed true to my favorite screen writer. This new series brought to Amazon by Julian Fellowes is not only developed by the talented writer, but also hosted. Cozy fireplace and all! It is everything you could love about Fellowes and more. Funny, heartwarming/wrenching, and tragic. It is an incredibly entertaining and binge-worthy! Now go, watch... you can thank me later :)

Brought to us by the man you wrote Downton Abbey, this show is a victorian age (1850's) Dynasty or Dallas with all the beautiful scenery and castles that many of us saw in Downton Abbey.  I enjoy the characters, and who doesn't love Ian Mcshane, and will very much hope and look forward to another season of Dr. Thorne...  ** My only complaint** --- are the Alfred Hitchcock-esq prologues and epilogues ... Please get rid of those.. other than the opening prologue, where we learned about the Author himself and a bit about his life, the rest prove boring and pointless. (we won't mention how much fellowe's tends to look and sometimes act like  hitchcock.
We thoroughly enjoyed, love won out.  A scholar, Frank won Mary's heart while Louis the playboy and obvious alcoholic, lost.

Delightful....Marry Money!

Hope to see more like this from Julian Fellowes.

I'm not sure I would watch this again. But if you like a short story that is wrapped up neatly at the end. Is predictable with an HEA. Then this is the story for you. I gave it a 5 because I really have no objection to it. It held my attention long enough for me to binge watch it. The actors were pretty to look at. Even the villain.  I like the narration from Mr. Fellows before and after each episode. Just don't question the edges in the plot details.
soooooooooo wonderful! loved it. loved characters, story and the most charming finale! extremely well done and completely entertaining.
Amateur hour here. Some beautiful locations, but no real wit or depth.
I really loved the pre/post commentary by Julian Fellowes. Wonderful costuming
Superb acting...wonderful...wish there was more
I like British period dramas, and this was pleasant, but very predictable story line.

An excellent period piece.  It was a guilty pleasure to binge watch this lush beautifully costumed piece this weekend.  I enjoyed the humor and the drama.  While the plot was predictable - it was pretty clear that Mary Thorne would come into a large sum of money - this did not diminish the pleasure of watching it all work toward a conclusion.  The casting was flawless and I enjoyed Julian's commentary particularly about the author with whom I am anxious to become better acquainted.  I do hope Amazon will do more of these types of series.  If so, I will be watching.
Julian Fellowes, along with a superb cast, hit another one out of the park...hated to see it end.
This was enjoyable! I loved Julian Fellows' commentary, the series itself was wonderful. Great casting, excellent adaptation of the books, costuming and sets were beautiful. Loved it.
Wonderful story and acting. Money seems to be an age old issue as it is today.

Note to one starred reviews: It was only a preview for one week, and it was obvious that more was to come for prime members, so I am surprised at the negative reviews for just the preview? This was a pleasure to watch, and the entire mini-series is completely free for prime members. Fellowes delivers again in a four part mini-series based on an Anthony Trollope novel. It isn't Downton Abbey II, as claimed by the media, but it is an enjoyable love story set in Victorian Era England and great to watch on a weekend in Springtime with the windows open and the birds chirping outside.

Tom Hollander is an absolute delight in the title role of this excellent presentation !! I really enjoyed (and applauded) the personalized introduction and ending of each chapter by Julian Fellowes !! Watch it today .. YOU will NOT be disappointed !!

What fun to have this story appear as a surprise from Prime. This made our Friday night which was otherwise doomed to watching a lesser show. We watched the whole thing at once. Don't expect the universe. It's not Downton Abbey. But on the other hand it is well done, the actors are real pros, and it's free with Prime. The introduction by Julian Fellowes is wonderful. The story is light but a treat. The main characters (Doctor Thorne and his daughter) are sympathetic and the villians are appropriately wicked but as Mr. Fellowes says ... not one-dimensionally bad and therefore interesting. After seeing this I decided to start listening to other Trollope books on Audible this morning and am enjoying the discovery.

The costumes and the settings are the best things about this remarkably silly Julian Fellowes indulgence. The acting, with the notable exceptions of Tom Hollander and Rebecca Front, is mediocre. Ian McShane engages in his usual scenery chewing overacting; there is no chemistry among the alleged romantic leads, and the heroes and villains are caricatures of characters. The most fun I had was matching the actors to other, more entertaining British costume dramas!
Wonderful story!

With the exception of Ian McShane and two or three other seasoned actors, the cast was poor. The story lacked luster and the main climaxes of the story were rapidly skipped over and could have been made so much better. I found the costumes dreadful! The hats were modern day straw beach hats, cut to shape and a cheap trim added to hide where the scissors had done their worst. There were no stunning dresses but a lot of ubiquitous starched flowers  I like Julian Fellowes as an actor and writer, and I can only surmise that the direction was not up to scratch. Sorry...didn't hit the mark for me!
LOVED it! Please make more like it!
Great!

Loved this. Watched it all in one evening. Fellowes' commentary added to the viewing experience.
Kudos!

Victorian era series about a penniless niece of Dr. Thorne, a widely respected doctor. We have two suitors for Mary, penniless and then not, but I found Frank, the man she prefers, to be boring and lazy. I didn't understand her attraction to him. His mother, Arabella objects to their plans of marriage until the end of the series simply because Mary is penniless and the family home can only be saved by marrying her grown children off to a rich man, or woman---anyone will do as long as lavish living of hearth and home is kept intact. No love need apply.
Then we have Louis, son of the deceased and wealthy uncle of Mary. He's portrayed as a boozer and it's un-nerving and overdone with his glass of booze, or whatever he drinks and in his hands almost all times and it's simply overdone. Without the drinks, Louis is much better suited to marry Mary. It's really the only obstacle that I can fathom. She's a good horsewoman; he's a good horseman and he does love her, despite his drinking. Loose the booze glass at every turn and things could be different. Frank's declarations of love fall flat and without emotion of any kind in a kiss or whatever form. I don't really think the series is about saving a mansion and a family's lavish way of living by marrying adult children into the world of money. In my opinion, it's about marrying for love being acceptable.
After watching this  I bought the six-volume set of Trollope's Barchester series.  P.S.  Any chance of Amazon bringing The Pallisers to Amazon Prime Video?

While I agree with some of the previous reviews, its not Downton...but it is definitely worth a watch!  I appreciate Julian Fellowes as a director, and screenwriter.  I even don't mind hearing his brief synopsis at the beginning of each episode, but I think its overkill to recap at the end of each episode.
 Knowing that Season 2 is up in the air,  I felt the wedding was rushed to tidy up loose ends just in case.
Well,  I hope they have a season 2. Hopefully, they read the reviews, so they next season will be as good as Downton!

Thoroughly enjoyable diversion. Enjoy it for what it is. Trollope was never as hard to slog through as Austen or Dickens and liked happy endings. It is entertaining and I enjoyed it so much I binge watched the whole thing in one sitting. The acting was fine and if anything understated. Dont let other reviews dissuade you. Give it a try.

A wonderfully told tale set in amazing settings.  Perfect actors. The only downside is that I wish it had been longer to draw out the characters and story more. I do hope Fellows goes on with this since this book was part of a series. Or he could just take them off on a journey of his own making. After all, we know he can create addictive shows. Highly recommended.

Very pretty.  Nice story. Worth watching to get your fix.

IF it had been less condescending to the audience,  having each segment explained and recapped,  I would have loved it for sensory value.

Skip over the fireside chats,  and enjoy.

It's definitely not Downton, but also, it would be wrong to compare it to that standard as Doctor Thorne is entirely different from it.
It motivated me to read the novels of Anthony Trollope. The script is good, as we can expect from Fellowes. The costumes are marvelous and the cinematography unique and clean. Its a little optimistic for my taste, a little too sweet of an ending. Then again, I'm a cynic. The message of the series is applaudable however. But the actors do their job well, you detest Arabella and the Lady De Courcy yet you pity Louis. I should like to see a second season and see if the characters get a chance to develop more. If anything, maybe a bit more time was needed, perhaps longer episodes. The story seemed rushed in certain parts.
Overall, its enjoyable. Well done Julian Fellowes. You are versatile and I hope to see more of your work!

I absolutely loved this four part series. It is gorgeous, charming, and made me smile the whole time. It is fairly fast paced, but this allows it to stay fresh and far from dull. In all honesty, I wish there were a few more episodes, but it was lovely nonetheless. The acting is pretty solid; some performances were a little hit or miss, but overall it was superb. The costumes and sets were very elegant and perfect for the series. The camera work was decent; sometimes it felt a little underwhelming, but I cannot complain. The story is very charming and active. I have never read anything by Trollope, but I have added him to my "to read" list. I highly enjoyed Doctor Thorne, and I would recommend it to anyone, especially people who enjoy shows like Poldark and Downton Abbey. I pray that it receives a disc version because I would like to add it to my shelf.

An absolutely delightful story!  I thoroughly enjoyed it.  Thanks to Julian Fellowes and to Amazon for bringing this story to the screen!  I had never heard of the English novelist Anthony Trollope before, and I appreciate learning of him through this introduction..
Like many British costume dramas, this can be summed up in three words:  bucolic, predictable, and cheesy.
Nice story line with good character development!

Really enjoyed this adaptation.  Though there were some tragic characters, and some I wouldn't invite over (including a mother), there was a great deal of humor that I liked in this production.  My favorite, perhaps, is near the end in Amazon's episode 4.  That's as much of a spoiler as I'm willing to give.  I don't think this is close to Julian Fellowes's Downton Abbey, and certainly not the biting wit of Maggie Smith, but there were allusions to other British works.  Quite honestly, I haven't read Trollope's book, but now find I must.  I'd like to know if his characters were written to appear as in the adaptation, or if they are more exaggerated.  I found a bit of Jane Austen, and was reminded a bit of the haughty Hyacinth.  Even though this won't be the sensation that many of the British shows come to be, I think the production values in the show were much better than we seem to do here, generally.  I would like to see more of Trollope's work brought to the small screen.

If you like British costume dramas, you'll probably like this. Definitely more Jane Austen than Downton Abbey - could have used some zinger one liner's. I recommend skipping Julian Fellowes intros and wrap-ups. It was good enough that I stayed up until well past my bed time watching the entire thing. Beautiful people and costumes. Adding the books to my reading list.

Really enjoyed this story.  Found the acting to be excellent and the setting quite beautiful. Watched it all in one evening, which brings me to the reason for 4 stars instead of 5, as his pre and post narrations were a bit trying, but I guess that is what fast forward is for.  Look forward to more of the same, sans narration of course.

Yes, yes, it is lovely to behold. Beautiful costumes, settings, landscape and cinematography, but a pretty flat plot. Mr. Fellowes himself appears at the beginning and end of each episode, extolling the virtues of Anthony Trollop's writing skill, expressing his admiration for Trollop's  ability to render characters of great depth, unfortunately range of character did not translate from the page to the screen, so we have only Mr. Fellowes' word for it. (I confess I've never read Trollop) However the cast was full of outstanding actors who could probably read a telephone book and make it interesting. Just think what would have been possible if the story had not been so bare bones predictable. When Alistar Cook introduced the old Master Piece Theater productions it was to offer  insight about the culture or history of the period  that  the general population, especially Americans, would not have been aware. These were generally informative and added to the appreciation of the story. Frankly I found Mr. Fellowes,  in his little fire side setting, in the same position, same jacket and tie, twice in each and every episode telegraphing the plot  with flagrant spoilers, directing your attention to details  of character in case we missed them, then recapping what we'd seen in case we failed to grasp the significance as annoying as it was condescending. The whole thing lacked tension and any sense of anticipation for the outcome.  I never felt sympathy for this rich, ungrateful family about to get thrown out on their pampered butts. So the good news is, it is pleasant to watch even if it's not very engaging. And, I'm going to read this book. I'll let you know if I change my opinion. :)

I find it outrageous that people Amazon include release a series and do not give credit to the author of the book "Doctor Thornel". This is a classic Anthony Trollope book and no where is his name mentioned. Instead they give credit to "Julian Fellowes". I wonder how he would feel if this series was playing on television without his name ever seen.
I loved this show.  What fun!  And wonderful happy endings for all.  Bravo Amazon Prime.  More of this, please.
Brilliant. Warm, funny, creative. And even nicer to look at than Downton!
Loved It! What a sweet, feel good movie! I hope Amazon will make more shows like this one! The actors had great chemistry and the story was very sweet and funny!

After seeing only one episode of the four, I am sold. As Fellowes did not have much time to develop characters as he did on Downton, I would say he has done a splendid job of it in his new series. (All this is to say that only one episode in you can already form connections to the characters.) Further, the British humor is not lost in what had promised to be, for me, a more "American" version of Downton. I cannot wait to see how the story unfolds.

Loving it!  Saw the first episode, and I am sad there are only 3 more left!

Keep Calm and Hope for a Second Season.
The English countryside scenery is breathtaking and who doesn't love a good love story!  The cast, especially Ian McShane, was an excellent choice!  Will watch it again; even knowing how it all ends.
Again Mr. Fellows has entranced us with a wonderful storyline...the homes and costumes were wonderful....

Julian Fellowes has done it again! Absolutely wonderful series that those missing Downton Abbey will thoroughly enjoy. There is plenty of mystery to unravel and the drama is top notch! What are you waiting for? Go watch it and enjoy!!!

Very well done.  While not as deep as the obvious comparison (Downton Abbey), this series is really enjoyable with good characters and beautiful cinematography.  Julian Fellowes is "the man" for this type of story.  Really hope to see more like this from him.  Thanks, Amazon.
loved!
Loved it!
Not as well done as Downtown Abbey but very good nonetheless. Am looking forward to the next season.
What's not to love about this? Especially enjoyed seeing Tom Hollander. Sorry I binge-watched now! Guess I'll have to watch them again!

After being in Abbey withdrawl I was thrilled to see another delightful work of Julian Fellows, Well Done. I absolutely loved each episode, couldn't wait to click "next"
 I only pray there is a  season 2
I loved it,  specially with Julian fellows near writing between the episodes was very helpful is very good
I really enjoyed this. I have been an Anthony Trollope Fan for years. Hopefully amazon continues making the rest of The Barsetshire Chronicles into movies.
Amazon is creating shows with some fabulous content and would love to see this become a new series. Love the storyline.
Would have preferred less of the commentary for Julian, otherwise I enjoyed the period piece.
Sell out. Maybe even treacherous.

What a wonderful, wonderful show. I enjoyed every minute and fabulous acting by all. Nothing made me giggle with joy so much as Lady Gresham groveling for Mary's forgiveness. Mary and Frank's chemistry was stellar. I wish there was more.
Found it utterly delightful.

Wonderful costumes, settings and casting.  Instead of being caricatures as they are in Dickens, the characters are real people who are, as Fellowes says, richly layered. The hero and heroine are both good, do good, and are rewarded. Ian McShane is fantastic in his small role and is redeemed at the end, as are the 'villains' of the piece. Even the smallest character contributes to the storyline or atmosphere and the village was just gorgeous. The subplot with 'Gus', Lady Augusta, is very funny, though not of course for her, and the American heiress Miss Dunstable was very intriguing and well played.  Devoured all 4 episodes in one sitting, it was so good. Yes, the Victorians were stiff, preoccupied with class, and had very formal ways of acting, which are brought out accurately here. Thank you to Amazon for bringing this to us all. Highly recommend.
Excellent! I could watch it over and over.

I actually was not aware of Thorpe or his prolific writing career. Watching these short episodes really intrigued me to turn to the source novels and read more. I enjoyed the treatment that presented the novels, and as I can't compare to the source novels, I can only speak to how well done it was as it motivated me to go read more.
Loved it !
Wonderful!!! I loved every minute of it!
I thoroughly enjoyed this adaptation from Julian Fellowes and it left me hoping for many more.

I loved this great period piece. Just sorry it was only four episodes. Would like to see more of Julian Fellowes. It reminds me of years ago when Alfred Hitchcock used to  host his shows. The Brits always do it better though!
This was a really fun little feel good series.  I liked the way Julian Fellowes introduced each episode, and debriefed after each episode.  I hope he writes more series like this.

Looks like a rush job, (awful editing...) made by people who took a survey of what made folks watch Downton Abbey, and then proceeded to make something that would hit all the bullet points. Predictable, choppy, but nice scenery and costumes.  OK filler to watch in the middle of the night.

Characters are not very developed.
Predictable plot line.

FIRST, I ADORE and am completely addicted to all things 18th and 19th Century romance pieces and if one wants a REAL Trollope, go to The Way We Live Now - complete and total PERFECTION, inc for one reason this disappointment grossly misses the mark - Rule #1, CASTING. When your leading "man" looks like a tween Abercrombe and Fitch model and appears much younger and more girly than your heroine, you know you've got a serious problem. All the upper lip injections in the world cannot give this utterly shallow lead actress the kind of natural pretty warmth required of a historic romance heroine, esp ag tween GQ.  Why A&E's seminal Pride & Prejudice, Sense & Sensibility, and Downtown Abbey bar none were all so incredibly successful and beloved was casting - the right cast can enthrall reading a recipe or the phone book.  This casting was bad, you wonder that so much expense, time, energy would be put into such a project then cut at the knees by really really bad casting.  Our heroine looks like a transvestite, to me, and though that may be ok elsewhere, it is not ok in Austen.  This visually gender neutral heroine - with as much warmth and depth as an ice slick on the road - distracts horribly from the story. Though loaded with some older stalwart historic romance fav actors, the other young starlets cast also totally lack the quintessential historic authenticity and character acting chops we luv and expect from a juicy historic romance piece.  The casual observer won't notice this, but the hard core won't luv it and in fact may wince as i did within the first 10 seconds.  The story is not either that compelling or fleshed out here.  Even so, Downton IMMED hooked us with superb casting - this is a barely tolerable dose for the truly period romance enamored, but it will NOT become Downton nor do Trollope the kind of justice or recognition Fallows seeks.

This can be a good substitute for Downtown & the characters are growing on me,but curious to know how many more episodes are we to expect and by when.? I specially enjoy Julian Fellows commentary before and after.

As a huge fan of Downton Abbey and Poldark,  Doctor Thorne did not disappoint! I enjoyed it so much that I watched the entire series in 2 days! I grew attached to the main characters and the storyline kept my interest. Some of the acting was a bit "cheesy" but the main characters were FANTASTIC so it was easy to overlook. For those leaving not so great reviews, I thought the creator did just fine with only 4 shows! You can only go so deep and develop an entire novel so far in limited amounts of time. Downton Abbey had several seasons to captivate us!  I thought this show was highly entertaining and I definitely recommend watching it!
I enjoyed this very much!

I excitedly anticipated this series and binge watched the entire thing last night and this morning. 'Doctor Thorne' It has all the snobbery, finery, scandal, and decorum as you've come to expect with British period piece dramas but, for me, it falls a little short of my expectation.  Tom Hollander and Ian McShane elevate this series with fine acting even though the adaptation, dialog, and soundtrack is a bit forced. I loved seeing Nicholas Rowe as Gazebee...yet he will always be a young Sherlock Holmes to me! The other actors were perfectly fine but less memorable. Nothing and no one really stood out. Beautiful costumes, locations, and cinematography, especially within the rooms of Osterley Park and West Wycombe House (Greshamsbury Park).

Overall an enjoyable, light diversion.

Another gem by Julian Fellowes!  I love content put out by Amazon and this man really know how to do it.  I like the format with the introduction and recap for each episode.  I anxiously await more like this!

Doctor Thorne was a waste of time.  The story was slow.  The hero and heroine had zero chemistry.  I could not  have cared less about the outcome.  Boring Boring Boring.  Thanks Drew for your help with my grammar.  But you did get the point.......right????
Very charming and entertaining. Much like a Charles Dickens story.

As far as period dramas go, there is nothing really "wrong with it". It's clean, family friendly, and well constructed.

However, it plays the game so safe that it could be described as boring. The acting can also come off slightly stilted, and... acted. No matter what the era, real dialogue doesn't "pass the talking rock". People interrupt, stutter, and have trouble articulating their speech. Of course, that doesn't make this a bad series, but dialogue improvements might have helped.
Another amazing show by Julian Fellowes done ever so well. I can only hope for more in the near future.

Five stars from me on this one.  The Brits are absolutely the best at period pieces.  As Julian Fellows might exclaim, "A rippingly good show!"  (If you haven't seen his performances in "Monarch of the Glen" you've missed a very special treat). Some of the scenes of the ladies in their silky pastel gowns seated in the elegant surroundings of Gresham looked like figures in a portrait.  Having read all of Anthony Trollop's novels and watched "The Chronicles of Barchester" at least a dozen times starring the incomparable Susan Hampshire you can imagine my delight in stumbling upon this super adaptation of Dr. Thorne.  I watched all four episodes in one sitting and lamented bitterly when the final credits ran.  Did someone say there are more episodes to come?
It was everything I wanted from a period romance. Sigh and swoon.

You have to really, really love 19th-century romance stories to enjoy this. From the first moment Julian Fellowes appears onscreen to introduce the story, you know you're in for something way below the quality you're used to with the BBC/Masterpiece theater.  And you get treated to one of those clunky intros with every episode.  But wait...there's more.  He comes back to close each episode.  Just as clunky and just as unnecessary.  (I suspect JF demanded screen time in return for making the Amazon deal.  JF didn't show up when this miniseries aired in Britain.)  Fortunately, when you stream, you can skip.  And you'll want to skip all the JF bits.

The plot?  "Doctor Thorne" is Anthony Trollope's story of a mysterious, two-dimensionally-good, orphaned girl, Mary, who's raised by the two-dimensionally-good Doctor Thorne, who claims to be her uncle.  Mary's in love with her childhood friend, but his parents oppose their relationship because they want their son to marry for money and save the family estate.  Sound familiar?  Anyone who has read any Dickens knows where this story goes.  There are no surprises here, no subtitles to the plot, no complexity of character.  And the music?  Yikes.  If you're ever stumped while watching this as to how you're supposed to feel, the overwrought score will tip you off.  ("Time to laugh!"  "Oh, sad part.")

Bravo to Amazon for providing Prime members with something a bit different.  And I hope they keep grabbing a variety of shows to stream.  And if you're looking for something harmless and somewhat literary you can watch with the kids, "Doctor Thorne" is a reasonable option.  But if you prefer more grownup fare with character development, plot surprises, and subtlety in direction, acting, and screenplay, have another go at the BBC's "Pride and Prejudice."
I loved it and sincerely hope that Series 2 will follow soon.
Loved it! That ending was icing on a cake!
loved Downton but cannot even stay with this! BORING!!!!!!
Loved this show!  This is filling my Downton Abbey void until Season 6 comes to Prime.  Very witty and humorous.
I don't appreciate Bait and Switch.  This is only a preview.  I have to pay (even though I have a Prime account) to watch this.

This adaptation of "Doctor Thorne" is witty, engaging, charming, and even at times downright funny. This is a sunny world populated by all kinds of scheming characters. Some are put in their place, others get their comeuppances at the end. It's somewhat predictable, and a little cramped (I wouldn't have minded another hour to flesh out the side stories) but quite charming.

It's also one of the few recent costume dramas I would have no issue problem recommending to anyone. It's nice to watch a grow up story without "the adult content" to match.
I can't wait!!

Doctor Fellowes is not really a "Downton" type mega-hit.  Instead, it is a little bit Cranford, a tiny bit Poldark, and a lot of Emma and Sense and Sensibility.

Taken in its own right, Doctor Thorne is everything I expected it to bewhich is just fine by me.  I enjoyed it thoroughly.

To be clear, it really more of a long movie than a "series," per se (just under three hours in total).  But the length works well enough for the source material.

To turn it into a set of four distinct episodes rather than the a movie format, the producers added formal fireside introductions and conclusions by Julian Fellowes to each "episode": kind of an Afred Hitchcock meets Masterpiece Theater kind of touch. Those weren't really weren't my personal cup of tea, because they tended to take me out of the flow of the story, and sometimes offered up (minor) spoilers.  Some viewers might enjoy those interludes though, and they were easy enough to skip over.

To be clear, nothing about Doctor Thorne was surprising in the slightest.  Marvelously grand houses.  Spectacular clothing.  Unnaturally beautiful people.  Stunning English scenery.  Fabulous wealth, and the desperate fear of losing it.  High-stakes tradeoffs between love and money.  Deathbed drama, and lighthearted frivolity.  The strictures of being a woman during that era.  Uptight English norms, and desires to break free of them.  The entre of an American heiress into that world, casting a bright light on some of the inherent dysfunction of that system.  And, of course, some requisite swoon-worthy deep eye gazing, with expressions of repressed and forbidden love.

Okay, so not terribly surprising, and more than a little predictable; even a bit formulaic at times.  But it is the source material by Trollope which is responsible for that, not something about this particular rendition.  And in any case, so what, since it is a formula that works?!  It was engaging and pleasant and perfectly marvelous fun, and I will happily watch it again.  And it is quite to Amazon's credit that it is willing and able to support original feature productions of this impressive quality.

The characters and all of their perfect imperfections were compelling, often comically so, with a few notably wise souls in the mix.  I was left wanting to see more of them, which is a good sign.  I enjoyed seeing familiar faces (favorites were Allison Brie of Mad Men, Ian McShane of Deadwood, with several other recognizable actors in the mix as well.)  I did not happen to find the familiarity to be distracting in this case, but be forewarned that some viewers may.

It will have a smaller potential audience than Downton Abbey.  Among other especially special attributes of Downton, it was quite a cross cutting show, enjoyed seemingly as much by men as by women.  I quite loved both of the shows myself, but I am guessing Doctor Thorne will not be as widely beloved.  This strikes me as a show mostly for the English period drama aficionado, which is quite fine by me, but naturally limits its reach.

For some interesting context about Anthony Trollope's work relative to his contemporaries, with discussion of Doctor Thorne in particular (with useful comparisons between the book and novel), Google  "The Way We Live Now," by Laura Miller, published on Slate.com on May 30, 2016.

For those of you who finish all 4 episodes/ 3 hours of Doctor Thorne tonight (...and, c'mon, you know you probably will...), and are then left wanting more British period drama, here are some ideas.  Here are good Amazon options, mostly on Prime (+ also check the comments section below this review, since people have been making some great suggestions there, as well!)

****************************************************************************
*** TIPS for VIEWING ALTERNATIVES (for after you have blown through Doctor Thorne!) ***
****************************************************************************

~~~  POLDARK ~~~ A succulent English drama that will tend to appeal to the same crowd who will enjoy Doctor Thorne, albeit with a bit more darkly melodramatic flair.  Set in the English countryside on the heels of the Revolutionary War as British soldiers return home, it has classic themes of marrying for love or money, sudden gains and reversals of fortune, working class struggles vs. the landed gentry, tension between those who are ready throw off the strictures of hierarchical English society versus the many elites who resist it mightily.  After blowing through Season 1 of Poldark on Amazon Prime, I am now eagerly awaiting Season 2.

~~~ LARKRISE TO CANDLEFORD ~~~ Seasons 1-3.  Based on a book of the same name, Larkrise to Candleford is a bit less opulent than Doctor Thorne and Poldark.  It spends much of its time with the middle and lower classes of English society (directly acknowleding the differences in engaging, if fairly predictable, ways).  As such, the costumes and sets aren't quite as marvelous.  But it is a lovely show, if a tad dated in terms of production quality.  It is also one that is family friendly (kind of like an English "Little House on the Prairie"), mixing life lessons in with the drama, so I have been rewatching it with my 11 year old.  Catch it while you can on Prime, as it has circulated in and out of Prime, and right now (May 2016) all three seasons are free on Prime. (and/or just read the classic books, as they are also a real treat, and fantastic window into that interesting time of railroads and associated technological developments, and how those affected rural English society.)

~~~ CRANFORD ~~~ Cranford is along the lines of Larkrise to Candleford, a little newer, and also quite a charming on small village life in merry 'ole England.

~~~ THE PARADISE ~~~ The genre is slightly different -- i.e. rather than focusing on the landed gentry in pastoral England, it focused on the opening of the first full-fledged department store in Gibson-girl London.  The concept can feel a tad predictable and trite (audacious store owner, big stores pushing out small stores, women gaining independence in the workplace, shop floor competition, etc.)  Yet it is much fun!  Great costumes.  Engaging characters.  An always-interesting focus on new developments replacing old traditions.  Different seasons of Paradise cycle in and out of Prime (and it doesn't seem to be on Prime as of the moment), but it always worth a look to see if/when The Paradise available for free.

~~~ MR. SELFRIDGE ~~~ Basically see my description of "The Paradise" for plot (the shows are almost amazingly similar!)  Keep the idea of a flashy and controversial department store replacing the increasingly staid stores of London.  Change the era to Downton Abbey/ early 20th century/pre and post WWI.  And basically, you get "The Paradise" and its department store politics, set in a later era, with an audacious businessman (Jeremy Piven of Entourage) who happens to be American.  It also has great costuming.  It also focuses a good deal on new developments pushing out old traditions, and on the societal change of women gaining independent power outside of the home.  Like the Paradise, it is also a little predictable and sometimes a bit trite, yet it is still good fun!  Several seasons of Mr. Selfridge happen to be on Prime at the moment, and you might want to grab it while you can because it, too, cycles in and out of Prime.

~~~ OUTLANDER ~~~ I almost hesitate to add Outlander because it not on Prime at the moment (so $19-ish per season), and because it probably has already been voraciously consumed by a good portion of the people looking into Doctor Thorne...but, oh, if you haven't seen it, you must!  Be forewarned though, it can be graphic, both sexually and in terms of violence; Outlander is definitely not family-friendly fare, and the violence sometimes seems over the top and unnecessary to me.  But, aside from that, it is quite a magnificent show.  If you are not familiar with it, or the wonderful books the series is based on, Outlander is a bit hard to explain -- it is mostly Scottish colonial period drama, mixed with time travel.  But even the sci fi adverse are likely to enjoy this show, with its magnificent costumes, sets, lush Scottish scenery, and, aye, the truly marvelous accents and men in kilts.  The acting and characters are great, as well.  Highly recommended, at least for those who are ok with fairly explicit violence and (...some wildly, passionately, super hot...) sex.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
~~~ Happy Viewing! ~~~
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

By it is sad to reflect on this sad remnant of Masterpiece Theater.

Consider: Upstairs/Downstairs went on for many, many episodes.  Each one advanced the plot only slightly. The series had entirely believable characters acting in entirely believable ways.  The last couple of seasons, as James suffers the after-effects of WWI, and Richard marries his secretary were excruciating.  Richard has done what we would think is natural, but everyone around him says "She doesn't know her place."  The gradual decline of James is even more pitiable.

Fast forward to Downton Abbey.  The plot evolves at lightening pace, and it is truly improbable that the head butler ends up in prison awaiting trial.

Dr. Thorne really marks the end of the road.  There are only four, 40 minute episodes, so this giant book is reduced to the length of a 2 1/2 hour movie.  Why, oh why, did they truncate it like this where the people commenting on this site are raving about it.  This book could have been made into about 16 episodes where you would actually come to understand the complex difficulties Trollope has each character face.

I've listened to this as an audiobook of 20+ hours.  Did you know that while Dr. Thorne is shown to be a saint, and while he also is the "hero," his hang-up  is that he maintains pretensions of his own about his background.  He is alienated from the branch of his family with the money because of a perceived slight, and he is at odds with the rest of the medical community because of his treatments.

Lady Arabella, meanwhile is a hypochondriac  who relies on Thorne.  You only see her cough once in the series, but it is a major theme that she wants his advice but is too proud to call on him.

And the reason the family is broke is mainly Lady A's insistence they maintain a house in London they can't afford.

In the book, the only person who knows about Mary's background is Gresham and he is boxed in because he was the one who brought Mary to the house.  Mary has no idea either until near the end, etc., creating endless tension as she is illegitimate.

Frank, meanwhile, though he claims he will marry Mary for love, ignore the money, and get a job, is probably not capable of functioning on his own.  In the book, you understand that this plan will fail because he is an underachiever at school, likes his horses, etc.

The only point in the series that really embraces Trollope's style is right at the end where the one sister advised the other not to marry the lawyer, and it turns out she then marries him herself.

Really too bad. I think the audience would have loved the full version, and I never understand the excuse that people have no time or short attention spans.  Take a look at Game Of Thrones or House Of Cards.  Complicated plots that have a wide following.
An in depth look at human nature in all its beauty and flaws carefully crafted by Julian Fellowes, I could watch this several times and not tire of it.
